Adventure Summary.name: Adventure Summary
Adventure Summary.text:
Crypt of Runes

In the Footsteps of Heroes

Throughout Crypt of Runes, you’ll see numerous references to previous Pathfinder Adventure Paths. The players should feel as if they’re following in the footsteps of past heroes as the adventure progresses! While you don’t need to be familiar with any previous Adventure Paths to enjoy this one, if your group has played through some of the adventures referenced in Crypt of Runes, this is a perfect opportunity to inject a bit of your own history into the game. Some of these opportunities include:

  • If previous PCs joined the Sihedron Council at the end of the Shattered Star Adventure Path, the current PCs might encounter some of them when they meet with the council in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor]{Chapter 1}.
  • If previous PCs defeated Zutha at the end of “Runeplague,” Book 3 of the Return of the Runelords Adventure Path, the current PCs might receive a vision of their past characters when they visit the Tarnished Temple of Xin.
  • If previous PCs played the Seven Dooms for Sandpoint Adventure Path, Liralarue might make cryptic mention of those heroes when the current PCs rescue her at the end of Crypt of Runes’ third chapter.

Chapter 1: History Has Broken

Having learned that the Risen of the Trinity Star have relocated to the Emerald Chambers, the PCs must locate the entrance to the Chambers and find a way to navigate them. Their research leads them to the Tarnished Temple of Xin. After facing the supernatural echo of Runelord Zutha, the PCs discover that the temple is now inhabited by Baolen, the Breaker of History—a kraken driven to destroy evidence of Golarion’s past.

Chapter 2: Ten Thousand Emerald Chambers

The PCs travel to the Velashu Uplands, where the entrance to the Chambers lies. Once there, they discover that the site has become a battleground for three feuding armies. Before they can enter the Emerald Chambers, however, the PCs must either arrange a ceasefire or find a way to distract the combatants. Thanks to their research at the Tarnished Temple of Xin, the PCs’ journey to the Chambers and the Crypt of Runes is relatively swift. To enter the wing associated with Pride, where the Risen of the Trinity Star are headquartered, they must first become the proxies of revenge for the Crypt’s embittered runelord legacies.

Chapter 3: Doorways to Dream and Doom

The PCs emerge from the Emerald Chambers with Aethusa, the former host of Runelord Xanderghul’s spirit, as an untrustworthy ally. Their most pressing concern is the knowledge that the Risen of the Trinity Star plan to open eight Doomsday Doors across the Saga Lands. The PCs must organize a response among their allies and race to foil as many of these plans as possible. Only then can the PCs research a way to free Aethusa from Xanderghul’s control. Doing so requires them to journey to the Dreamlands, where they must defeat a dream version of Aethusa and rescue another unlikely ally: the so-called Eighth Runelord, Liralarue.

Advancement Track

“Crypt of Runes” is designed for four characters.

15The PCs begin this adventure at 15th level.

16The PCs should reach 16th level just before entering the Crypt of Runes.

17The PCs should be 17th level upon emerging from the Emerald Chambers at the beginning of Chapter Three.

The PCs should reach 18th level by the end of this adventure.

History Has Broken.name: History Has Broken
History Has Broken.text:
Chapter 1: History Has Broken

During the previous adventure, the PCs learned that the true leader of the Risen of the Trinity Star is none other than Xanderghul, Runelord of Pride. While Xanderghul’s goals remain unclear, the PCs know that he recently possessed a woman named Aethusa and now seeks to bring untold devastation to the Saga Lands.

To prepare for the apocalypse he plans to unleash upon Golarion, Xanderghul relocated the Risen of the Trinity Star to an ancient Thassilonian site called the Emerald Chambers—more specifically, to the Crypt of Runes, a sprawling museum-tomb associated with Pride where the runelords of the past have been memorialized. Xanderghul found it easier to create additional risen runelords to serve as the commanders of his new cult at this location. The PCs already encountered some of these risen runelords during the previous adventure, and they are sure to face more once they confront the cult in their new headquarters.

While the party’s logical next step is to head to the Velashu Uplands, where the Emerald Chambers are said to be located, information about the Crypt of Runes—including the method by which they might navigate its sprawling interior—has been lost to time. Complicating matters further, the Velashu Uplands have become a battleground for the armies of Belimarius, the Velashu Horse Lords, and a mass of Noland raiders. As a result, the PCs can’t simply wander the Uplands until they stumble upon the Chambers. Even if they could manage to evade the armies, the Chambers themselves contain numerous locations linked together by a complicated maze of portals. While Xanderghul can simply rely on memory to navigate the Emerald Chambers, the PCs aren’t so fortunate. Instead, they must gather more information before entering the Chambers, lest they find themselves wandering an extradimensional labyrinth forever!

Seeking the Crypt of Runes.name: Seeking the Crypt of Runes
Seeking the Crypt of Runes.text:
Seeking the Crypt of Runes

Mythic Points

Opportunities for the PCs to regain Mythic Points by completing mythic deeds or defeating mythic foes appear in this adventure, but these aren’t the only ways to do so. Remember that a PC should regain a Mythic Point whenever they follow their Mythic Calling and when a PC achieves a legendary accomplishment. You should keep an eye out for opportunities to award the PCs these points. Though there are suggestions written out for when to award points during certain encounters in this adventure, you shouldn’t feel limited to these opportunities. Mythic Points fuel a mythic character’s story, and players shouldn’t feel constantly starved for them or afraid to use them out of fear of not being able to earn more! Critical successes on rolls can be a great opportunity to award a Mythic Point for a legendary accomplishment, for example, especially if the timing of that critical success is particularly cinematic or thematic for the PC in question. As long as the PCs don’t feel like they’re being punished for using these points and are simultaneously not spending them frivolously, the rate of Mythic Point renewal is about right!

Before the PCs can enter the Crypt of Runes, they must locate the entrance to the Emerald Chambers. While sifting through hundreds of years of Thassilonian history might seem daunting, knowing where to begin the search is relatively simple. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:30] or appropriate Lore check to Recall Knowledge is familiar with one of three locations where information about the Emerald Chambers might be found. If they critically succeed, the PC knows two locations. If the PCs ask Kandirvek, the omen dragon refers them to one of the locations (preferably one the PCs don’t know about themselves). Knowledge of even one of these leads is enough to get the PCs started on their journey.

The PCs might possess magic they can use to learn more, such as the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.hp6Q64dl7xbdn4gQ]{Collective Memories} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7DN13ILADW2N9Z1t]{Commune} rituals. Particularly successful attempts could yield information repurposed from the Emerald Chambers’ Research stat block (See @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01researching000]{Here}). Still, the PCs should visit the locations to gather all the information they need to safely navigate the Chambers. Doing so gives the PCs the opportunity to meet some of the individuals whose help they’ll need later in the adventure!

The three sources most likely to have stored key information about the Emerald Chambers are Magnimar’s Sihedron Council, Riddleport’s Cypher Lodge, and Korvosa’s Acadamae. The PCs can visit these locations in any order and can travel either as a group or strike out individually. Their journey to these sites passes uneventfully and, provided the PCs don’t dawdle overmuch, time shouldn’t be a pressing issue. You can calculate the party’s travel times to and from a particular location by referring to the Travel Speed table (Pathfinder Player Core 438), or you can simply assume the journey takes a handful of days, especially if the party uses teleportation magic to facilitate travel or if Kandirvek volunteers to fly the heroes between locations. Although stat blocks are provided for each of the cities, the adventure assumes the PCs don’t spend much time exploring them. If you feel your players are eager to put a stop to Xanderghul’s plans, you can skip directly to the meetings with the NPCs in charge of the research locations, handwaving away the journey between these sites entirely.

This section uses the research subsystem (Pathfinder GM Core 190). Each of the three research sites presents a challenge the PCs must overcome to gain access to that location’s most pertinent information about ancient Thassilon. When the PCs finish researching, calculate their total RP and compare the result to the thresholds in the Emerald Chambers stat block @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01researching000]{Here}.

Established Allies.name: Established Allies
Established Allies.text:
Established Allies

The PCs have already made a few powerful allies during the previous adventure—most notably, the omen dragon Kandirvek—but other NPCs like Ayavah may have become important parts of the PCs’ stories as well. These NPCs don’t have a “load bearing” role in this adventure or the next, but they can serve as additional allies for the PCs to call upon as they need. Just because the adventures have moved on to new places doesn’t mean old allies and friendships should be forgotten!

Kandirvek can fly the PCs quickly across the Saga Lands, a role he’s eager and willing to play. As the challenges the PCs face grow, Kandirvek might become more and more of a liability—and at the same time, the dragon shouldn’t steal the PCs’ glory. If he does aid them in this role, Kandirvek’s ability to help the PCs on-site should be limited. His prophetic wings ability can also work well to help get the PCs back on the plot’s track if they get stuck along the way.

This adventure assumes Ayavah remains in Vekker’s Crossing and is involved in helping to manage the refugees of Xin-Eurythnia, and as such, her influence at this stage is likely to be limited. PCs capable of teleporting across vast distances, however, can always make a quick trip to visit her as needed. In the next adventure, her role may well be larger as the PCs return to Xin-Eurythnia, so if they had a strong relationship with her in the first part of the Adventure Path, it’s a good idea to have her play a small role in this one, even if it’s only to send the PCs periodic updates about how the refugees are faring.

Tarnished Temple Features.text:
Tarnished Temple Features

All areas of the Tarnished Temple are unlit, except for the aboveground entrance (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01templeentran00]{A1}) and Baolen’s hall (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01baolenshallu00]{A7}). The height of the chambers varies, as detailed in the individual area descriptions. Many of the chambers are either partially or fully submerged, so the PCs will need magic that allows them to breathe underwater if they wish to explore the temple. Any of the NPCs in the previous section can arrange purchase of such items and might even suggest doing so if they learn about the party’s plans to travel to Xin.
Tarnished Temple Features.name: Tarnished Temple Features

The Nine Alcoves.text:
The Nine Alcoves

Near the entrance to each chamber, a plaque written in Azlanti describes that chamber’s former contents, but a PC must move within 15 feet of the entrance to read the plaque clearly. The titles on each one are indicated in quotes below. For each location, a Recall Knowledge DC is listed, should a PC wish to determine if they know more about a location—on a success, they recall the italicized information.

A7a. “The Black Squares of Ungevick”: @Check[arcana|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— Runelord Zutha created the Black Squares of Ungevick to serve as a vast, necromantic engine. The Squares are said to still exist beneath the sea off the southern coast of modern Varisia.

A7b. “Sech Nevali”: @Check[religion|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— Xirie, the first Runelord of Sloth, constructed Sech Nevali as the greatest of all temples devoted to the Peacock Spirit. It’s also known as the Hanging Monastery. The PCs might will potentially visit Sech Nevali later in the adventure during @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event3saving00]{Event 3 - Saving the Saga Lands}.

A7c. “Storval Stairs”: @Check[society|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— The Storval Stairs are a set of giant-sized tiers that ascend to the top of the Storval Rise. Runelord Karzoug directed the construction of the stairs, as well as the monumental statues that flank the steps.

A7d. “The Emerald Chambers”: @Check[arcana|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[religion|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— This location was built as a memorial for Xin, and to house tombs and memorials for other runelords and important figures in ancient Thassilon.

@UUID[Actor.Gpcu9OsQH4t1Jj4p]{Rubble}
This chamber has partially collapsed, and the emerald prototype the PCs need remains buried beneath the rubble. Locating the emerald among the chunks of stone requires a successful @Check[athletics|dc:34] check to move the rubble, followed by a successful @Check[perception|dc:36|traits:concentrate,secret,action:seek|name:Seek] check to Seek.

The Emerald Chambers prototype is an emerald roughly the size and shape of a human eye. Created during the Chambers’ original construction, the interior of this emerald eye contains a “blueprint” of the Chambers, allowing anyone who peers into its depths to Sense Direction in the Emerald Chambers. Though it appears identical to one of the eyes of the Silent Devotees the PCs will encounter on their way to the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02thecryptofru00]{Crypt of Runes}, this emerald eye has no additional magical properties. As a precious stone, it could be sold for 500 gp, or ten times that much to a collector of Thassilonian antiquities.

A7e. “Obelisk Forest of Mundatei”: @Check[nature|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— The Obelisk Forest of Mundatei lies in a valley at the foot of the Mindspin Mountains. The “forest” is made up of thousands of rune-carved obelisks said to contain treasure—or the entombed corpses of the forest’s builders.

A7f. “The Shining Queen”: @Check[arcana|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— The PCs likely recognize the Shining Queen by its modern name, the Sunken Queen—a ruined temple in the eastern Mushfens, the sides of which bear carved depictions of Runelord Sorshen, with curved spires radiating up from the pyramid’s top.

In addition to potentially learning the above information, the first time a PC touches the plaque, Sorshen takes the opportunity to establish a psychic link with that character from beyond reality, taking advantage of an ancient link between her and the contents of this alcove. She sends the character a vision of Eurythnia as she hopes to see it in the future: a thriving nation where artists, adventurers, and other misfits from across Golarion are welcomed. This message is key to the proper answer to the lust sentry’s question during the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02thetrialofru00]{The Trial of Runes}.

A7g. “Rimeskull”: @Check[arcana|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— Rimeskull is a mountain in northwestern Varisia. Today, the side of the mountain is carved in the image of a massive skull, though in its day the carving depicted the face of Emperor Xin.

A7h. “The Dome Hive”: @Check[society|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— The Dome Hive was a structure that served as the headquarters for ancient Edasseril’s legions of bureaucrats. The Hive towered over the buildings around it, each level filled with hundreds of offices, meeting rooms, and storage spaces.

A7i. “Azeradni’s Gardens”: @Check[nature|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]— Though no evidence of them survives today, the Gardens were purportedly created by Runelord Azeradni, the third Runelord of Sloth, using magical seeds that ensured the gardens never needed tending. The PCs may have discovered one of these effortless gardens in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5}.

Reward: If the PCs manage to succeed at all of the checks to learn about all nine of these alcoves, grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.
