Securing Support.name: Securing Support
Securing Support.text:
Securing Support

The adventure assumes the PCs have enough clout to arrange meetings with the prominent figures in charge of the three research sites they must visit to learn about the Emerald Chambers, but convincing them is a different matter altogether. At each of the three locations, the PCs are presented with a chance to make a case for why they should gain access to the research site. This section uses the Victory Points subsystem (GM Core 184).

Scene Notes Ambiences

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.J20s1QaMbwLAcn0i]{City} @UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.lwWPy9XdAnCwVtHr]{Indoors} @UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.C1Ayc4Kh3fh4Laxn]{Nature}

During each of these three encounters, the party can attempt four checks to earn Victory Points. Each time, the skill check rolled must be different, chosen from one of the options listed in that encounter—the PCs can’t roll more than once on any one check. At the end of the four checks or as soon as the party reaches 5 Victory Points (whichever comes first), compare the total Victory Points earned to the three tiers detailed for each encounter to determine the party’s results.

Sihedron Council.name: Sihedron Council
Sihedron Council.text:
Sihedron Council

The Sihedron Council of Magnimar has been interested in Thassilonian history and its magical traditions ever since they aided in the reassembly of the Thassilonian artifact known as the Sihedron in 4712 ar (an event that took place in “The Dead Heart of Xin,” Book 6 of the Shattered Star Adventure Path). Reforging the Sihedron awakened ancient dangers that nearly destroyed the city, so today, the members of the Sihedron Council—including its founder, Pathfinder Society Venture-Captain Sheila Heidmarch (pragmatic female human diplomat 9)—work not only to study the magic of ancient Thassilon, but to ensure such power never falls into the wrong hands.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.eRt3saugdROiK9Z7]{Sihedron Council}

The PCs can arrange a meeting with Sheila at Heidmarch Manor. The first Pathfinder lodge to be founded in Varisia, Heidmarch Manor is in Magnimar’s wealthy Alabaster district and is Sheila’s private estate. The manor grounds include the Meeting House, where the Pathfinder lodge itself is located, as well as individual cottages for visiting Pathfinders, each of which is named after one of ancient Thassilon’s realms (Bakrakhan House, Eurythnia House, and so on). For this meeting, however, Sheila arranges to speak with the PCs at her personal residence. Also in attendance is Sheila’s husband, Canayven Heidmarch (stern male human ranger 9), as well as Sheila’s awakened gorilla companion, Broxton (refined male awakened gorilla 6).

Other members of the Sihedron Council might attend the meeting, as well. One member sure to be present is Magnimar’s head priestess of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna}, Bevaluu Zimantiu (discerning female human cleric 11), who is particularly curious about the recent troubles in Xin-Eurythnia. If your group played the Shattered Star Adventure Path, PCs from that campaign might also be present at this meeting, using this opportunity to meet with a band of up-and-coming heroes.

Convince the Council

  • concentrate
  • Exploration

The party works to convince the Sihedron Council to aid their cause by attempting four of the following skill checks to earn Victory Points (VP).

@Check[pathfinder-society-lore|dc:32] (to appeal to the Heidmarchs while using their own society's traditions)

@Check[diplomacy|dc:33] (to make the request politely but earnestly, and to come across as responsible adventurers)

@Check[occultism|dc:34] (to prove to the council that you understand the dangers involved in meddling with ancient magic)

@Check[intimidation|dc:35] (to make the council understand and believe that you're not getting in over your head)

@Check[performance|dc:36] (to inspire the council with stories of your great adventures)

@Check[deception|dc:39] (to appear less unsavory and untrustworthy than expected)

1 VP Though Sheila is an expert in Thassilonian lore, none of the council members know much about the Emerald Chambers. They direct the PCs to the Museum of Ages, where the city's historical items (including those related to ancient Thassilon) are stored.

3 VP While at the Museum of Ages, the PCs are encouraged to inspect the remains of the clockwork constructs collected in the wake of the Sihedron's reforging. The council also calls upon Toth Bhreacher, fellow member of the Sihedron Council and the founder of Magnimar's Machineworks, to assist in this research. Toth's help grants the party a +2 circumstance bonus to checks made to Research at the Museum of Ages.

5 VP In addition to Toth's help (see above), the council offers to fund the party's efforts (see Treasure below).

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.zs9WbfOr2j0TVI1a]{Council's Gift}
If the PCs earn 5 Victory Points during their efforts to convince the Sihedron Council, the council funds the PCs by giving them 2,500 gp and a truesight potion.

Reward: Each Victory Point the PCs gain earns them 5 XP, for a total award of 25 XP if they earn 5 Victory Points. If a single PC earns more than 3 Victory Points during this encounter, grant them a Mythic Point for this legendary accomplishment.

Founder’s Archive and Museum of Ages.name: Founder’s Archive and Museum of Ages
Founder’s Archive and Museum of Ages.text:
Founder’s Archive and Museum of Ages

Magnimar Settlement 12

  • City

Government Lord-Mayor (autocracy)

Population 16,428 (81% humans, 5% halflings, 4% dwarves, 4% elves, 3% gnomes, 3% other)

Languages Common, Varisian

Religions @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.AlL9GtlTldbqNoVm]{Calistria}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.mm1j6UbHqFCI8fwB]{Erastil}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.eErEiVmBqltYXFJ6]{Iomedae}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.GX6PF9ifR47Xyjg9]{Norgorber}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.BNycwu3I21dTh4D9]{Sarenrae}, various Empyreal Lords

Threats monsters from the Mushfens, Korvosan aggression, criminals and thieves, strange intruders from within the Irespan

Cosmopolitan Magnimar is welcoming of a wide range of ancestries and heritages, and travelers encounter less prejudice here than they might in Korvosa or elsewhere. Diplomacy checks to Make an Impression gain a +1 circumstance bonus in Magnimar.

Bevaluu Zimantiu (discerning female human cleric 11), head priestess of Desna

Master Leis Nivlandis (insightful male aiuvarin wizard 12), head of the Stone of the Seers

Sabriyya Kalmeralm (cunning female human rogue 14), Lord-Mayor

The Founder’s Archive and Museum of Ages share a collection of buildings just north of Usher’s Hall in Magnimar’s Capital District. Established using municipal funds to encourage education and the arts, these institutions house documents related to Magnimar’s history and host rotating exhibits of objects on loan from private collectors. The institutions are run by Madam Irba Demerios (focused female human archivist 8), who oversees the Founder’s Archive, and Doctor Ernst Landis (esteemed male human wizard 10), who curates the Museum of Ages. Assuming the party’s meeting with the Sihedron Council went smoothly, Sheila Heidmarch has already sent word to both Irba and Ernst, asking them to help the PCs in their investigation. If the PCs earned at least 3 Victory Points during that meeting, Toth Bhreacher (industrious male human wizard 16) also greets the PCs as they arrive.

While the Founder’s Archive and the Museum of Ages host a wealth of information about ancient Thassilon, records regarding the Emerald Chambers are sparse. However, when Xin’s clockwork army washed ashore in the aftermath of the Sihedron’s reforging, the members of the Sihedron Council collected many of the constructs for further study. Research into the constructs is ongoing, but it’s clear they were built on the Isle of Xin. As the PCs sift through the information stored in the Museum of Ages, they should soon realize that the constructs represent their best chance for learning more about the Emerald Chambers.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.vw2dWM1cLwQUFRAu]{Hall}

If Toth Bhreacher accompanies the party, he proves familiar with the constructs and is quick to suggest this path of inquiry. Toth has done more research into Thassilonian constructs than anyone else in Magnimar; in fact, he was the first person to identify that the clockwork constructs were created by First King Xin. While most of the constructs are beyond repair, Toth leads the party to an extraordinary model housed in the museum’s basement. This construct has been crafted in the likeness of an enormous, predatory whale. Though the construct—a clockwork whale (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22006advent.JournalEntryPage.06clockworkwha00]{Here})—shows clear signs of damage, Toth believes it could hold secrets somewhere inside its gear-filled “brain.” He agrees to help the party access the whale’s programming to learn more. (As a reminder, Toth grants the PCs a +1 circumstance bonus to checks made to Research at the Museum of Ages).

Damaged Clockwork Whale: The PCs study information stored in the “brain” of a clockwork whale.

  • Maximum RP 4
  • Research Checks @Check[clockwork-lore|dc:32|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to know how best to interpret the clockwork’s stored information, @Check[arcana|dc:34|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or @Check[crafting|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to safely access the “brain” of the clockwork whale.
  • Special If the PCs score a critical failure on any check, the construct reactivates and goes berserk, inflicting @Damage[12d8[bludgeoning]] on every PC (a basic @Check[reflex|dc:36|basic] save).

Cypher Lodge.name: Cypher Lodge
Cypher Lodge.text:
Cypher Lodge

Riddleport Settlement 10

  • City

Government Titular overlord with competing crime lords

Population 13,300 (77% humans, 7% dwarves, 5% aiuvarins, 4% dromaars, 7% other)

Languages Common, Varisian

Religions @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.wkDOeK7ENz1ra8IC]{Besmara}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.AlL9GtlTldbqNoVm]{Calistria}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.v67fHklTZ6LoU54q]{Cayden Cailean}

Threats pirates and other criminal elements, warring crime lords, reckless Cyphergate scholars

Blind Eye to Crime When confronted with suspicious behavior, the wary residents of Riddleport know not to ask too many questions. Deception checks to Impersonate gain a +1 circumstance bonus in the city.

Avery Slyeg (brash male aiuvarin smuggler 8), crime lord and owner of the River Runner Inn

Elias Tammerhawk (opportunistic male human wizard 15), Speaker of the Order of Cyphers

Gaston Cromarcky (pragmatic male Varisian fighter 12), Overlord of Riddleport

Perched atop a crag on the slopes of Riddleport’s western ridge, the Cypher Lodge is the headquarters of the Order of Cyphers, a group dedicated to uncovering the truth behind the enigmatic symbols inscribed upon Thassilonian monuments. Part laboratory and part museum, the Cypher Lodge is open to all members of the order and offers limited access to its archives to non-members for a small daily fee. To learn more about the Emerald Chambers, the PCs need information the order normally restricts from non-members.

The PCs can request access to the order’s restricted archives by speaking to Elias Tammerhawk (opportunistic male human wizard 15), the order’s leader. Elias responds by asking to meet the party in a local watering hole called the Murky Maiden. He asks the PCs to arrive discreetly but tells them little else for the time being.

Much like Sheila Heidmarch in Magnimar, Elias is concerned about the threat the legacy of ancient Thassilon poses to Varisia. In fact, he’s moved much of the order’s most sensitive research (including the information the PCs need) to his private townhouse. Though hesitant to open his library to what might be trouble-making adventurers, Elias never misses a chance to take advantage of a situation. He says the PCs can ease his misgivings if they help him deal with a “little problem” he’s run into with the local authorities.

Scene Notes Ambiences

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.JhHKKDoblRQcrScR]{The Murky Maiden} @UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.vw2dWM1cLwQUFRAu]{Hall}

Recently, one of Elias’s trusted subordinates, Venton Derrard (devious male human thief 7), was arrested as a suspect in a high-profile burglary. Venton is currently being held in custody at Shoreleave, Riddleport’s fortress-prison. While Elias admits Venton is guilty of his crimes (this is Riddleport, after all), he stresses that the arrest was politically motivated. Elias explains that Shoreleave’s jailor, General Anton Mescher (efficient male human jailor 4), is in league with Gaston Cromarcky (calculating male human politician 12), Riddleport’s current overlord and Elias’s chief political rival. If the PCs secure Venton’s release, Elias promises to open the contents of his private library to them.

Before the PCs start planning an elaborate jailbreak, Elias offers them enough money to simply buy Venton’s freedom: a hefty bribe of 400 pp. He explains that the coins must be paid to Gaston directly, and that the PCs will have to convince the overlord that they’re unconnected to Elias, lest Gaston refuse the bribe out of spite. Elias can help the PCs devise a good cover story—probably that they hate Elias as much as Gaston does and want Venton for their own reasons—but ultimately, they must rely on their own guile to complete the mission.

Bribe the Overlord

  • concentrate
  • Exploration

The party meets with Gaston Cromarcky, overlord of Riddleport, and then tries to convince him to accept a bribe in return for freeing Venton Derrard. They must attempt four of the following skill checks to earn Victory Points (VP).

@Check[underworld-lore|dc:32] (to use the proper thieves’ etiquette in the meeting)

@Check[intimidation|dc:33] (to fight fire with fire and appear menacing and threatening)

@Check[thievery|dc:34] (to subtly let Gaston know through hand signals that it’s in his best interest to comply)

@Check[deception|dc:35] (to trick Gaston into thinking he’s making the decision instead of being manipulated into it)

@Check[athletics|dc:36] (to present yourself as an impressive figure worthy of Gaston’s time and attention)

@Check[diplomacy|dc:39] (to be patient and respectful in a way that doesn’t annoy Gaston or make him see you as weak-willed)

1 VP Gaston accepts the bribe but sees through the PCs’ cover story and regards them as fools—an opinion he makes sure they know.

3 VP Gaston falls for the cover story, accepts the bribe, and thanks the PCs for doing business with him. When the PCs return to Elias with the news, he’s relieved enough that he can concentrate and focus more, and he is willing provide aid to the PCs when they investigate his library. His help grants the PCs a +2 circumstance bonus to Research in Elias’s Private Library.

5 VP Gaston is impressed (and perhaps a bit unnerved) by the PCs and waves a hand to deny the bribe, explaining that he’d only imprisoned Venton to make a point to the thief and that, surely, he’s learned his lesson by now. Elias also provides aid during the research (see above).

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.FbPaVqcUmUNhMfEg]{Elias' Reward}
If the PCs earn 5 Victory Points and return with the bribe intact, Elias is astounded and gives them the 400 pp as a reward.

Reward: Each Victory Point the PCs gain earns them 5 XP, for a total award of 25 XP if they earn 5 Victory Points. If a single PC earns more than 3 Victory Points during this encounter, grant them a Mythic Point for this legendary accomplishment.

Elias’s Private Library.name: Elias’s Private Library
Elias’s Private Library.text:
Elias’s Private Library

Elias Tammerhawk’s residence is on the west bank of the Velashu River, not far from the Cypher Lodge itself. The residence’s unassuming facade conceals a sprawling sub-basement in which Elias stores documents and other research regarding ancient Thassilon. While Elias claims that he plans to return this trove once he can “ensure the public’s safety,” he has no intention of doing so anytime soon. The documents are mixed with his personal research, as well as with a collection of modern Chelaxian statuary that Elias recently accepted as payment for a debt. The result is a disorganized mess the PCs must sift through to find the information they seek.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.lwWPy9XdAnCwVtHr]{Indoors}

Elias’s Library: The PCs do their best to find their way through the disorganized library and learn what they can from its contents.

  • Maximum RP 4
  • Research Checks @Check[library-lore|dc:32|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to search for pertinent information, @Check[athletics|dc:34|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to clear the statuary and give your companions a place to work, or @Check[occultism|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to understand which documents are related to the Emerald Chambers.
  • Special If the PCs score a critical failure on any check, they accidently damage some of the library’s contents, which increases the DCs for all future checks by 1 each time.

The Acadamae.name: The Acadamae
The Acadamae.text:
The Acadamae

The Acadamae is a notoriously demanding wizard’s college and one of Korvosa’s jewels. Its headmaster, Toff Ornelos (weary male human wizard 17), agrees to the speak with the PCs but insists his time is limited. The meeting takes place in the headmaster’s office in Ornelos Hall, a tidy chamber filled with floor-to-ceiling bookshelves. As the PCs speak, Toff briskly signs a stack of writs while glancing at his office door, as if already awaiting his next appointment.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.lwWPy9XdAnCwVtHr]{Indoors}

Gain Headmaster’s Support

  • concentrate
  • Exploration

The party meets with Toff Ornelos, headmaster of Korvosa’s Acadamae, in a brief but intense meeting to secure access to the school’s resources and investigate the Emerald Chambers. They must attempt four of the following skill checks to earn Victory Points.

@Check[academia-lore|dc:32] (to know how to swiftly navigate the pitfalls of university bureaucracy)

@Check[deception|dc:33] (to trick Toff into thinking that the PCs are alumni in good standing; if the PC making the check is an actual alumnus of the Acadamae, they can instead attempt a @Check[diplomacy|dc:25] check to earn Victory Points)

@Check[arcana|dc:34] (to appeal as a fellow scholar of arcane magic and impress Toff with your knowledge)

@Check[diplomacy|dc:35] (to eloquently and delicately make a request in a polite but efficient manner)

@Check[society|dc:36] (to speak clearly, quickly, and to the point, making it obvious you’re respecting Toff’s time)

@Check[intimidation|dc:39] (to argue forcefully and make veiled threats against a headmaster who’s been through a lot worse in his life)

1 VP Toff grows impatient and brusquely dismisses the PCs, telling them to go speak to Planchara in the Hall of Whispers and stop wasting his time.

3 VP Toff regards the PCs with an appraising eye, then nods as if he approves of what he sees. He quickly pens a pass for them to present to Plachara, telling them to visit her in the Hall of Whispers. This pass also informs Plachara that she is to aid the PCs in their investigation, which grants them a +2 circumstance bonus to checks made to Research in the Hall of Whispers.

5 VP Toff is delighted by the PCs and invites them to come back some day and regale him with tales of their adventures when they and (more importantly) he have more time to spend in discussion. He gives the PCs a pass to the Hall of Whispers (see above), as well as a few additional supplies to aid them (see Treasure, below).

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.x62e5Bre3vR9Kz4V]{Toff's Reward}
If the PCs earn 5 Victory Points, Toff sifts through some papers on his desk before handing them a stack of six scrolls to aid them in their efforts: two scrolls of sending, two 7th-rank scrolls of teleport, and two 8th-rank scrolls of summon fiend.

Reward: Each Victory Point the PCs gain earns them 5 XP, for a total award of 25 XP if they earn 5 Victory Points. If a single PC earns more than 3 Victory Points in this encounter, grant them a Mythic Point for this legendary accomplishment.

The Hall of Whispers.name: The Hall of Whispers
The Hall of Whispers.text:
The Hall of Whispers

Korvosa Settlement 11

  • City

Government Queen (constitutional monarch)

Population 15,250 (79% humans, 6% dwarves, 4% elves, 3% halflings, 3% aiuvarins, 2% gnomes, 3% other)

Languages Common, Shoanti, Varisian

Religions @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.d56paSkcwvll2OhR]{Abadar}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QRkcFciCOmFoxF1B]{Asmodeus}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.BNycwu3I21dTh4D9]{Sarenrae}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.gxwmzxUWBOhdgFSN]{Shelyn}

Threats crime family violence, Ileosa loyalists, underground dangers

Comfortable with Command Korvosa’s residents are used to taking orders both from the city’s former patron, Cheliax, and the city’s own monarchs. Intimidation checks to Coerce gain a +1 circumstance bonus in the city.

Boule (imposing male human rogue 6), guildmaster of the Cerulean Society thieves’ guild

Cressida Kroft (diligent female human monarch 10), former field marshal and reluctant queen of Korvosa

Toff Ornelos (weary male human wizard 17), headmaster of the Acadamae

The Hall of Whispers sits on the eastern side of the Acadamae and is dedicated to the study of death, undeath, and Void magic. Rumors that the building serves as the final resting place of students who die during their terms at the Acadamae are exaggerated; nonetheless, the Hall of Whispers is an ominous place filled with shadowy corridors, cobweb-filled reading rooms, and the occasional mindless undead servant.

Planchara Ebongrave (cautious female dromaar spiritualist 15), the dean of the Hall of Whispers, was the mastermind behind the construction of the Acadamae’s copy of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.dP5OmTGy0NJl4a1D]{The Kardosian Fragments}, an attempt to reconstruct portions of a greater tome penned by Runelord Zutha. The original Kardosian Codex represented one third of an even larger work, the Gluttonous Tome, to which Zutha bound his essence. All three sections of the original Gluttonous Tome have been destroyed, but Planchara suspects a fragment of Zutha’s angry spirit haunts the Kardosian Fragments. Planchara has put off studying the tome for fear that doing so might open a door for Zutha to slip back into the Universe, but upon hearing the PCs need to learn more about the Emerald Chambers, she swiftly realizes that this dangerous text could be the best place to look for information. There are old tales, after all, that suggest that the Emerald Chambers are themselves a vast tomb.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.vw2dWM1cLwQUFRAu]{Hall}

A cursory inspection of the Kardosian Fragments reveals that it is filled with a scattershot of all manner of necromantic rites and notes related to the creation and control of undead, but that it contains little information about the Emerald Chambers. Instead of studying the book directly, Planchara suggests the PCs open their minds to serve as a conduit for Zutha’s spirit, so that the party can interrogate the runelord “in the flesh,” as it were. The PC who chooses to do so must spend 10 minutes under Planchara’s guidance meditating before the Kardosian Fragments, after which their eyes turn white, their posture distorts into an awkward hunched stance, and their voice becomes deep and liquid, as if they were speaking through a huge chest filled with lungs drowning in blood. This process can be repeated as often as the PCs wish. When a PC ends a session of channeling Zutha, that PC must attempt a @Check[will|dc:34] save to resist becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} with an unlimited duration (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} with an unlimited duration on a critical failure).

The Kardosian Fragments: The PCs interrogate the shattered remnants of Zutha’s spirit to learn what he knows of the Emerald Chambers, using one of their own as a medium for the conversation.

  • Maximum RP 4
  • Research Checks @Check[will|dc:32|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] saving throw to battle Zutha mentally during the interrogation (this check may only be made by the PC serving as the vessel), @Check[diplomacy|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or Intimidation to demand or coax answers from Zutha’s spirit (these checks cannot be made by the PC serving as the vessel).

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.0rMYaEtY7FL40tMa]{Planchara's Reward}
Once the PCs earn all 4 RP from @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.dP5OmTGy0NJl4a1D]{The Kardosian Fragments}, Planchara entrusts them with the text, as she wants nothing more to do with it.

Researching.name: Researching
Researching.text:
Researching

While the PCs gain access to the three research opportunities, they’ll be able to conduct investigations using the following Research stat block. While it’s unlikely the party will fail to secure at least a basic amount of help from the NPCs in this section, if the PCs suffer a spate of poor rolls (or if they go out of their way to insult a particular NPC), they might find themselves limited to two or even one research opportunity. The good news here is that the PCs only really need to achieve 2 Research Points to know where to go next—the information and benefits gained at higher Research Point thresholds will make their subsequent adventures run more smoothly but aren’t required for the plot to continue.

In the unlikely event the PCs fail to secure access to any of the research sites, they could ask for advice from their omen dragon ally, Kandirvek, who might be able to use his prophetic wings to guide the PCs toward the Isle of Xin. Alternatively, a PC who has the Avenging Runelord mythic destiny might have a dream in which their associated runelord spirit guides them toward the isle. You could even have one of the three groups the PCs visited take pity on them and contact the party with the 2 Research Point information block below after they become intrigued enough by the PCs’ plight to do some research on their own. In any of these cases, it’s best to work with the PCs’ suggestions and give them a chance to learn that the Isle of Xin should be their next stop even though they’ll miss out on the treasure and experience points they could have otherwise earned by visiting the three sites.

The Emerald Chambers Research 15

  • unique
  • arcane

Research Checks Founder’s Archive and Museum of Ages (Magnimar), Elias Tammerhawk’s library (Riddleport), Hall of Whispers (Korvosa)

2 Research Points Originally, the Emerald Chambers were built to serve as the final resting place of First King Xin, and the original plans for the Emerald Chambers were drawn up on the Isle of Xin, the same place from which the constructs housed at the Museum of Ages are thought to originate. This isle may be the best place to investigate for clues next. Furthermore, the Emerald Chambers are filled with hundreds of extradimensional spaces linked by magical portals. A group of martial spellcasters known as the Silent Devotees, ancient Thassilonians who underwent a painful rite to transform themselves into immortal guardians, patrol these portals and the chambers. According to legend, the devotees possess the ability to “step through space” and cast an eerie pall of magical silence.

4 Research Points The entrance to the Emerald Chambers lies in a valley in the Velashu Uplands. After Xin was laid to rest, the individual runelords claimed various parts of the Chambers for their own and erected enormous statues called “Rune Sentries” to guard the Chambers’ entrance. One location of particular note within the Emerald Chambers, the Crypt of Runes, was shared by all seven runelords. The Crypt of Runes served as a memorial for all the previous runelords, with each sin having a separate wing within the Crypt. As one of the primary architects of the Emerald Chambers, Runelord Xanderghul saw to it that the section of the Crypt of Runes associated with himself and the sin of pride was the most extensive, and rumors held that he continued to use this location as a secret laboratory up until the days before Earthfall. This section of the Crypt of Runes within the Emerald Chambers seems the most logical place to seek the Risen of the Trinity Star, but unfortunately, only the runelords, the Silent Devotees, or someone with a copy of the original plans for the Chambers could navigate to the Crypt of Runes without becoming hopelessly lost. This level of research prepares the PCs for their inevitable interaction with the Rune Sentries, granting them a +1 circumstance bonus to all skill checks made during the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02thetrialofru00]{Trial of Runes}.

6 Research Points During the Chambers’ construction, “prototypes” of the site were created in the form of magic emeralds. Each emerald was a miniature version of the Chambers and allowed the first Silent Devotees to navigate them without becoming lost. One of these emeralds was put on display in the Tarnished Temple on the Isle of Xin, a museum dedicated the greatest monuments of ancient Thassilon. The amount of information the PCs have learned will greatly help them navigate the perils that await them on Xin and in the Tarnished Temple—all Perception checks to notice hidden features or Hazards, as well as all checks made to disable hazards, while on the Isle or in the Tarnished Temple gain a +3 circumstance bonus as a result of the PCs’ extensive research.

Reward: For every 2 RP the party earns, award them 10 XP, to a maximum of 30 XP if the PCs earn all 6 RP.

To the Tarnished Temple.name: To the Tarnished Temple
To the Tarnished Temple.text:
To the Tarnished Temple

Making Connections

Though the players don’t know it yet, their characters might need to call upon the individuals they meet while researching the Emerald Chambers to prevent the opening of the Doomsday Doors during @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa]{Chapter 3}. How the PCs interact with these individuals will inform the tough choices they must make later in the adventure. Avoid simply hand-waving the party’s meetings with these NPCs, even with “side characters” such as Canayven Heidmarch in Magnimar or Planchara of Korvosa’s Acadamae. While the characters might not like everyone they meet during this section (Gaston Cromarcky of Riddleport, for example), forming a coalition from these disparate personalities is one of the Mythic Deeds the PCs must perform to prevent Golarion’s destruction!

Soon after Xin’s death, the runelords of Thassilon decided a mausoleum should be built in his honor. They designed this memorial in the city of Xin, a neutral ground where all seven runelords could meet on equal footing. In the end, however, Xanderghul’s force of personality ensured that Xin’s mausoleum would be built in Cyrusian, the empire of pride. Further, a special section of the Chambers called the Crypt of Runes would be created to memorialize all runelords from that point on, so that they could be honored alongside First King Xin, and here again Xanderghul’s pride won out, for the section of the Crypt of Runes devoted to his own legacy would be the largest of the seven by far.

By this point, the PCs should know that to navigate the Emerald Chambers and find the Crypt of Runes, they’ll first have to travel to the Isle of Xin, where the plans for the Emerald Chambers were designed. The city of Xin lies 100 miles west of Magnimar. Ships avoid approaching the isle due to its dangerous waters and powerful denizens, so if the PCs wish to sail to Xin, they’ll need to purchase or charter a ship on their own, likely from Magnimar. A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.vehicles.Actor.Qlvei5jjRXdsXUPo]{Cutter} is a good choice to purchase for 750 gp if the PCs want to sail to Xin themselves. If they prefer to charter a larger sailing ship, they can do so for 100 gp plus a deposit of an additional 2,000 gp—the deposit is refundable if the ship makes it back to Magnimar in one piece. If the PCs approach the Sihedron Council for aid, the council covers all costs for the trip and deposit if the PCs achieved at least 3 VP when speaking with them earlier. Via ship, the trip to Xin takes four to five days of sailing. Encounters with dangerous sea monsters along the way can give your PCs a chance to earn some extra XP if you feel like they’re running behind!

Scene Notes Ambiences

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.qhfAx0Hhuq5LtFUe]{Ship Voyage} @UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.j4yVod9SP9KRdhAq]{Island}

Magic can also be used. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.U0hL0LLaprcnAyzC]{Migration} is an excellent choice here, as the island is easily in range of this spell; PCs using migration can make the trip via flight or by swimming in just five hours. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WPKJOhEihhcIm2uQ]{Marvelous Mount} heightened so that the mounts can walk on water or fly can also work here, but even if heightened to 8th rank with a fly Speed of 80 feet, a marvelous mount will still need multiple castings or days to make the 100 mile trip. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} can shorten the trip only if the PCs can swim. Nature’s pathway is useless, as even today, no trees grow atop the barren isle.

It’s simple enough for a PC to study up on Xin’s location and appearance, using sea charts and descriptions from previous visitors, over the course of 8 hours of research in Magnimar, at which point @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.69L70wKfGDY66Mk9]{Teleport} could become a viable option. A 100 mile teleportation could put the PCs a mile off the coastline of the relatively small island, leaving them with a long swim or a short flight to make up the last bit of travel! This makes teleport a better option for when the PCs return from Xin to the mainland.

Of course, if the PCs remain friends with Kandirvek, the omen dragon is more than willing to fly them out to the island. This is the most convenient option available, as Kandirvek can cover the distance from Magnimar to Xin in about five and a half hours. The Tarnished Temple is located on an islet near the Isle of Xin’s southwestern coast, and the PCs should be able to spot it with little trouble.

Baolen, Breaker of History.name: Baolen, Breaker of History
Baolen, Breaker of History.text:
Baolen, Breaker of History

Soon after the Isle of Xin reemerged from the ocean over a decade ago, scholars and treasure-seekers alike flocked to the island in hopes of recovering relics of Golarion’s past. Xin is now shunned by most of the world, with one notable exception. Several years ago, a group of sedacthies known as the Kraken Callers came to Xin and began exploring the ruins around the isle. In the waters below an islet on Xin’s southwestern coast, the sedacthies discovered a network of chambers arranged around a central hall that had gone unexplored since Xin sank into the sea.

Unbeknownst to the Kraken Callers, they had discovered the ruins of the Tarnished Temple, a museum built by Emperor Xin to honor the seven convictions of rule. The sedacthies settled into the chambers and began collecting treasures from nearby Xin. Using these relics as offerings, they lured a kraken named Baolen, the Breaker of History, to the waters around their new home. Baolen had interest in such treasures, due to his ability to glimpse visions of alternate pasts—histories that could have been, but never came to pass. When the Kraken Callers collapsed the entrance to the Tarnished Temple’s central hall behind him, Baolen was content to accept the sedacthies’ adoration rather than escape.

Unfortunately for the PCs, Baolen is more concerned with destroying Golarion’s history than preserving it. Born with a passion for knowledge, Baolen underwent a ritual centuries ago that would have allowed him to fill in the gaps of history by witnessing the past firsthand. The ritual failed, however, cursing the kraken with visions of false pasts. In a vain attempt to make sense of these visions, Baolen destroys ancient treasures and any records that contradict the pasts he sees. From stone tablets etched with decrees that were ancient even before the reign of Xin to the busts of haughty runelords, there is no historical artifact that is safe from Baolen’s fury.

While many of the books, tablets, and scrolls contained in the Tarnished Temple were destroyed when the Isle of Xin sank into the sea, some were sealed in magically protected vaults or were simply resistant to the elements and survived. Among these relics is the Emerald Chambers prototype the PCs need. Sorting through the items Baolen has already destroyed, however, is a daunting task—and one the kraken is unlikely to let the PCs undertake unopposed.

The Kraken Callers.name: The Kraken Callers
The Kraken Callers.text:
The Kraken Callers

The sedacthies known as the Kraken Callers have always worshipped krakens, but until they “captured” Baolen they’d never managed to gain one’s attention so thoroughly. Though Baolen barely notices the sedacthies’ devotion, he finds the Callers useful and so plays the role of captive god in return for continued offerings. For their part, the Kraken Callers serve Baolen by collecting—and then destroying—objects gathered from the nearby Isle of Xin. When not exploring Xin, resting in their sleeping grottoes (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01sleepinggrot00]{A4}), or receiving visions from Baolen’s retrocognitive ink (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01murkywatersu00]{A6}), the sedacthies toil in their workshop (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5}) destroying objects under the direction of their leader, a sedacthy wizard named Maddenmist. Once aware of intruders, the sedacthies coordinate their efforts, sacrificing their lives to protect Baolen.

Temple Entrance.name: Temple Entrance
Temple Entrance.text:
A1. Temple Entrance Severe 15

This islet is crowded with toppled columns and slabs of black marble, as if the flotsam of an ancient city was once delivered onto its shores by a wave of unimaginable size. A stone’s throw away from the islet, strange shapes poke above the waterline—the upper portions of titanic statues, their lower bodies hidden beneath the waves. A triumphal arch rises from the islet’s highest point, its upper reaches missing as if swatted by one of the submerged statues’ giant hands. Before the broken arch, a block of marble serves as an altar of some kind.

The PCs can land on the islet anywhere they choose, but mounds of rubble and its natural topography have combined to form a 50-foot-high cliff along the islet’s westernmost shore. Climbing the cliff requires a successful @Check[athletics|dc:20|traits:move,skill,action:climb|name:Climb] check.

A1a. Buried Entrance: The entrance to the Tarnished Temple isn’t immediately obvious, as the stairwell leading into the islet’s interior down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01waterlineund00]{A2} is hidden beneath a pile of rubble. A PC who spends an hour Searching the islet and succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:30|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check will discover the buried entrance. Though clearing the rubble is a trivial task, it still requires an hour of work. Once cleared, a five-foot-wide stairwell is revealed—it leads down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01waterlineund00]{A2}.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.h4UxAClzeny99bbe]{Reveal Entrance}

Zutha’s Defeat

The events of the Return of the Runelords Adventure Path took place in 4718 AR, roughly 7 years before the PCs arrive at the Tarnished Temple of Xin. Return of the Runelords followed a group of heroes as they worked to prevent several runelords—including Zutha, the Runelord of Greed—from reawakening and returning to Golarion. In “Runeplague,” Book 3 of that Adventure Path, the heroes traveled to the Tarnished Temple, the very site where the current PCs now stand. There, they used the Bone Grimoire—one third of the Gluttonous Tome—to draw power from the Netherworld and incarnate the runelord into a shadowy simulacrum of his former self. The heroes emerged victorious, and as a result, the Gluttonous Tome crumbled to dust, permanently killing the last runelord of gluttony.

If you and your players have played through Return of the Runelords, those characters are the same heroes the current PCs witness in their vision at the Tarnished Temple! Use this opportunity to recount the heroes’ adventures on the isle, incorporating your previous play experiences into the vision the current PCs receive. If you haven’t played Return of the Runelords, the events of the vision remain the same, except Runelord Zutha meets his end at the hands of other heroes—either iconic characters (such as Feiya the iconic witch or Kyra the iconic cleric) or heroes of your own creation.

A1b. Altar: Several years ago, a band of heroes used the altar on the islet’s southwest end to summon—and summarily defeat—a manifestation of Runelord Zutha, forever preventing the runelord from returning to Golarion. A character who Searches near the altar discovers broken arrows, dented shields, and scorch marks that suggest a great battle took place there nearly a decade or so ago.

Characters who approach the altar feel an indefinable dread radiating from the stone, another hint that something truly momentous once occurred in the area. A PC trained in Arcana, Occultism, or Religion notices this energy and realizes that meditating on the power could grant them insight. Doing so takes 1 minute, after which the PC can attempt a @Check[arcana|dc:34] or @Check[occultism|dc:34] check or a @Check[religion|dc:36] check with the following results.

Critical Success The PC receives a vision of the battle during which Runelord Zutha was defeated (see the Zutha’s Defeat sidebar above). As part of this glimpse, the PC realizes there are chambers below the islet, and that an entrance to these chambers lies buried not far to the northeast (at area A1a). This insight grants the PC a +4 circumstance bonus to skill checks to recite the details of Runelord Zutha’s downfall when facing his haunt (as detailed in the Disable section of the haunt’s stat block). The first PC to achieve a critical success here earns 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Success As critical success, but the insight grants the PC a +2 circumstance bonus instead.

Failure As success, except the flashes of insight the PC receives are brief and somewhat confusing. The PC gains no bonus against Zutha’s haunt.

Critical Failure The PC doesn’t receive a vision. Instead, they feel the lingering presence of Zutha’s rage emanating from the altar. When Zutha’s haunt is triggered, the PC treats the result of their saving throw against the haunt’s Howl of Rage as one degree of success worse.

A1. Temple Entrance Severe 15

@UUID[Actor.cKz5NI6RnGaGvYeK]{Zutha's Legacy}

Hazard: Zutha’s soul cage, an unholy grimoire known as the Gluttonous Tome, was destroyed forever when a band of heroes successfully completed a ritual to prevent the Runelord’s return to Golarion. However, dangerous echoes of Zutha’s spirit continue to haunt this site. Before the PCs descend into the islet’s interior, Zutha’s haunt manifests. While Zutha wasn’t a mythic spellcaster himself, the fragments of his spirit have interacted with the legacy of all runelords of gluttony and the energies of the Isle of Xin to create a potent mythic hazard.

As a reminder, characters who received a vision of Zutha’s defeat gain a +2 circumstance bonus to checks made to recite those details (or a +4 if they critically succeeded). A character holding the Kardosian Fragments gains a +2 item bonus to checks made to exorcise Zutha’s spirit.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.eNSgvvxzYxIj1mhY]{Altar}
Objects left behind by previous expeditions lie scattered around the altar. A PC who Searches the area uncovers a +2 greater striking keen kukri, a major sturdy shield, a scroll case containing a scroll of moment of renewal, a scroll of sunburst, and a scroll of water breathing (4th rank), and a greater countering charm containing a dominate spell.

Reward: Defeating Zutha’s legacy is a Mythic Deed that grants each character 3 Mythic Points.

Waterline.name: Waterline
Waterline.text:
A2. Waterline Moderate 15

The stairwell descends deep into the islet’s interior before opening into a spacious chamber whose floor has nearly entirely collapsed. A pool of water choked with rubble fills its place. Judging from the salt deposits on the walls, the pool connects to the ocean somewhere deep beneath its surface. A ragged walkway of unbroken floor surrounds the pool.

Though heavily damaged, the murals in this room depict the runelords and their servants as they created the various monuments found in Varisia today. Many of these monuments are immediately recognizable to a well-traveled viewer, including Skull’s Crossing, a dam built by Runelord Karzoug to hold back the waters of Storval Deep; the Lady’s Light, a towering statue of Runelord Sorshen that stands in the south-westernmost reaches of the Mushfens; and the Irespan, a cyclopean bridge that once spanned over 200 miles of Runelord Alaznist’s empire of Bakrakhan.

A character who succeeds at a @Check[crafting|dc:40] check recognizes that, though the murals date to the creation of the Tarnished Temple, the damage to them is more recent. Shortly after the Kraken Callers “captured” Baolen, Maddenmist ordered the sedacthies to vandalize the murals.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.Xn8kk2lDSg7gwdfC]{Reveal Deeper Passageway}

A submerged opening to a deeper passageway lies at the bottom of the pool, roughly 20 feet below the water’s surface. Rubble obscures the opening, making spotting it from the shore nearly impossible for anyone who Searches this room without entering the water (a @Check[perception|dc:45|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search]). This difficulty decreases to a @Check[perception|dc:30|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] for a character who Swims in the pool. The passage leads to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01antechamber000]{A3}.

A2. Waterline Moderate 15

@UUID[Actor.O3qCfocT5hEWpENd]{Clockwork Whale}

Creature: When the Kraken Callers first discovered the Tarnished Temple, they found a clockwork whale trapped in this chamber. The sedacthies hijacked the whale’s programming and set it to guard the entrance to their lair. The creature is similar in construction to the one the PCs might have seen while visiting the Museum of Ages in Magnimar, though it is in noticeably better condition.

The whale floats near the rubble at the bottom of the pool until a creature enters the water, at which point it rises to attack. The whale pursues foes, hauling itself out of the pool and onto dry ground if necessary. While it can’t fit up the steps to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01templeentran00]{A1}, it can easily swim down the passage to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01antechamber000]{A3}. If the clockwork whale does so, the sounds of combat there rouse the sedacthies in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01sleepinggrot00]{A4} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5}. If the sedacthies arrive before the PCs defeat the whale, this encounter escalates to Severe or beyond.

Antechamber.name: Antechamber
Antechamber.text:
A3. Antechamber

The submerged hallway opens out into another, much smaller pool. Steps rise from the water to a pillared landing on the chamber’s northern arc. The sounds of chisels striking stone issue from an archway at the back of the balcony. Across from the submerged hall, also below the waterline, there is a dark shape in the wall that suggests the western passage once continued eastward through this area.

The submerged passage to the east leads to the sedacthies’ sleeping grottoes (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01sleepinggrot00]{A4}), while the archway on the balcony opens into their workshop (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5}).

If the characters make loud noises here (such as if the battle with the clockwork whale from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01waterlineund00]{A2} spills into this area), the sedacthies in the connecting rooms investigate. The sedacthies in the workshop (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5}) arrive in 4 rounds, while those in the sleeping chamber (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01sleepinggrot00]{A4}) arrive 4 rounds after that.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.bEFN4wisCHAr0vWM]{Silt}
Unlike the previous chamber, this pool is largely free of rubble. Instead, several feet of silt fill the bottom. A character who prods the silt with a weapon or another similar tool can attempt a @Check[perception|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check to Search. On a success, they uncover the marble bust of a scowling human man. Though the right half of the man’s face is hidden by a growth of coral, a PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:32|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[society|dc:34|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge identifies him as Gimmel, the third Runelord of Greed. (If the PCs identified Risen Gimmel in “Lord of the Trinity Star,” they recognize the bust without a check.) Even in its current state, the bust is worth 2,000 gp. The bust is Bulk 2 and grants a +2 circumstance bonus to haggle with the runelords of greed in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofgreed00]{B7} of the Crypt of Runes.

Sleeping Grottoes.name: Sleeping Grottoes
Sleeping Grottoes.text:
A4. Sleeping Grottoes Moderate 15

The vaulted ceiling of this entirely submerged chamber has suffered a collapse, which has filled the space with hills of broken stone. Set in grottoes among the rubble are the half-shells of giant clams draped in canopies of seaweed.

The chamber is 30 feet from floor to ceiling and filled entirely with water. The floor is an uneven layer of rubble several feet deep. Additionally, the sleeping grottoes have been arranged in mounds tall enough to provide standard cover or greater cover to any creature that climbs inside one.

A4. Sleeping Grottoes Moderate 15

@UUID[Actor.j6TG0t0LsdPZYlOa]{Kraken Callers (4)} @UUID[Actor.UpD5Dj692BBkxMR3]{Quoroc}

Creatures: When not working in the nearby workshop (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5}) or scouring the shores of Xin for treasure, the Kraken Callers rest here. The number of clamshell beds suggests that up to a dozen creatures could sleep here at once, but only four sedacthies are here when the PCs arrive.

Before the Kraken Callers arrived at the Tarnished Temple, they were accomplished fleshwarpers. Their pet, a fleshwarped giant octopus they call a quoroc, watches over the sedacthies resting in the chamber. While smaller than a typical giant octopus, the creature’s far-too-many arms exude a paralytic toxin like a jellyfish.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.SSPeMtecoFLNXKTD]{Sleeping Grotto}
The sedacthies’ leader, Maddenmist, hid three items in the northwestern sleeping grotto: a major potency crystal, a greater flaming runestone, and a ilver skullcap etched with snake patterns and a Sihedron rune. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[religion|dc:38|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes the cap as typical of those worn by high priests of Lissala. This runic skullcap grants a PC wearing it a +2 item bonus to any skill check made during the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02thetrialofru00]{Trial of Runes}.

Workshop.name: Workshop
Workshop.text:
A5. Workshop Moderate 15

Slabs of stone repurposed as crude worktables fill this space. Shattered stone tablets, fragments of broken statuary, and shards of glass cover every surface. An archway stands in the center of the room’s southern wall, while a wider passage extends to the east.

The ink-clouded waters in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01murkywatersu00]{A6} give the sedacthies a glimpse of Baolen’s visions of alternate pasts. After visiting that chamber, they return here to destroy any items that contradict the false histories they see.

The passage to the east leads to a stairwell that becomes fully submerged about halfway down its length. The stairs lead to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01murkywatersu00]{A6}.

A5. Workshop Moderate 15

@UUID[Actor.j6TG0t0LsdPZYlOa]{Kraken Callers (5)} @UUID[Actor.t1TXXZPHHRjXOoYt]{Maddenmist}

Creatures: Unless alerted to the party’s approach, Maddenmist and five Kraken Callers labor here. Maddenmist works at the table in the chamber’s northwest corner, disfiguring an ancient marble statue with a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.McnPlLFvKtQVXNcG]{Shape Stone} spell. The other sedacthies stand at various tables throughout the room. The sedacthies attack intruders on sight but are particularly concerned about protecting Baolen. If any PC makes a dash down the passage to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01murkywatersu00]{A6}, the sedacthies break off combat to purse them.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.XEUrOUOWdSwYLfId]{Workshop}
Many of the treasures in the workshop have been damaged beyond recognition. Three items of note, however, survive. One is what appears to be a tiny seed made of solid gold: an effortless garden. The other is a collection of stone tablets commissioned by Runelord Alaznist that outline her “rules of war.” The tablets are worth 3,500 gp. A PC who understands Thassilonian can read these tablets—anyone who’s done so gains a +2 circumstance bonus to checks made to answer the wrath sentry during the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02thetrialofru00]{Trial of Runes}. The final item is a recent discovery that would have been the next to be destroyed had the PCs not intervened: a +2 greater striking greater astral returning starknife emblazoned with etchings of constellations that was once wielded by a member of the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22004cultso.JournalEntryPage.04orderofthest00]{Order of the Starless Night}.

Maddenmist’s greater staff of arcane might dates back to the time of ancient Thassilon and bears a silver Sihedron headpiece. The staff, which Maddenmist discovered in the underwater ruins of Bakrakhan, once belonged to Thybidos, the penultimate Runelord of Wrath. If the PCs encounter the spirit of Alaznist in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofwrath00]{B12} of the Crypt of Runes, she recognizes her predecessor’s staff, granting the PC who carries it a +2 circumstance bonus to checks made to influence her during that encounter.

Murky Waters.name: Murky Waters
Murky Waters.text:
A6. Murky Waters Moderate 15

The stairwell opens abruptly into a natural cavern. The ceiling rises roughly ten feet above the stairs, but murky water fills the rest of the cavern, making its full dimensions difficult to discern.

When Earthfall struck and forced the city of Xin beneath the waves, the impact split the Tarnished Temple into several pieces, creating this natural cavern in the space between. The chamber is roughly cylinder-shaped. The stairs open near the top of the cylinder, almost 100 feet above the cavern’s floor. A 10-foot-wide opening at the bottom the cavern leads to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01baolenshallu00]{A7}. Spotting this opening requires a successful @Check[perception|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,action:seek|name:Seek] check to Seek, unless a creature happens to move adjacent to the opening, in which case they see it automatically. Once the hazard in this area is disabled, however, the tunnel to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01baolenshallu00]{A7} becomes obvious.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.yIBfsbwcII49bsAg]{Reveal Cavern Opening}

A6. Murky Waters Moderate 15

@UUID[Actor.hqru3dkTj8OpN3cs]{Elemental Tsunamis (2)} @UUID[Actor.lUXpzw2VCNSKkdkg]{Flawed Memories}

Creature: A pair of elemental tsunamis were trapped in this cavern during Earthfall. The tsunamis avoid conflict with the sedacthies but won’t recognize the PCs and attack them as soon as they enter the cavern. The tsunamis pursue the PCs up the stairwell until it reaches air, but neither ventures into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01baolenshallu00]{A7}, as they fear Baolen. In addition to incorporating some of the effects of this room’s hazard into their Strikes, these tsunamis have wavesense, allowing them to locate the PCs as they swim through the murky ink. They are entirely immune to the effects of the Flawed Memory hazard.

Hazard: Baolen regularly ejects his retrocognitive ink into this cavern, fouling the water. Any creature in the area (other than the elemental tsunamis) is affected by the Flawed Memories hazard. When the sedacthies visit the cavern, they willingly “breathe” in the ink to receive visions from their god. Due to their repeated exposure to the ink, the sedacthies have immunity to any mental damage they would take from the hazard. In addition to its mind-altering effects, the water is murky, limiting visibility within the cavern. Until the hazard is disabled, non-adjacent creatures are concealed from one another.

Reward: Disabling the flawed memories is a mythic deed that earns the PCs 3 Mythic Points.

Baolen’s Hall.name: Baolen’s Hall
Baolen’s Hall.text:
A7. Baolen’s Hall Severe 15

This octagonal chamber is nearly two hundred feet across and entirely submerged in water. On seven of the room’s eight sides, archways open into smaller, adjoining chambers, all of which seem to have at least partially collapsed. A harsh yellow light from the ceiling illuminates an enormous plinth in the center of the room. Judging from the pair of feet that remain atop the plinth, a statue of titanic proportions once stood there. Columns the size of trees surround the plinth to support the chamber’s ceiling one hundred feet above. The chamber’s eighth side opens into a hallway leading north.

This chamber is just one of many within the Tarnished Temple where objects related to the construction of ancient Thassilon’s great works were displayed. It’s also currently home to Baolen, the Breaker of History, whom the Kraken Callers trapped here several years ago. The chamber, including the adjoining chambers, is entirely submerged.

Numerous @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.mRz8Jmk4Q06SsZpC]{Everlight Crystals} illuminate what’s left of the giant statue in the center of the room. The crystals fill the area inside the columns with bright light and the rest of the chamber with dim light.

The plinth in the center of the hall is all that the remains of the enormous statue of Xin that once stood in this chamber. The plinth is 10 feet high.

Each of the nine side chambers was an area where culturally significant objects of ancient Thassilon were once displayed. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Walls of Force} once separated viewers from the items, but these barriers either failed during Earthfall or were destroyed by Baolen. The ceilings of the chambers have collapsed, partially filling each area with rubble. The chambers themselves are detailed under @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01theninealcov00]{The Nine Alcoves}.

Upon entering the room, allow the PCs to attempt either a @Check[architecture-lore|dc:30] or a @Check[crafting|dc:34] check to note that the four columns surrounding the plinth are load bearing, such that destroying three or more of the columns would cause the entire chamber to collapse. Each column is 100 feet high, 15 feet in diameter, and made of magically reinforced stone (AC 30, Hardness 15, 60 HP, BT 30). A single casting of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.r7ihOgKv19eJQnik]{Disintegrate} destroys enough of a column to cause it to collapse. Alternatively, a character with mythic proficiency in Athletics can use a single Interact action to topple a column by succeeding at a @Check[athletics|dc:40] check. Finally, each time Baolen makes an arm or tentacle Strike against a creature within 10 feet of a column, roll a @Check[flat|dc:5]. On a failure, the kraken’s attack also strikes the column, causing the column to collapse.

After the first column collapses, it should be clear to the PCs that destroying the columns would have disastrous results to anyone caught within the hall. Once three or more columns are destroyed, the chamber’s ceiling begins to collapse. For the next 4 rounds, any creature that begins their turn in the area takes @Damage[8d10[bludgeoning]] (@Check[reflex|dc:36|basic]). On a critical failure, the creature is also knocked prone and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} by the debris (Escape DC 35). Due to his enormous size, Baolen has a +2 circumstance bonus to his Reflex saving throw against the collapsing ceiling, as well as to checks made to Escape the debris.

Any creature still in the chamber at the end of 4 rounds (including Baolen) is crushed beneath hundreds of tons of stone, takes @Damage[20d6[bludgeoning]], is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} (Escape DC 40), and begins to suffocate. To escape this fate, the PCs can retreat to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01murkywatersu00]{A6}, take refuge in a side chamber (trapping themselves but surviving the collapse), or teleport away.

A PC who thinks to escape via the northern hallway is disappointed, as the Kraken Callers collapsed the passage when they “trapped” Baolen within the hall. Roughly 50 feet down its length, the PCs are met by a solid wall of rubble. (A row of everlight crystals in the hall’s ceiling illuminate the space, but depending on how the PCs approach the passage, they might not realize the hall has collapsed until they look directly down its length.) Clearing the rubble requires weeks of coordinated effort—opening the hallway more expediently would demand a feat worthy of the runelords themselves!

A7. Baolen’s Hall Severe 15

@UUID[Actor.CkdKjhdsTDOwu1uN]{Baolen}

Creature: Baolen attacks the PCs as soon as they enter the hall, using his first turn to engage the party and fill the chamber with his Ink Cloud. Baolen’s confusing visions of the past blind him to the possibility of his own death, making him oblivious to the collapsing chamber. If they recover the emerald prototype from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01theninealcov00]{A7d}, clever PC might collapse the chamber intentionally to defeat the kraken.

As a level 18 mythic creature, Baolen is a Severe encounter for level 15 characters, made even more difficult by the encounter’s unusual environment. While defeating Baolen is a feat worthy of mythic heroes, consider reminding the players that the PCs are here to retrieve information about the Emerald Chambers, not to kill Baolen. In many ways, the encounter with Baolen is as much a puzzle as a tactical combat. How can the PCs navigate the flooded hall, investigate the side chambers, and retrieve the emerald eye from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01theninealcov00]{A7d}, all while avoiding a rampaging kraken? As 15th-level mythic characters, the PCs should have an impressive array of abilities and magic items to help them tackle this challenge. Encourage the players to make use of these resources and be open to other creative solutions. So long as the PCs leave the isle of Xin with the emerald eye, they successfully “complete” this part of the adventure, regardless of whether they defeat Baolen in combat, crush him in the collapsing hall, or avoid engaging with the kraken entirely.

Reward: If the PCs manage to escape the Tarnished Temple with the Emerald Chambers prototype but didn’t kill Baolen, grant them mythic points and XP as if they’d defeated him in combat anyway.

Ending the Chapter.name: Ending the Chapter
Ending the Chapter.text:
Ending the Chapter

With a way to navigate the Emerald Chambers in hand, the PCs can leave the Tarnished Temple, regardless of whether Baolen has been defeated. From here, the party must journey to the Velashu Uplands, where the entrance to the Emerald Chambers lies. Even if the PCs earned XP at every opportunity thus far, they should still not have enough to reach 16th level. They’ll have the opportunity to do so early in the next chapter, however, before entering the Crypt of Runes.

Arranging a Ceasefire.name: Arranging a Ceasefire
Arranging a Ceasefire.text:
Arranging a Ceasefire

Oh! It’s You!

If your players played through the Shades of Blood Adventure Path before moving on to Revenge of the Runelords, Lograsi will be a name they may recognize: he’s the long-lost lover of Nicza, the main villain of Shades of Blood, whom the PCs are likely to have defeated! Lograsi knows that Nicza, whom he thought was long gone, returned for a brief time only to be silenced as a result of a psychic link they share, but whether or not he knows the PCs had something to do with his death is left to you to decide.

Consider this option, though—when the PCs meet Lograsi here, he might begin to suspect something but only at the back of his mind. After this encounter is completed, Lograsi researches this nagging suspicion and learns the truth, so that when the PCs meet him again in the next adventure, he’s got a personal reason to fight them: revenge! If the PCs choose reveal to him here that they were the ones who destroyed his lover, Lograsi doesn’t believe them but is shocked they know Nicza’s name. In this case, he steps away from the influence encounter with a bitter sneer and returns with his army to Xin-Edasseril to research this shocking revelation. Reduce all influence points gained with Lograsi to 0, but since he leaves the area, the PCs only need to convince one of the remaining armies to agree to a ceasefire to gain access to the Emerald Chambers.

Though the situation outside the valley is tense, the soldiers of each army regard the PCs with a mix of wary curiosity and surprise, provided they approach peacefully. From these soldiers, the PCs learn that while no one knows what the Rune Sentries are, none of the generals want the magic that animates them to fall into enemy hands. The situation remains at a stand-off for now, with each army worrying that one of the others has caused the floating stone heads to manifest as a secret weapon. Still, if any army makes a move toward the sentries, the others swiftly follow. The same goes for the PCs: if they press on into the valley, each of the assembled armies assumes the characters are agents of their enemies. The PCs know that to enter the Emerald Chambers, they must reach the sentries and pass some sort of complex trial, so a ceasefire among the armies must be arranged unless they want to tackle this trial while also caught in a mass combat between three powerful forces.

The following is an Influence encounter (GM Core 187) in which the PCs broker temporary peace among the three competing generals: Lograsi (a velstrac worshipper from ancient Azlant, who leads Belimarius’s forces), Roaring Storm (a Shoanti exile and head of the Noland raiders), and Knud Helmarsson (a proud Ulfen man who seeks to organize the Horselords against Belimarius’s aggression). The soldiers of the armies offer to send word to their leaders so that the party can speak with them, and within the hour, the three generals (accompanied by honor guards) approach the PCs.

Negotiations with the three take place over the course of 3 hours, with each Influence round lasting an hour. Before the encounter begins, each individual general introduces themself to the PCs while casting wary and threatening glances at the other two. At this time, each PC may attempt to Discover information about the general of their choice without using up a turn during the actual Influence encounter.

At the start of each round, each PC must decide which of the three generals they want to Discover or Influence during that round. The meeting is presented as a single Influence stat block, but the skills used depend on which general a PC interacts with.

If the PCs haven’t brokered a truce by the end of their 3 hours, one of the generals (likely Roaring Storm) grows impatient and orders their forces to make a break for the valley. See the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02event1thetri00#things-go-sideways]{Things Go Sideways} sidebar for advice in this case. Note that while the PCs need only achieve Influence 6 to secure the ceasefire, earning an even higher influence beyond this baseline can give the PCs greater advantages later in the adventure!

Influence 6 The generals agree to a truce, but each demands a tribute in return. This tribute can take the form of a magic item of level 15 or higher or an offering of coins and gems worth a combined total of least 7,000 gp. Each general demands their own tribute.

Influence 9 The generals agree to stand down without requiring a tribute.

Influence 12 The generals not only agree to stand down without a tribute, but two of them are personally impressed with the PCs. The PCs may choose which two of the three are impressed. During @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event3saving00]{Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands}, these two generals reduce the Overcome DCs to an obstacle they’re deployed to by 2 instead of by 1.

Weaknesses All three generals are frustrated with and wary about Runelord Belimarius’s long-term plans. Mentioning her presence and plans in any attempt to Influence the generals reduces the DC of that Influence check by 2.

Lograsi Background Born in ancient Azlant, Lograsi was a cultist who fled to Xin-Edasseril once his crimes were discovered. When the city reemerged from time, Lograsi seized the opportunity to gain political power by serving Runelord Belimarius as a general in her army.

Lograsi Appearance Lograsi is a thin Azlanti man dressed in gray leather, with a neat goatee and captivating violet eyes.

Lograsi Personality Cruel, short-tempered, strategic

Roaring Storm Background Roaring Storm’s name comes from the ear-splitting squalls she made as a baby. Exiled from her quah for questioning elders and similar misbehavior, she now leads a band of soldiers made up of criminals, raiders, and other misfits.

Roaring Storm Appearance Roaring Storm is a Shoanti woman whose diminutive frame belies her spirit.

Roaring Storm Personality Boastful, loud, reckless

Knud Helmarsson Background Knud has assembled his fellow Horselords to defend their home against Belimarius’s forces. Once eager to meet Lograsi in battle, the arrival of the Noland raiders has forced Knud to reconsider his tactics after his army took more damage than he anticipated in some preliminary skirmishes.

Knud Helmarsson Appearance An Ulfen man in his middle years, Knud is very tall but has a gentle demeanor.

Knud Helmarsson Personality Proud, quiet, stubborn

Reward: Award the PCs 5 XP for each Influence Point they earn, to a maximum of 60 XP.

The Rune Sentries.text:
The Rune Sentries

The questions asked by each sentry follow. Any alternative skills, as well as bonuses the PCs might receive, are also noted. If you think a player’s answer to a sentry’s question is particularly creative, reward them by reducing the DC of the check by 2.

Kaliphesta, Runelord of Gluttony

“What separates the living, the mindless dead, the dead that think, and that which moves without spirit?”

Favored Skills @Check[religion|dc:36] or @Check[undead-lore|dc:36]

Special Bonus The PC gains a +2 item bonus to their check if they possess the Kardosian Fragments.

Naaft, Runelord of Envy

“How does a ruler ensure the loyalty of those who serve?”

Favored Skills @Check[intimidation|dc:36] or @Check[labor-lore|dc:36]

Special Bonus The PC gains a +2 circumstance bonus to their check if they successfully answered a different Rune Sentry’s question.

Kaladurnae, Runelord of Greed

“What fills your coffers more quickly, and why: truth or lies?”

Favored Skills @Check[crafting|dc:36] or @Check[mercantile-lore|dc:36]

Special Bonus The PC gains a +2 item bonus to their check if they wear fine clothing or carry on them at least 2,000 gp in non-magical treasure.

Xirie, Runelord of Sloth

“Which is the shortest path to greatness?”

Favored Skills @Check[occultism|dc:36] or @Check[library-lore|dc:36]

Special Bonus The PC gains a +2 item bonus if they possess the effortless garden from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5} of the Tarnished Temple.

Alderpash, Runelord of Wrath

“You have two enemies. One camps at your borders but could be crushed easily. The other poses no immediate threat but is more formidable. How do you proceed?”

Favored Skills @Check[society|dc:36] or @Check[warfare-lore|dc:36]

Special Bonus A PC who read Alaznist’s tablets in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5} of the Tarnished Temple gains a +2 circumstance bonus to answer the sentry.

Sorshen, Runelord of Lust

“Which of my works will be best remembered?”

Favored Skills @Check[deception|dc:36] or @Check[art-lore|dc:36]

Special Bonus A PC who received Sorshen’s message in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01baolenshallu00]{A7f} of the Tarnished Temple saw a vision of Sorshen’s plans for the future of Eurythnia. If the PC responds “Eurythnia” or something to that effect, their answer pleases the sentry and grants them an automatic success. Otherwise, the PC gains a +2 circumstance bonus to their check.

The Rune Sentries Varies

@UUID[Actor.RghVBhAWAH1uQzpw]{Rune Sentries} @UUID[Actor.yRq7IjAC4TMaiiq0]{Peacock Phoenix}

Creature: As their responses to the sentries are secret checks, the PCs have no way to tell how well they’re doing until the test is completed. Thankfully, the PCs don’t have to answer all the questions correctly for the story to continue. Once they’ve answered six questions and it’s Xanderghul’s turn to pose the final one, his sentry simply sneers and says, “Nothing you say will suffice, intruders. The only answer I’ll accept is your death!” With that, the ground shakes as Xanderghul’s head, empowered by the presence of the Trinity Star cult within the Emerald Chambers, cracks open like an egg. Moments later, a peacock phoenix wreathed in brilliant, multicolored light emerges from the egg and attacks.

Hazard: As the peacock phoenix emerges from Xanderghul’s head, his denial causes the PCs to automatically “fail” the Trial of Runes and triggers the Rune Sentry hazard. However, the head of each sentry the PCs satisfied during the trial crashes to the ground, as per the hazard’s Entry Denied reaction, making the hazard less dangerous. Meanwhile, lightning arcs from the eyes of any sentry whose question the PCs failed to answer properly. Note that if the PCs successfully answered most (or all) of the trial’s questions, the hazard is much easier to defeat, thereby reducing the difficulty of an otherwise Extreme encounter.

Reward: In addition to the XP they receive from defeating the peacock phoenix and overcoming the hazard, award the PCs 5 XP for each question they answered properly during the Trial of Runes, to a maximum of 30 XP. Surviving the Trial of Runes is a Mythic Deed, which earns the PCs 3 Mythic Points each.

The Emerald Chambers.name: The Emerald Chambers
The Emerald Chambers.text:
The Emerald Chambers

Once the peacock phoenix is defeated, the platform below the sentries begins to glow with emerald light. The glow intensifies for several moments then disappears, teleporting any creatures standing on the platform into the Emerald Chambers. The PCs appear within a vast domed room, the floor and walls glowing green and appearing to be crafted of raw emerald. This material is sustained by the magic of the site—attempts to chip away bits of emerald cause the fragments to become dull, worthless shards of basalt.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.1U25PPKyfdwpbT07]{The Emerald Chambers}

The interior of the Emerald Chambers is a labyrinth of twisting corridors carved from this same solid, raw emerald. Every hundred feet or so, these corridors split, creating cascades of branching paths that defy geometry. Few thieves ever found their way into the Chambers during the Runelords’ reign, but those who did died of old age before reaching their intended destinations. There are a thousand locations within the Emerald Chambers, each with their own dangers and surprises. This adventure, however, is concerned with only two of these thousand chambers—the empty and largely harmless entry hall the PCs appear in and the sprawling complex known as the Crypt of Runes.

Thankfully, the PCs have a way to navigate the Emerald Chambers in the form of the emerald eye they recovered from the Tarnished Temple. To reach the Crypt of Runes, a PC must hold the emerald eye up, peer through it, and concentrate on seeking the path to the Crypt of Runes. The PC then attempts a @Check[survival|dc:32|traits:secret,exploration,skill,action:sense-direction|name:Sense Direction] check to Sense Direction or a @Check[perception|dc:36] check to simply observe the visual clues revealed by the emerald eye. If they succeed, they find their way to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02heartofsin0000]{B1} of the Crypt of Runes after traveling for an hour through a maze of identical-looking passages. On a failure, they find themselves back in the entry chamber and must try again. Once the PCs successfully navigate the route, they can come and go with or without the emerald eye between area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02heartofsin0000]{B1} and the entrance to the Emerald Chambers by spending only 10 minutes of travel.
