From the entry chamber, a PC can always opt to step into a softly glowing lighter green circle on the floor; doing so teleports the PC back to the surface among the Rune Sentries.

The Emerald Chambers (including the Crypt of Runes) are located deep underground in the Darklands layer of Nar-Voth, yet there are no physical connections to the Darklands within them. The Chambers magically renew and refresh breathable air and vary in depth underground from 800 feet to 1,000 feet.

Event 2: Into the Chambers.name: Event 2: Into the Chambers
Event 2: Into the Chambers.text:
Event 2: Into the Chambers Severe 15

Creatures: When the PCs first enter the Emerald Chambers, and then again each time they return to the entrance (either as the result of a failed attempt to navigate or deliberately after returning here from the Crypt of Runes), they’re confronted by the legendary guardians of the Emerald Chambers—four silent devotees. These green-skinned, glaive-wielding figures materialize before the PCs and stand impassively, crossing their glaives to bar passage onward.

As the central chamber is nearly 200 feet in diameter and contains no notable features, no map for this encounter is provided—simply use a blank grid for this encounter. The silent devotees appear about 30 feet away from the PCs, blocking their progress forward regardless of the direction the PCs choose. If the PCs have already successfully navigated a route to the Crypt of Runes via the use of the emerald eye, the silent devotees recognize them as deserving their place here and step aside to allow them passage. Otherwise, they attack as soon as any PC attempts to step toward them.

Event 2: Into the Chambers Severe 15

@UUID[Actor.wi1tlIg28BXHVULV]{Silent Devotees (4)}

A PC who thinks to present the emerald eye to the silent devotees before combat begins has a chance to convince the guardians that the PCs belong here, even if they haven’t already navigated a route. Successfully presenting the emerald eye as a badge of passage requires either a @Check[intimidation|dc:35] check or a @Check[diplomacy|dc:38] check. On a success, the devotees stand down and allow the PCs to pass, but on a failure, they attack. Once combat begins, the silent devotees fight to the death.

Reward: The first time the PCs convince the silent devotees to let them pass by presenting the emerald eye, grant them XP as if they’d defeated them in combat.

The Crypt of Runes.name: The Crypt of Runes
The Crypt of Runes.text:
The Crypt of Runes

Sinful Favor

As the PCs explore the crypts, they’ll have chances to earn a sin’s favor. When the PCs eventually break the rune wards blocking entrance into the Crypt of Pride, the legacies of the runelords whose sins they’ve earned the favor of empower them, granting them access to a bonus Vengeance Feat. See @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02breakingthew00]{Breaking the Ward} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22006advent.JournalEntryPage.06vengeancefea00]{Vengeance Feats} for more details about these bonus feats and how they’re gained.

When Xanderghul arrived at the Crypt of Runes, his first task was to disable the runes that warded the entrances to each of the Crypt’s seven wings. Rather than simply breaking these wards, however, Xanderghul transferred the runes of envy, gluttony, greed, lust, sloth, and wrath to the entrance to his cult’s new headquarters, the Crypt of Pride. As only a runelord—or someone designated as their champion—can bypass the wards, the only way the PCs can enter the Crypt of Pride now is to visit the other wings and convince the unquiet spirits of the runelords there to choose them as their proxies for revenge. The characters can explore the other wings in whatever order they choose, and while they don’t have to visit all six wings to bypass the runes on the Crypt of Pride, the more thoroughly they explore the Crypt of Runes, the better prepared they’ll be to face the Risen who dwell within.

Once the PCs complete their journey through the Emerald Chambers, they arrive at a glowing green archway and know the Crypt of Runes lies beyond. By stepping through the archway, the PCs are teleported into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02heartofsin0000]{B1}, arriving adjacent to the area’s southern uncurved wall. To return to this arch in the Emerald Chambers, they need only step back onto the Sihedron and take an Interact action with the concentrate trait to be teleported back.

Grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment of reaching the Crypt of Runes.

Crypt of Runes Features.name: Crypt of Runes Features
Crypt of Runes Features.text:
Crypt of Runes Features

Unlike the passageways that connect the various locations within the Emerald Chambers, the Crypt of Runes is made of fitted stone, not emerald. Except where noted, any doors the PCs encounter are unlocked and are made of reinforced wood. Ceiling heights average at 10 feet, and all chambers are brightly lit by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.mRz8Jmk4Q06SsZpC]{Everlight Crystals} embedded in the ceiling.

Heart of Sin.name: Heart of Sin
Heart of Sin.text:
B1. Heart of Sin Moderate 16

This circular chamber is nearly eighty feet across, with a vaulted ceiling that rises nearly twice that height. Set into the floor in the middle of the space is a seven-pointed star, the tips of which point to doors spaced evenly around the room’s perimeter. Six of the doors stand ajar. The seventh door, directly to the north, glows with a host of runes. A statue of a human man with flowing hair holding a staff stands atop a plinth in the center of the star. The man faces a mural painted on the chamber’s southern wall.

The statue in the center of the room is a depiction of First King Xin. His image is repeated within the mural on the southern wall, only here the man is shown laid out in death. The original seven runelords (Naaft, Kaliphesta, Kaladurnae, Sorshen, Xanderghul, Xirie, and Alderpash) surround the bier on which Xin’s body rests. An insightful viewer might recognize that, while their overall demeanor is solemn, the looks on their faces betray a hint of satisfaction at the sight of their dead king.

The doors in area B1 marked a–f lead to the Crypts of Envy, Gluttony, Greed, Sloth, Lust, and Wrath respectively. Powerful wards associated with the corresponding type of rune magic once protected each of the doors, but Xanderghul has transferred all the runes to the entrance to the Crypt of Pride on the north wall of the chamber. With the combined energy of all seven rune wards protecting that entrance, only several runelords working together could enter the Crypt of Pride. Any attempts the PCs make to enter the Crypt of Pride or otherwise bypass the runes fail in an impressive (though harmless) display of arcane magic.

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:36] check understands the nature of the runes protecting the Crypt of Pride. As the runes aren’t meant to work together in this way, all seven runes don’t have to be defeated; if four of the seven runes are removed, the entire enchantment collapses. However, only a runelord or someone designated as their champion can remove their corresponding rune ward.

Creature: After Xanderghul and most of the cult left to begin opening the Doomsday Doors, the remaining Risen retreated to the Crypt of Pride. In his stead, Xanderghul appointed Risen Runelord Karzoug and a rune giant named Czaresia to lead those left behind. Risen Karzoug is in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}, but Czaresia is here, guarding the entrance to the Crypt of Pride against intruders.

A fanatical member of the cult of the Trinity Star, Czaresia eagerly awaits the day when a runelord once again rules the Saga Lands. Her skin is decorated with the rune of pride repeated dozens of times. She wears robes of deep violet, and though the mace she carries is styled like a scepter, the way she handles the weapon suggests she’s an impressive warrior.

B1. Heart of Sin Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.KAOGF59X59zbsy6x]{Czaresia}

Czaresia knows how difficult it is to navigate the Emerald Chambers, and the party’s sudden arrival puts her on the back foot. If the PCs attack immediately, they gain a +2 circumstance bonus to initiative (@UUID[Item.yhYFnzG8CXWSsYFg]{Sudden Arrival}). If the PCs fail to take this advantage, Czaresia assumes a defensive posture but attempts to parley. She’s most interested in learning how the PCs navigated the Emerald Chambers, in the eventuality she’s forced to find a way out of the Chambers herself.

She’s even willing to talk a bit about Xanderghul’s recent plans, under the pretense that she finds her low status in the Trinity Star demeaning. In particular, she’s likely to extol the power of the wards blocking access north to the Crypt of Pride and even explains how they might be defeated, speaking in a condescending way that makes it apparent she doesn’t believe the PCs have the skill to do so. She has no intention of letting the PCs live, and once she’s sized up the heroes, she attacks.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.yTNNQBqWa2gz5ERh]{Pouch}
In addition to her mace and robes, Czaresia carries a beloved’s bracelet in a pouch on her belt. The giant discovered the bracelet while looting the crypts of the other runelords and claimed the treasure for herself simply as an object of beauty—she doesn’t fully understand the scope and use of its magical powers (and wouldn’t be able to fit the bracelet on one of her wrists in the first place).

Covetous Corridor.name: Covetous Corridor
Covetous Corridor.text:
B2. Covetous Corridor Moderate 16

Statues of men and women dressed in finery and holding various magical implements stand against the walls of this wide corridor. Five statues line the northern wall, while the remaining four stand across from them. A tenth statue, depicting a matronly woman holding an ornate halberd, stands separate from the others at the eastern end of the hall. Plaques set into the plinths on which the statues stand name each of the ten figures. Beyond the tenth statue, the corridor turns north toward a flickering green glow.

The statues depict the ten runelords of envy, and the plaques at the foot of each list the runelords’ names and provide a bit of history about them. (You can use this information to introduce the PCs to the dead runelords, the spirits of whom they might encounter in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofenvy000]{B3}.) The five statues against the north wall depict (from west to east) Naaft, Tannaris, Ivamura, Jurah, and Chalsardra. The four statues to the south are Esedrea, Zarve, Desamelia, and Phirandi. The statue at the end of the hall depicts the last Runelord of Envy, Belimarius. Each statue is a bit larger than life and was sculpted from a single block of marble, although the wands, staves, and other magical implements they hold are separate pieces.

A shimmering curtain of green energy separates the corridor from the Crypt of Envy (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofenvy000]{B3}). Other than the fact the barrier is opaque (preventing visual effects from passing through it), it functions as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force}. When the PCs first arrive, the barrier is the equivalent of a 6th-rank wall of force, but the statues in the corridor can use magic stolen from the PCs to strengthen the barrier.

B2. Covetous Corridor Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.HYWd4OBjiRV39xwP]{Covetous Corridor}

Hazard: The statues of the first nine runelords are enchanted to steal magic from intruders in the hall. Once a critical threshold of magic is reached, the stolen energy is transferred to the statue of Belimarius, which in turn uses the energy to strengthen the magical barrier that blocks the entrance to the Crypt of Envy.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.lCo3fyUoa8FBLCXu]{Toggle Barrier}

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.HGfjd8OdeLkwaWwq]{Statue}
While the implements held by the runelord statues can be removed, they’re carved from marble and are worthless except as curiosities. The exception is the halberd wielded by the Belimarius statue. This weapon is made of gold and dawnsilver and has been crafted in the likeness of the Invidious Halberd, one of the Seven Weapons of Rule that marked the offices of the runelords. Though only a replica, the halberd functions as a +3 greater striking spell reservoir halberd and is worth 6,500 gp for its fine craftsmanship. The PCs can also use the halberd when dealing with the squabbling spirits in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofenvy000]{B3}.

Crypt of Gluttony.name: Crypt of Gluttony
Crypt of Gluttony.text:
B5. Crypt of Gluttony Moderate 16

Four great mausoleums, their marble doors shattered, occupy the northern half of this chamber. A fifth mausoleum, larger and more impressive than the others, stands against the eastern wall. A dining table set with fine dishware, crystal goblets, and silver candelabras stretches before this larger structure. A hallway leads westward from the chamber, while a stairwell in the southwest corner leads down.

This chamber houses the mausoleums of the five runelords of gluttony. The structures in the north half of the room belong to the first four runelords, while the larger one against the eastern wall is Runelord Zutha’s.

B5. Crypt of Gluttony Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.8U5BAWPRrKAQbn6V]{Ravenous Crypts (4)}

Creatures: The four mausoleums to the north animate as soon as one or more of the PCs enter, awakening as ravenous crypts. Stripped bare of their original contents, the crypts hunger for something new to fill their stomachs—namely, the PCs!

Command Center.name: Command Center
Command Center.text:
B18. Command Center

This L-shaped area is divided into three sections. The southern arm is filled with tables covered by maps and scribbled notes. Bookshelves stacked with tomes fill the northern arm. Where the two sections meet, there are cushioned benches surrounding a dais that supports a tall lectern. A gemstone inlay on the lectern’s face forms the shape of a blazing comet with three tails.

Two hallways converge in the room’s southwest corner, one from the west and another from the south. In the chamber’s northern arm, an archway opens into another area to the west.

The Risen of the Trinity Star use this chamber to plan their movements, research magic, and receive instructions from Xanderghul. The area contains a wealth of information about the cultists and their plans, which the PCs can uncover using the Research rules (Pathfinder GM Core 190). Examining the area and preparing for research requires 10 minutes of Searching, after which the PCs can spend as much time researching as they like, but after 30 minutes, one of the cult’s risen runelords (such as Kaliphesta from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02fleshworks0000]{B15}, Xirie from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02viewingchamb00]{B17}, or Tannaris or Ivamura from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02prisonentran00]{B20}) arrives to consult the tomes on the bookshelves or re-read a dispatch on the tables.

Planning Tables: Maps of the Saga Lands are spread out over the three tables in the room’s southern arm. Among the maps are dispatches from various factions of the Risen of the Trinity Star and their allies. The cultists use this area to solidify their plans to open the Doomsday Doors.

  • Maximum RP 4
  • Research Checks @Check[warfare-lore|dc:33|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to intuit the movements of the cultists, @Check[society|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to read through the correspondence and interpret the maps, or @Check[perception|dc:37|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to notice a previously overlooked clue.

Bookshelves: The three bookshelves in the room’s northern arm are filled with treatises on various arcane subjects and are organized with no rhyme or reason.

  • Maximum RP 4
  • Research Checks @Check[academia-lore|dc:33|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or @Check[type:library-lore|dc:33|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to identify the most useful tomes, @Check[arcana|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to make sense of the books’ obscure subjects, or @Check[perception|dc:37|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to flip through random books in search of notes scribbled in the margins.

Lectern: Xanderghul addresses the cultists from behind the lectern. The comet inlay on the lectern’s face is composed of an array of precious gemstones surrounding a single aeon stone. When activated from behind the lectern, the aeon stone projects illusory images of locations across the Saga Lands, where Xanderghul believes the Doomsday Doors are located. A shelf on the inside the lectern contains a pile of Xanderghul’s notes, as well as the key to the locked storeroom in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02barracksunde00]{B14}. (Any PC who Searches the podium find the notes and key automatically.)

  • Maximum RP 4
  • Research Checks @Check[thievery|dc:33|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to override the lectern’s magic and activate the aeon stone, @Check[arcana|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to activate the aeon stone, or @Check[society|dc:37|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to examine Xanderghul’s notes.

Command Center Research 16

  • unique
  • arcane

Research Checks planning tables (southern arm), bookshelves (northern arm), lectern (northeast corner)

2 Research Points Xanderghul and his cultists have adopted the Crypt of Pride as their new headquarters. By robbing the crypts of the other runelords, Xanderghul gathered the objects he needed to create many of the risen runelords who now serve him. Most the cult is currently elsewhere, but Xanderghul’s objective is clear: the runelord plans to destroy Golarion and use the energy released for him to become a god.

4 Research Points Xanderghul no longer possesses Aethusa. He has created a new body for himself and is mortal once again, though his soul can inhabit Aethusa or any of the risen runelords if he dies. To stop Aethusa from interfering with his plans, Xanderghul secured her in a specially created prison elsewhere in the chambers, which can be accessed via the chamber above the Temple of the Apocalypse (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02templeofthea00]{B19}); this allows the PCs to automatically notice the magical secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}. To further protect Aethusa’s prison, Xanderghul bound several shining children inside summoning runes around the area.

6 Research Points To destroy Golarion, Xanderghul plans to open Doomsday Doors throughout the Saga Lands. He has identified the locations of seven such doors. The first, the one under Xin-Eurythnia, has already been opened. The remaining six doors are beneath Korvosa, the Sleeper in Belkzen, the city of Jol in the Lands of the Linnorm Kings, under Windsong Abbey on Varisia’s Lost Coast, Old Xin-Edasseril, and Sech Nevali.

8 Research Points Xanderghul’s return to Golarion was orchestrated in part by someone called the Ashen Man. The Ashen Man’s motivations are a mystery even to Xanderghul, but the runelord knows he’s an entity from the Dimension of Time and has an association with Jandelay, a demiplane made up of the relics of destroyed worlds. The statue in the Temple of the Apocalypse is one of these relics.

10 Research Points The PCs learn that the Ashen Man has warned Xanderghul about the one who set into motion his enemies’ fight against him, the Thassilonian dream spirit known as Liralarue. A dispatch from one of the cult’s risen runelords confirms that a group called the “Bittersweet Sisters” have imprisoned Liralarue in a place called the Oubliette Plains in Leng. Though the Sisters aren’t described, it’s clear they’re powerful allies of the Ashen Man. The notes make it apparent that Xanderghul doesn’t consider Liralarue, “a long-dead echo of a failure barely worth remembering,” a threat to his plans. He’s more concerned with keeping Aethusa hidden and secure in a secret prison—PCs who reach this tier understand how the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} works.

12 Research Points The PCs discover detailed plans of how Xanderghul intends to deploy his forces while opening the Doomsday Doors. The party can use this information to stay one step ahead of the cultists, granting them a +2 item bonus to Warfare Lore checks against the Organize a Response obstacle in @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event3saving00]{Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands}.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.Za2boAwfvqSVW4yZ]{Lectern} @UUID[Actor.AjFowibfUW5DTtvH]{Bookshelves} @UUID[Actor.vJvE1NG3pAdKXwF9]{Slender Folio} @UUID[Actor.RnWt8ZyK39CQhvz9]{Large Spellbook} @UUID[Actor.KDE78YtBdtJlDeBd]{Hidden Slot}
Due to its magical properties, the lectern is worth 2,000 gp, although its size and weight make it difficult to transport (treat the lectern is a Bulk 10 object). The PCs can pry the aeon stone from the inlay; doing so destroys the lectern’s ability to project images (making it impossible to use it to Research via Society checks to examine the notes) but once removed, the stone functions as an amplifying aeon stone. The remaining 37 gemstones are an assortment of semiprecious stones worth 75 gp each.

The treatises on the bookshelves are rare tomes on a variety of subjects. Altogether the books are worth 5,000 gp, provided the PCs take the time to collect them. If the PCs earn at least 2 Research Points while investigating the bookshelves, they also discover a scroll case containing scrolls of the following spells: acid grip (7th-rank), chain lightning, eclipse burst, and teleport (7th-rank). If they earned at least 2 Research Points while investigating the lectern, they discover a slender folio tucked into a larger book that contains the formula for the planar displacement ritual.

Set atop a bookshelf is a large spellbook with a +2 greater striking dagger atop it. The spellbook’s title, Thrice-Born Souls, is etched in Thassilonian on its iron cover, and a quick glance through its contents confirms that this spellbook belongs to Aethusa. The dagger does as well—Xanderghul stashed them here absently and then more or less forgot about them.

One final pair of treasures can only be located by a PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:42|traits:concentrate,secret,action:seek|name:Seek] check made while Seeking Thrice-Born Souls—a success reveals a hidden slot within the book’s back cover in which Xanderghul has stashed a 9th-rank scroll of seize identity.

Reward: Each time the PCs reach a new tier of information, grant them 10 XP, for a total of 60 XP once they earn 12 RP. The first PC who achieves a critical success while researching here gains 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Temple of the Apocalypse.name: Temple of the Apocalypse
Temple of the Apocalypse.text:
B19. Temple of the Apocalypse Moderate 16

An archway to the east opens into an octagonal chamber roughly seventy feet across. In the center of the room stands an enormous statue, its cracked stone at odds with the pristine marble of the rest of the crypt. The statue depicts a feminine figure with feathered wings in place of arms. The statue’s face has all but crumbled away, but carvings in her flowing hair suggest she once wore a crown of flowers. A slab at the figure’s feet, made from the same stone as the statue itself, serves as some sort of altar.

High on the north wall, a balcony overlooks the area, nearly sixty feet above the chamber’s floor.

A character who succeeds at a @Check[religion|dc:35|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] about the statue recognizes that, while the figure is clearly some sort of goddess, she isn’t worshipped on Golarion (or elsewhere in the Universe, for that matter). Other than the statue’s presence in the Crypt of Pride, no evidence exists that the cultists revere the goddess or otherwise interact with the statue.

Creatures: The “statue” is a vogorond, a remnant imbued with the collective consciousness of a world destroyed by an apocalypse. Xanderghul received the vogorond as a gift from the Ashen Man, who transported it here from Jandelay.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.MFg9RfOK6GRczeaS]{Animate Statue}

B19. Temple of the Apocalypse Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.EVBptXo4eSePprU9]{Vogorond}

The vogorond has used its Monument ability to appear as an inanimate statue (DC 45 Stealth), but it animates if a PC approaches within 10 feet or if any character heads to the balcony leading to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02prisonentran00]{B20}. The vogorond fights until destroyed.

Combat with the vogorond alerts the risen runelords in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02prisonentran00]{B20}, who immediately begin preparing for battle. If the PCs rest in this area, the runelords might ambush them while the party is still weakened from the encounter with the vogorond. If the PCs explore the balcony before the vogorond is defeated, they might find themselves caught between the vogorond and the runelords. Fighting the two groups at once is an Extreme encounter, but note that the vogorond makes no effort to exclude the runelords from its ruinous aura.

Prison Entrance.name: Prison Entrance
Prison Entrance.text:
B20. Prison Entrance Moderate 16

This pentagonal chamber is roughly fifty feet wide but narrows to a point to the north. Otherwise, the room is featureless, save for an archway that opens onto a balcony to the south.

Before he left the Crypt of Pride, Xanderghul chose this room as a starting point to further expand the Emerald Chambers. A hairline rift in the room’s northeast wall (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02openingtheri00]{Opening the Rift}) tenuously connects it to the large chamber beyond (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}). While Xanderghul’s expansion project is ongoing, area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} has served as a convenient place to imprison Aethusa until a more stable site can be secured.

B20. Prison Entrance Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.MkJoEGgGA62m1E4v]{Risen Runelord Tannaris} @UUID[Actor.2W8RQWvD2jeoyqgj]{Risen Runelord Ivamura}

Creatures: Xanderghul ordered the second and third risen runelords of envy, Tannaris and Ivamura, to keep watch over this area in the event Aethusa’s prison fails. If the risen runelords hear sounds of battle with the vogorond in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02templeofthea00]{B19}, they prepare by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.A2JfEKe6BZcTG1S8]{Fly} on themselves, then manifest their runelord polearms (both similar looking halberds). If they have time, they each cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.XXqE1eY3w3z6xJCB]{Invisibility} on themselves (note that both have already cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.C2w3YfBKjIRS07DP]{Hidden Mind} earlier in the day). If the PCs defeat the vogorond but don’t head directly to this area, the runelords ambush them before the party has an opportunity to rest.

Opening the Rift.name: Opening the Rift
Opening the Rift.text:
Opening the Rift

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check to Search the chamber notices a hairline fissure in the chamber’s northeast wall. A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.gpzpAAAJ1Lza2JVl]{Detect Magic} or similar spell automatically reveals the magical energy leaking from the rift. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] or @Check[nature|dc:37|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic], @Check[occultism|dc:37|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic], or @Check[religion|dc:37|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] check to Identify Magic understands the nature of this strange rift; it’s a magical secret door of sorts that can be opened with the following action (PCs who reached 10 Research Points in the Command Center automatically understand this method, and that knowledge reduces all DCs for this action by 2).

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.wp5aOcRfQ14ttmws]{Toggle Rift}

Due to the nature of the Emerald Chambers and area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} technically being in a separate chamber from the Crypt of Runes, simply smashing through the wall won’t suffice—PCs who dig through the wall find only solid stone. The rift itself is along the wall but not part of it; it can be opened in the following way even if all of the physical matter it overlaps has been removed.

Open the Rift 1

You focus your knowledge of magic into the secret rift to trigger it into opening, or you use brute force to pry it open. Attempt a @Check[arcana|dc:37], a @Check[nature|dc:40], @Check[occultism|dc:40], or @Check[religion|dc:40] check, or a @Check[athletics|dc:45] check with the following results. Once you succeed at any of these checks, you automatically achieve a critical success on all future attempts to Open the Rift. Once opened, the rift remains open for 1 hour, at which point it snaps back in place. Creatures standing in the space occupied by the rift are shunted into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02prisonentran00]{B20}. The rift can be opened from the opposite side in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} using this action as well, but doing so from that side reduces the DCs by 10.

If you possess an Avenger Feat, treat your result as one degree of success better than your rolled result.

Critical Success You open the rift into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} safely.

Success You open the rift into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} but are blasted by magical feedback that erodes your sense of self-worth and confidence in the face of Xanderghul’s superiority. You take @Damage[10d6[mental]] damage.

Failure You fail to open the rift into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}. The blast of magical feedback inflicts @Damage[20d6[mental]] damage to you, and you become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} with an unlimited duration.

Critical Failure As failure, but @Damage[20d6+60[mental]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2}.

Reward: Opening the rift to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} is a mythic deed that grants each character 3 Mythic Points.

Aethusa’s Prison.name: Aethusa’s Prison
Aethusa’s Prison.text:
B21. Aethusa’s Prison Extreme 16

In contrast to the other areas of the Crypt of Runes, the walls, floors, and ceiling of this chamber are made of what appears to be pure emerald. A wide concourse, its ceiling thirty feet above the floor, surrounds a central space accessed by ten-foot-wide archways set into the chamber’s inner walls. Shifting, rainbow-dappled light emanates from within this inner sanctum.

Xanderghul imprisoned Aethusa here after returning to his own body. He knows she remembers much of her time under his control and that merely killing her would potentially allow her to be resurrected by his enemies. In addition, she continues to function as sort of safety net for him—if he perishes, he can instantly shift his soul back into her body and avoid death entirely (a better alternative than a risen runelord vessel, due to the limitations a magically created body would impose on him).

Creatures: When the PCs arrive, a risen runelord—Karzoug, the final runelord of greed—stands vigil in the center of the chamber, along with four shining children bound to the area by Xanderghul. The shining children each float just above the ground within the four archways leading into the central chamber and fight to the death, following Karzoug’s commands if he issues them. When combat begins, the four shining children activate their blinding aura—while this aura could theoretically affect Karzoug, he’s very unlikely to fail his saving throw against the effect. If he does become blinded by this aura, he spends a Mythic Point on his turn to remove the condition.

Karzoug himself considers this role to be humiliating and has managed to find certain subtle ways to act against Xanderghul’s control over him by slowly leeching power from Aethusa’s prison to bolster himself. He’s already managed to use this method to create the Chromatic Robe (@UUID[Actor.Qu4u5Lc1PwOnZglA]{Karzoug}) he wears and hopes in time to gain full autonomy. Such a goal is still months away at best, but in desperation he could destroy the prison to escape his own destruction, even though he knows doing so would likely invite even greater punishment from Xanderghul.

B21. Aethusa’s Prison Extreme 16

@UUID[Actor.CHn34ZGiLeRAROTT]{Risen Runelord Karzoug} @UUID[Actor.zJwTuEM0pIvY0lFZ]{Shining Children (4)} @UUID[Actor.lizp8nUFkRkY0ApM]{Aethusa's Prison}

Each time an attempt to Open the Rift in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02prisonentran00]{B20} achieves any result other than a critical success, the attempt registers in this room as a flash of green light from the southwest and a bell-like tolling. If the PCs achieve a critical success on their very first attempt to enter, they can potentially catch Karzoug unawares if they’re stealthy, but otherwise he manifests his polearm and casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.XS7Wyh5YC0NWeWyB]{Fiery Body} on himself in preparation for battle.

In combat, Karzoug tries to lure the PCs into triggering the summoning runes, leaving the central area only if the PCs seem determined to attack him from range. Once engaged in melee, he separates the PCs with walls of force or holds them in place with impaling spikes. He makes sure to always save at least 1 Mythic Point so that he can use Chromatic Resurrection, but if the PCs destroy Aethusa’s prison, he’ll use that last point freely to regain a spell or recover from a condition as appropriate.

Karzoug isn’t immune to the Chromatic Eruptions of Aethusa’s prison, but his Mythic Reflex ability combined with the resistances granted by his chromatic robe means he’s unlikely to take significant damage from the hazard. Unless the PCs destroy the prison first, once Karzoug is reduced to 0 Hit Points, if he still has at least 1 Mythic point, his Chromatic Aegis activates, destroying the prison but also making the runelord nigh invincible before shunting him elsewhere into the world.

Hazards: Aethusa’s prison is a 10-foot-diameter sphere made of roiling energy—a substance similar to the chromatic ooze in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02chromaticcau00]{B16}. The sphere is mostly opaque, but now and then a glimpse of a human woman floating in a fetal position within can be spotted within. The prison floats above a flat-topped pedestal in the center of the area. The pedestal is etched with containment runes that strengthen the prison and hold the structure in place. Though the PCs don’t have to free Aethusa before defeating Karzoug, while it remains intact, the prison gives the risen runelord an opportunity to escape death via his Chromatic Aegis ability.

Note that the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.1IeT2jIpBxxUo1uD]{Slates of Distant Letters} Risen Runelord Karzoug carries is the one he used to communicate with Risen Runelord Gimmel in the previous adventure. If the PCs sent a reply using this one, feel free to have them find that reply still scribbled on this slate to tie up that mystery!

Reward: For releasing Aethusa from her prison, award each PC 80 XP. If the PCs manage to disable Aethusa’s prison before they slay Karzoug, grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Ending the Chapter.name: Ending the Chapter
Ending the Chapter.text:
Ending the Chapter

Once Aethusa’s prison is destroyed (either by the PCs or via Karzoug’s Chromatic Aegis ability), her body floats gently down onto the pedestal, unconscious but apparently unharmed by her her experience. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[medicine|dc:33] check confirms Aethusa should awaken on her own in a few minutes.

Once she recovers, Aethusa is disoriented, frightened, and defensive. Dressed in simple robes, with all of her gear missing and with no prepared spells, she’s currently suffering from her supernatural imprisonment and is clumsy 4, drained 4, enfeebled 4, and stupefied 4. Her drained condition value recovers normally with rest, but her other condition values will take months, if not years to lessen without magical aid. All of these conditions function at rank 10 for the purposes of counteracting them (@UUID[Item.CkiVg1n1CQ2JmV8Q]{Supernatural Imprisonment Ailment}).

Aethusa recalls her time spent possessed by Xanderghul as if remembering a nightmare—certain memories are stark and obvious, while others are faded and confusing at best. Her @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22006advent.JournalEntryPage.06campaignrole00]{NPC entry} gives her stats and how the PCs can earn her trust, after which she shares everything she knows about Xanderghul and the Risen of the Trinity Star. This information can automatically impart anything the PCs didn’t discover yet while researching the Command Center (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02commandcente00]{B18}), up to the 10 Research Point tier (they can only gain the bonus to checks during @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event3saving00]{Event 3} by earning 12 Research Points normally).

Aethusa also confirms that Xanderghul has built a new body for himself and is no longer possessing her. Though relieved to be free of Xanderghul’s possessing spirit, she feels as if the runelord still has some hold over her. She suspects that Xanderghul is using her, the risen runelords, and possibly others as “living soul cages.” If Xanderghul’s mortal body dies, his soul will simply shift into one of these soul cages.

While Aethusa has no love for the PCs, she wants revenge and now sees the characters as potential allies against Xanderghul. Her most immediate concern, though, is Xanderghul’s plan to open the Doomsday Doors. As much as she wants to be free of Xanderghul’s control, even Aethusa agrees that her desires must be put on hold to prevent an imminent apocalypse.

The easiest way to leave the Emerald Chambers is via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.69L70wKfGDY66Mk9]{Teleport} or similar magic, but if they have to make their way back on foot, you should allow them to reach the entrance chamber with ease. Regardless of whether the PCs enlist Aethusa’s help in closing the Doomsday Doors or part ways with her, she urges the characters to work swiftly. For better or worse, the fate of the Saga Lands—and likely all of Golarion—now rests in their hands!

Ten Thousand Emerald Chambers.name: Ten Thousand Emerald Chambers
Ten Thousand Emerald Chambers.text:
Chapter 2: Ten Thousand Emerald Chambers

Having secured a “blueprint” of the Emerald Chambers, the PCs must now travel to the Velashu Uplands, where the entrance to the Chambers is located. The site lies in an unnamed valley in the Uplands, but when the PCs arrive, they find the soldiers of three armies camped in the region. The forces include a battalion of Belimarius’s foot soldiers, a band of Noland raiders, and an army of Velashu Horselords. For the moment, hostilities among the armies have paused. In the distance, the PCs can see the reason why: roughly half a mile away, a circle of massive stone heads rotates in the sky above the valley.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.JLMHRORdk6j7NC4A]{Velashu Uplands}

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:34|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge is sure there’s no record of the heads ever being here, so they must have arrived recently. In truth, these enormous busts of the first seven Runelords once guarded the valley’s entrance, but the monuments were destroyed and buried in a landslide during Earthfall. Unbeknownst to the PCs or the opposing armies, Xanderghul raised the statues from beneath the ground when he returned to the valley. These floating heads were known as the Rune Sentries in the time of ancient Thassilon and guard the entrance to the Emerald Chambers.

The Trial of Runes.name: The Trial of Runes
The Trial of Runes.text:
The Trial of Runes

Once the PCs arrange a ceasefire, they can enter the valley and approach the Rune Sentries without triggering an all-out war. When the party arrives, they find seven stone heads—one for each of the original runelords—circling ominously roughly 50 feet above a circular stone platform. The PCs can begin the Trial of Runes by climbing the steps that lead to top of the platform. Once there, the eyes of the sentries flash as the heads turn their attention to the party.

Event 1: The Trial of Runes.name: Event 1: The Trial of Runes
Event 1: The Trial of Runes.text:
Event 1: The Trial of Runes Extreme 15

The mandate of the Rune Sentries was simple: to prevent anyone but the truly worthy from entering the Emerald Chambers. To access the Chambers, the PCs must answer a series of questions designed to determine whether they are runelords or mere pretenders. The sentries begin by demanding proof that the PCs are even worthy of such a test. As the PCs approach, the Rune Sentries speak in a single voice that echoes through the valley.

“You seek entrance to the Emerald Chambers, the final resting place of First King Xin. To begin the trial, show us—the lords of Thassilon—proof of your right to rule through your command of rune magic!”

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.vGTSvKxAQh2SE08E]{Things go Sideways - Battle}

Things Go Sideways

The PCs are likely impatient to enter the Emerald Chambers and might try to avoid the armies entirely by sneaking into the valley. In this case, you can run this section as an Infiltration (GM Core 196). Obstacles might include creating a distraction, avoiding a patrol sent to scout the sentries, or finding an alternate route into the valley through the nearby hills. Similarly, if the PCs bungle the Influence encounter, they might have to navigate the battlefield without being drawn into the conflict or race to the sentries before one of the generals reaches them. While the PCs don’t have to engage with the three armies to enter the Emerald Chambers, keep in mind that doing so gives them an opportunity to make alliances that might help them later in the adventure. If a battle among the armies is unavoidable, you can either have the PCs fight a few troops (choosing from Pathfinder Battlecry!) or narrate the conflict’s outcome as you choose—just make sure Lograsi survives, as he returns in Book 3 of this Adventure Path!

If the PCs insist on taking on the Trial of Runes while war rages around them, the distractions and stray ranged attacks and other elements should increase the DCs of all skill checks made during this already difficult encounter by 2.

To begin the trial proper, the PCs must first display their mastery over rune magic. Any character who has taken the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.journals.JournalEntry.vx5FGEG34AxI2dow.JournalEntryPage.09VwtSsYldMkVzU1]{Runelord} archetype or the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.Af7vcTToxetHThj4]{Avenging Runelord} mythic destiny can do so by simply stepping forward and presenting themselves to the sentries. Presenting a magic item that is at least level 15 and has ties to ancient Thassilon also suffices. By now, the PCs should possess at least one such item. ( Maddenmist’s greater staff of arcane might, the runic skullcap from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01sleepinggrot00]{A4}, or the Kardosian Fragments will all do as examples, but the emerald eye will not.) Allow the PCs a few attempts, but if they struggle, allow any PC a @Check[arcana|dc:30] check to realize what they should do. If no PC satisfies the sentinels, they immediately trigger the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02therunesentr00]{The Rune Sentries} hazard.

If the PCs prove they’re worthy to undertake the Trial of Runes, the examination begins. During the trial, the sentries depicting six of the original runelords—Kaliphesta (gluttony), Naaft (envy), Kaladurnae (greed), Xirie (sloth), Alderpash (wrath), and Sorshen (lust)—each ask a question geared toward that runelord’s specific interests. The sentries can ask their questions in whatever order you prefer. Notably, Xanderghul’s head remains silent throughout the trial, scowling disapprovingly at the PCs each time they answer another sentry’s question. To answer a Rune Sentry’s question, a PC must use the Answer Sentry activity.

Answer Sentry 2

  • concentrate
  • Secret

The PCs can discuss their responses but must designate one character as their representative for each question to deliver the group’s answer using this activity. When that PC answers, they must phrase the answer in a way that not only contains an appropriate reply, but is phrased with the proper level of respect to the runelord tradition being addressed. There’s no one right answer to any of these questions; as long as you deem the reply to be appropriate and earnest, then the PC attempts a @Check[arcana|dc:39] check, a @Check[diplomacy|dc:44] check, or a DC 36 check made with either one of that particular Rune Sentinel’s favored skills. A character who doesn’t speak the answer can Aid the party’s representative as normal. While there’s no one “correct” answer to any question, the results of each skill check are as follows.

Critical Success The PC answers the question to the sentry’s satisfaction. The head remains floating but crashes to ground when the Rune Sentries hazard is triggered, removing that head’s action during the hazard’s routine. The answer also impresses the remaining sentries, causing the DC of the next check to Answer Sentry to be reduced by 2. The first PC to achieve a critical success when Answering Sentry earns 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Success As critical success, but the answer doesn’t impress the remaining sentries, and the following checks are made at the normal DC.

Failure The PC’s answer fails to satisfy the sentry. The head remains floating and animates when the Rune Sentries hazard is triggered.

Critical Failure As Failure, but the remaining Rune Sentries scowl their disapproval—the DC of the next check to Answer Sentry increases by 2.

Crypt of Envy.name: Crypt of Envy
Crypt of Envy.text:
B3. Crypt of Envy

Nine mausoleums of green marble line the walls of this chamber. An extension in the room’s northeast corner contains a tenth mausoleum. Even more impressive than the others, this structure is domed and features a colonnade around its circumference. The doors of all ten crypts have been shattered, leaving fist-sized chunks of marble scattered about their entrances.

Nine ghostly figures dressed in the same finery as the statues in the hallway to the south are gathered in the center of the room. The figures bicker with each other, seemingly moments away from coming to blows.

Outraged that Xanderghul has defiled their mausoleums, echoes of the souls of the first nine runelords of envy argue about what to do to avenge this slight. Though the doors of Belimarius’s mausoleum (the circular structure in the room’s northeast corner) have also been shattered, Belimarius herself isn’t present—her mausoleum is of symbolic value only.

While the souls of these nine runelords have long departed, these lingering spiritual echoes maintain much of their former personalities but exist more akin to haunts today than as physically dangerous undead. The nine runelord manifestations continue to bicker, oblivious to the PCs until someone addresses them or attempts to interact with them.

These spirits argue in Thassilonian, yet the magic of this chamber allows each PC to understand the spirits in their native tongue as they go around and around in circles, arguing over whose fault it was that Xanderghul robbed their tombs. If the PCs interrupt the spirits or attempt to interact with them, the spirits angrily accuse the PCs of being Xanderghul’s minions or sycophants. While the spirits can take no physical action, their anger at the PCs should be apparent.

The PCs can’t fight these spirits, and any attempt to do so is only interpreted by the spirits as proof of their allegiance to Xanderghul. Some of the spirits might challenge the PCs and give them a chance to prove otherwise if the PCs don’t begin to speak to them on their own. The proper way to resolve this encounter is by interacting with the spirits in an Influence encounter (GM Core 187). The PCs have three 10-minute rounds to influence the bickering spirits. If the PCs don’t reach the second influence threshold by that time (or if they spend more than 1 minute attempting and failing to combat the spirits), the spirits disappear into their mausoleums, each preferring to let Xanderghul’s crime go unavenged than share their power with another.

Spirits of Envy Influence 16

  • Unique
  • Spirit

Perception +31

Will +33

Discovery @Check[arcana|dc:33|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[occultism|dc:35|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[perception|dc:37|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover]

Influence Skills @Check[society|dc:33|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to impress the spirits by citing notable achievements from their lives), @Check[deception|dc:35|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] or @Check[diplomacy|dc:35|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to flatter the spirits without making an individual runelord jealous), @Check[performance|dc:36|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to inspire the assembled spirits with promises of Xanderghul’s punishment), @Check[intimidation|dc:38|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to command the attention of the bickering spirits)

Influence 3 The spirits stop arguing long enough to listen the PCs. The next three Influence checks gain a +1 circumstance bonus to the roll.

Influence 6 Five of the spirits agree the PCs are their best chance for getting revenge against Xanderghul. This is enough support to break the ward of envy blocking entrance to the Crypt of Pride, even though four of the spirits still doubt the PCs’ ability to act as their avengers.

Influence 9 All nine of the spirits are impressed by the PCs. The spirit of Runelord Phirandi (or whichever runelord the PCs took the greatest liking to during the encounter) thanks the PCs for agreeing to avenge their legacies against Xanderghul and grants the PCs the favor of envy. Grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for this legendary accomplishment.

Resistances The spirits would rather let Xanderghul go unpunished than share their power with each other. Suggesting that the spirits work together increases the check’s DC by 2.

Weaknesses If the PCs recovered Belimarius’s replica halberd from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02covetouscorr00]{B2} and carry it openly, the runelords squabble over which of them should claim it; as long as the halberd remains visible, all Influence checks gain a +1 circumstance bonus. Some of the spirits go so far as to suggest that the halberd be destroyed so that no one can use it—if the PCs destroy the halberd in front of the spirits, they’re so delighted that the party automatically earns enough points to reach Influence 9 and the encounter ends.

Background The runelords of envy ruled the Thassilonian realm of Edasseril for over 1,000 years before Earthfall struck. There were more runelords of envy than any other sin, as many were overthrown by their aspiring successors. Naaft was the first Runelord of Envy and the original wielder of the Invidious Halberd. The second-to-last Runelord of Envy, Phirandi, was poisoned by his own apprentice, Belimarius.

Appearance The spirits wear the symbols of office appropriate to a runelord, but their forms are incorporeal, becoming more and less substantial as their anger ebbs and flows.

Personality Like childish politicians, the spirits of envy are more concerned with personal power than the greater good. Individuals are susceptible to flattery but grow jealous when forced to share the spotlight with others.

Reward: If the PCs earn at least 6 IP during the encounter with the runelords of envy, award them 40 XP. The first PC to achieve a critical success at an Influence check or Discovery check during this encounter earns 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

The Gullet.name: The Gullet
The Gullet.text:
B4. The Gullet Moderate 16

Frescoes depicting sumptuous feasts decorate the walls of this passageway. Though the scenes at the western end of the hall look festive, the images become increasingly decadent as they progress eastward down the passage. Starting at the hall’s midpoint, about seventy feet down its length, men and women dressed in fine robes preside over the feasts, encouraging their guests to partake in greater excesses. At its eastern end, the hallway opens into a larger chamber.

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:30] or appropriate Lore check confirms that the figures presiding over the feasts are depictions of the five runelords of gluttony: Kaliphesta, Atharend, Aethusa, Goparlis, and Zutha. Characters who move to inspect the figures, however, risk triggering a devious trap.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.IDh8RQdvdqqMFuqE]{Toggle See-saw}

B4. The Gullet Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.qnsv0JUpccFLnesA]{The Gullet}

Hazard: The floor tilts once a significant amount of weight (such as the majority of the PCs) is placed beyond its midpoint, 70 feet down its length. The eastern side of the floor declines 110 feet, forming a ramp that sends the PCs tumbling down into a chamber beneath the hallway (area B4a) and temporarily blocks their access to the Crypt of Gluttony (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofglutt00]{B5}). Once the weight in the hallway returns to an even distribution (such as when the PCs are deposited in area B4a), the ramp rises back to its original position. Depending on how the PCs enter the hallway, one or more of the characters might find themselves separated from their companions for the time being!

Once the Gullet resets, returning to the hall from the lower chamber is essentially impossible without teleportation. However, a 140-foot-long ladder leading up to stairs in the lower chamber’s southwest corner (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02bwormpitunde00]{B4b}) connects to the Crypt of Gluttony (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofglutt00]{B5}), giving separated PCs a chance to reunite with their companions.

Worm Pit.name: Worm Pit
Worm Pit.text:
B4b. Worm Pit Low 16

PCs who fail to Grab an Edge when the ramp tilts are deposited in a chamber 30 feet below the tilted ramp’s end (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02thegulletund00]{B4a}). The chamber is unlit and featureless except for a ladder carved into the southwest wall that leads 140 feet up to a flight of stairs. It’s a @Check[athletics|dc:20|traits:move,skill,action:climb|name:Climb] check to climb this awkward ladder.

B4b. Worm Pit Low 16

@UUID[Actor.TErjhiTeUZ3ejU7Y]{Insatiable Bore Worm Swarm}

Creature: An insatiable bore worm swarm—each maggot bloated to the size of a large rat—awaits characters who fall into the chamber. Sustained through magical means yet not to the extent that their hunger is ever fulfilled, the worm swarm relentlessly pursues its prey, fighting to the death. Note that unlike typical bore worms, these worms can climb but cannot burrow. They only climb up the walls of this pit to pursue escaping meals, never to escape themselves.

The Feast.name: The Feast
The Feast.text:
The Feast

Moments after the PCs defeat the ravenous crypts, the spirits of four former runelords of gluttony manifest at the dining table near Zutha’s mausoleum. (If the table was overturned or otherwise damaged during the fight with the ravenous crypts, it magically resets itself as the spirits of the runelords arrive.) Ominously absent among the spirits is Runelord Zutha, despite his apparent destruction during the events of Return of the Runelords. Whether Zutha’s spirit has been permanently destroyed or lies dormant somewhere between the realms of the living and dead, waiting to rise again, is beyond the scope of this adventure.

As the runelords take their seats, a sumptuous banquet appears before them. The first runelord of gluttony, an imperious woman named Kaliphesta, gestures for the PCs to join them as she and the other runelords begin to eat. Even though the meal is made from spirit-stuff and provides no nourishment (to the living at least), the roasted meats, pies, puddings, candied nuts, and fine wine are all indistinguishable from the real things and quite delicious.

A PC who joins the feast must be careful not to overindulge, for the meal is supernaturally compelling and amazing in flavor. Each PC who joins the feast must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:37] saving throw. On a failure, the PC is overstuffed and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 3} on a critical failure) for 24 hours (@UUID[Item.hxnqMQ7r2RyLVs6f]{Overstuffed} @UUID[Item.god4rabc4flRss1f]{Overstuffed (Critical Failure)}).

Between bites, the runelords of gluttony bemoan the fact that their mausoleums have been violated. The PCs can commiserate with the runelords, boast of how they’re going to defeat Xanderghul, speak of other topics, or simply feast in silence—the runelord spirits are too focused on their own meals to make much notice of anything the PCs do during the feast until it runs its course after 30 minutes. At this time, if at least half of the PCs took part in the feast, the runelords approve and agree that the PCs’ appetites are worthy—this support is enough to break the ward of gluttony blocking entrance to the Crypt of Pride. If all of the PCs took part in the feast, the runelords are particularly impressed, and the PCs earn the favor of gluttony.

These spirits revisit their feast every 24 hours, should the PCs choose to return at any time.

Reward: If all of the PCs take part in the feast and earn the favor of gluttony, award them all 20 XP. The first PC to achieve a critical success at a saving throw during the feast earns 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

False Crypt.name: False Crypt
False Crypt.text:
B6. False Crypt

Seven mausoleums decorated with exquisitely carved columns occupy this chamber. The doors of each stand open, allowing the structures’ contents—piles of coins, gemstones, and jewelry—to spill out. Set into the wall near the chamber’s entrance is a plaque of beaten brass.

An ancient Azlanti inscription on the brass plaque reads: “Abundance everlasting to the seven runelords of greed: Kaladurnae, Fethryr, Gimmel, Ligniya, Mazmiranna, Aethusa, and Haphrama.”

Wary PCs might be suspicious of so much treasure collected in one place and apparently free for the taking. The number of mausoleums is another clue that not everything here is what it seems, as there were eight runelords of greed, not seven. Runelord Karzoug’s crypt is missing.

Other than the plaque by the entrance, nothing in the chamber is real. The mausoleums and mounds of treasure are all expertly crafted counterfeits designed to foil would-be thieves. A character who inspects the chamber (without touching any of the treasure) can see through the counterfeit valuables with a successful @Check[crafting|dc:35] check or @Check[perception|dc:37] check.

A character who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check to Search the area near the plaque discovers that the wall there is designed to shift to one side. Touching the plaque while speaking Karzoug’s name aloud magically causes the wall to shift, revealing a passage leading to the real Crypt of Greed (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofgreed00]{B7}). Alternatively, the wall can be Forced Open with a successful @Check[type:athletics|dc:37|traits:attack,skill,action:force-open|name:Force Open] check.

A character who attempts to physically interact with any of the counterfeit treasure in this room is targeted by a powerful curse.

Counterfeit Transformation Curse 17

  • Arcane
  • Curse
  • Incapacitation
  • Polymorph

Those who would rob from the runelords of greed are cursed to become what they ignorantly covet—false treasure. A character who interacts with any of the valuables in this false crypt is targeted by this curse.

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:36]; Effect As detailed below.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected, but realizes they were nearly transformed into a counterfeit treasure.

Success The creature takes @Damage[6d6[bludgeoning]] damage as their body undergoes painful physical changes and contortions before returning to their true form without further effects from the curse. If they trigger this curse again, they must attempt the save once more, but gain a +2 circumstance bonus to the roll.

Failure The creature transforms into a valuable looking piece of artwork (of a size no more than Bulk 2) in which they are recognizable—a masterwork painting, a statuette made of a valuable material, or simply with their countenance rendered in miniature on a weapon’s pommel or a goblet’s side. The nature of the transformation should play into the PC’s theme and personality. The transformed character remains aware of their surroundings while cursed, but can take no actions while cursed. At the end of each hour, the PC can attempt a new @Check[fortitude|dc:36] saving throw to recover from the curse, but on a critical failure on this save, the curse becomes permanent. Once a PC recovers from this curse in this way, they are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} with an unlimited duration, as their bodies never quite feel the same. The cursed character can still be targeted by effects like Break Curse or cleanse affliction, and if the curse is removed in this way, they do not suffer the clumsy condition thereafter (@UUID[Item.070LNqdncauImI9H]{Lingering Discomfort}).

Critical Failure As failure, except without the chance to recover; the curse automatically has an unlimited duration.

Crypt of Greed.name: Crypt of Greed
Crypt of Greed.text:
B7. Crypt of Greed

The seven mausoleums in this chamber are every bit as opulent as those in the previous room. However, their doors have been pried open, and any treasure they once contained has been looted.

The mausoleums in the north half of the room belong to the first four runelords of greed, while the ones against the southern wall belong to the next three. Karzoug’s domed mausoleum, even more luxurious than the others, occupies the room’s southeast corner.

As the PCs enter the area, the spirits of the eight runelords of Greed—Kaladurnae, Fethryr, Gimmel, Ligniya, Mazmiranna, Aethusa, Haphrama, and Karzoug—manifest before them. The runelords are outraged their tombs have been looted, and for a moment seem as if they might blame the PCs for the theft. Just before the spirits turn on the party, however, Karzoug stays their hand. “These troublesome heroes aren’t worthy of our ire,” the runelord sneers, “but we might use them against the one who is.” He addresses the PCs. “It seems we have a common enemy in Xanderghul. What price will you pay in return for our help?”

At this point, the PCs can bargain for the runelords’ favor by taking the Haggle with Greed activity. Each PC can attempt to bargain once with the runelords. Once all of the PCs who want to attempt this activity have made their checks, total the number of Bargaining Points they’ve accumulated and compare them to the results below to determine the final results.

Haggle with Greed

  • Concentrate
  • Exploration

You attempt to convince the spirits of the runelords of greed to grant you the power to break the greed rune. The spirits first ask what you have to offer; if what you initially offer as payment for their aid is worth less than 10,000 gp, the spirits are unimpressed. You can try to Haggle with Greed again if you offer something worth the proper amount.

Once you offer something properly valuable, attempt a skill check to determine how many Bargaining Points (BP) your efforts yield. You can attempt a @Check[diplomacy|dc:35] check to convince the runelords to accept your offer, or a @Check[deception|dc:37] check to exaggerate the value of your offering. If your offer includes treasure of special value to the runelords of greed (such as the bust of Runelord Gimmel from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01antechamber000]{A3} of the Tarnished Temple), you gain a +2 circumstance bonus the check.

Critical Success You gain 2 BP.

Success You gain 1 BP.

Critical Failure You make a crucial misstep and lose 1 BP.

1 Bargaining Point The runelords grant the PCs the power to break the greed ward, but only if they offer something worth at least 20,000 gp. If the PCs refuse, the spirits fade and do not return.

2 Bargaining Points The runelords accept the offered payment, provided it’s worth at least 10,000 gp. In return, they grant the PCs the power to break the greed ward.

3 Bargaining Points The runelords are impressed by the PCs’ haggling, and agree to grant them the power to break the greed ward in return for an offering worth at least 5,000 gp—or for the bust of Gimmel from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01antechamber000]{A3} of the Tarnished Temple, if the PCs offer it. In addition, Runelord Karzoug graces the PCs with the favor of greed.

Reward: If the PCs earn the favor of gluttony, award them all 20 XP. The first PC to achieve a critical success at a saving throw during the haggling earns 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Crypt of Lust.name: Crypt of Lust
Crypt of Lust.text:
B8. Crypt of Lust Moderate 16

Murals depicting carnal pleasures decorate the walls of this pillared hall, which opens into a larger space at its western end.

Unlike the other sin crypts, this area doesn’t contain mausoleums built in honor of former runelords, because Sorshen, the Runelord of Lust, lived beyond the fall of Thassilon. Instead, the west end of the hall opens into a chamber decorated with floor-to-ceiling murals depicting important events from Sorshen’s life: her exodus with Xin from Azlant and her founding of Eurythnia, her discovery of the Everdawn Pool, and her creation of the Eye of Desire, the demiplane where she took refuge during Earthfall.

As the PCs enter the chamber at the far end of the hall, a psychic projection of Sorshen steps from a mural to address the party. The PCs should recognize Sorshen immediately, as they met her in the flesh in Xin-Shalast during the events of Lord of the Trinity Star. She seems worse for wear, however, and her image flickers in and out of existence as she addresses the party.

“At last, I’ve reached you! As you already know, Xanderghul has returned, and I believe he intends to destroy Golarion, starting with the Saga Lands! Find me in Jandelay and I can—”

At that point, Sorshen’s message is cut short as thick gray smoke rises from the floor to obscure her image. Through the haze, the PCs spy shapes that hint at crumbling buildings and broken boulevards—the devastated landscape of Jandelay, a demiplane where the remnants of dead worlds are collected. A PC can recognize what this vision shows with a successful @Check[occultism|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[religion|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge. When the smoke clears, Sorshen has disappeared, replaced by two faceless figures that immediately advance on the party.

B8. Crypt of Lust Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.Fr66mFzzKu6UZiET]{Jandelay Tolokands (2)}

Creatures: Sensing Sorshen’s attempt to communicate with the PCs, the Ashen Man dispatched two of his agents, a pair of tolokands, to intercept them. These tolokands wear open gray robes that appear to have been partially burnt, and their bodies flake drifts of ash with every movement. The tolokands arrive having already cast haste on themselves. They begin the battle by Demoralizing the nearest characters, mocking their efforts to save an already doomed world—unlike normal tolokands, these ones are more self-aware and can speak in raspy, grating voices. “Hope is gone,” they say. “Golarion is marked for destruction. The Ashen Man’s reward has come.” These mythic tolokands pursue characters who try to flee, fighting to the death.

Reward: Attempts to reestablish contact with Sorshen inevitably fail. However, once the tolokands are defeated, Sorshen musters the power to grant the PCs power over the rune of lust and grants them the favor of lust.

Slothful Stairs.name: Slothful Stairs
Slothful Stairs.text:
B9. Slothful Stairs Moderate 16

A daunting flight of stairs spirals upward hundreds of feet before disappearing into the darkness.

Clever PCs might recognize that the taxing climb required by the stairwell seems out of character for any crypt of the Runelord of Sloth. A character who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:35|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check to Search the hallway outside the stairwell discovers the secret door leading to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofsloth00]{B10}, allowing the party to bypass the stairs.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.VOun4NCvVrHXdm6H]{Toggle Staircase}

B9. Slothful Stairs Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.X0zys4hj4zPT9lM2]{Slothful Stairs}

Hazard: PCs who choose to climb the stairs feel their limbs grow heavier with every step; even flying characters experience this effect. After climbing upward for 100 feet, the sensation becomes so overwhelming that the PCs are forced to make a choice: either turn back or risk exhausting themselves. A PC who’s determined to press on must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:35] saving throw or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} until they leave the stairwell.

The first PC to reach the top of the stairwell after clambering for 300 feet discovers that it ends at a featureless wall. Touching or otherwise inspecting the blank wall triggers a hazard. A PC can avoid some of this hazard’s dangers by flying, or by Climbing the outer walls with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:move,skill,action:climb|name:Climb] check.

Reward: If the PCs discover the secret door to the Crypt of Sloth or otherwise avoid the treacherous stairwell, grant them XP as if they had disabled the trap.

Crypt of Sloth.name: Crypt of Sloth
Crypt of Sloth.text:
B10. Crypt of Sloth

Seven mausoleums fill this chamber. The structures are all grand in design, but their stone doors have been shattered, and their contents looted.

Starting at the eastern mausoleum and working clockwise, the mausoleums belong to the seven runelords of sloth: Xirie, Ilthyrius, Azeradni, Zalelet, Krenlith, Ivarinna, and Krune.

When the PCs arrive (either though the secret passage or via the portal from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02slothfulstai00]{B9}), they’re met by the spirits of the runelords of sloth. The runelords aren’t pleased their crypts have been defiled, but they can’t be bothered to do anything about it themselves. Instead, they conceal their indolence by claiming that they must remain cautious, lest Xanderghul discover their plans to move against him.

If any of the PCs volunteer to seek vengeance on their behalf, the runelords are happy to delegate the task. Krune, a man whose skin is tattooed with the formulas of hundreds of spells, marks one of the PCs with a glowing rune of sloth. That PC must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:35] saving throw or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} on a critical failure) until the rune of sloth warding the entrance to the Crypt of Pride is destroyed. In addition, the PCs gain the favor of sloth. This is a level 16 curse effect. Removing it doesn’t revoke the PCs’ support of the runelords of sloth or the favor of sloth.

Field of Ruin.name: Field of Ruin
Field of Ruin.text:
B11. Field of Ruin Trivial 16

Instead of connecting directly to the Crypt of Wrath (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofwrath00]{B12}), this hallway opens into a demiplane manifested by Runelord Alaznist’s anger. As soon as the first PC enters this area, all of the PCs are suddenly transported into a demiplane forged from the wrath of Runelord Alaznist’s shattered soul. Each PC must immediately attempt a @Check[will|dc:35] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 4} on a critical failure) from the overwhelming hatred they feel directed at them as they gaze upon the new world they find themselves in. (This transportation into the field of ruin happens only once—if the PCs escape and then return here at a later time, this area functions as an unremarkable hallway.)

The carnage of a great conflict stretches as far as the eye can see, a rolling plain of broken warriors and gulches choked with blood. A shrieking wind echoes across the landscape, while high above, the overcast sunset sky roils with thunderheads streaked with lightning. Atop a distant hill stands a ring of five white-walled mausoleums.

In 4716 ar (during the events of the Return of the Runelords Adventure Path), Runelord Alaznist awoke and set about to alter the history of Golarion. Before her altered timeline could replace the original, however, a group of heroes defeated Alaznist, and her soul was torn apart. The demiplane that now links the Crypt of Wrath to the rest of the Emerald Chambers is a manifestation of Alaznist’s hatred for the Saga Lands—the realm where she suffered her defeat and a land she would rather see destroyed than remain free of her control.

The entrance to the demiplane disappears as soon as a PC steps onto the battlefield (though it remains visible from the opposite side). When the PCs first arrive, give them a few minutes to take measure of their new surroundings. Characters who examine the bodies discover warriors from all across the Saga Lands among the casualties. At the GM’s discretion, some of the NPCs the characters met previously in the adventure—even ones who would be out of place on a battlefield, such as Sheila Heidmarch of Magnimar—might also be among the fallen. Other than the fact that all these people met a violent end, no clue exists as to the nature of the conflict that occurred. As far as the PCs can tell, the battlefield stretches forever in all directions.

The five mausoleums stand atop a rise roughly 160 feet away from where the PCs enter the demiplane. The structures are replicas of the mausoleums in the Crypt of Wrath (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofwrath00]{B12}) and are positioned in roughly the same arrangement. Like the mausoleums in that area, the doors of these structures have shattered. The demiplane itself has the unbounded scope trait—as soon as a PC moves more than 160 feet from the center of the demiplane (where the mausoleums stand), they loop back on themselves and once again face the mausoleums. Up close, it’s obvious that the shattered doors of the mausoleums open not into a stony interior, but out into an underground room—a PC who steps through one of the mausoleum entrances emerges from the corresponding structure in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofwrath00]{B12} of the Crypt of Wrath. A PC who does so and then turns around to look into the crypt they just “exited” from sees not this battlefield, but the crypt’s looted interior.

B11. Field of Ruin Trivial 16

@UUID[Actor.pan7rJotLml1O93c]{Warsworn}

Creatures: As soon as the PCs arrive in the demiplane, a thundering bellow rises in the distance as a mass of broken bodies coalesces into a warsworn that rushes toward the party like a wave. The warsworn begins the encounter at a point on the opposite side of the demiplane from the PCs on the far side of the mausoleums, 320 feet away. Every four rounds, another warsworn erupts from the edge of the demiplane in a randomly determined quadrant. There is no limit to the number of warsworn that can be pulled into this realm, although only 4 can be in existence here at any one time, with a replacement warsworn appearing four rounds after this maximum is reduced.

You can use the layout of the five tombs from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofwrath00]{B12} for this fight, but extend the battlefield outward in all directions 160 feet. The battlefield itself features no real terrain of note, although feel free to place patches of difficult terrain in the form of mounds of dead bodies here and there if you wish.

Reward: Regardless of how many warsworn the PCs defeat here, grant them 40 XP once they escape this encounter. If the party makes it out of this demiplane without killing a single warsworn, grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Pride Crypt Entrance.name: Pride Crypt Entrance
Pride Crypt Entrance.text:
B13. Pride Crypt Entrance Moderate 16

This hall is eighty feet wide and nearly twice as long, with a ceiling that soars roughly fifty feet overhead. Twin rows of marble columns run down the length of the space. On the western wall, a pair of archways open onto stairwells heading down, while a third archway on the opposite wall leads to a passage extending east. A fresco with figures the size of giants decorates the northern wall.
