The fresco on the north wall depicts scenes from Xanderghul’s life, including his meeting with the linnorm Fafnheir, his ascension into the Peacock Spirit, and the civil war in which he killed the runelords Angothane, Atharend, and Jurah. The fresco is enchanted with an illusion that causes the figures of Xanderghul to sneer at creatures who approach the scenes. While unsettling, this effect is harmless.

A PC who succeeds at a @Check[type:perception|dc:33|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:search|name:Search] check while Searching the area notices that a section of wall in the southeast corner is designed to slide to one side. The occupants of the Crypt of Pride are aware of this secret door and might use it to outmaneuver the PCs. The door is obvious from the opposite side.

Loud noises in this room carry to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02fleshworks0000]{B15} and @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02viewingchamb00]{B17}. While the other runelords don’t rush to Haphrama’s aid, they’re prepared for battle when the PCs arrive in those areas.

B13. Pride Crypt Entrance Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.H8iDGMg5gXpFVAFa]{Risen Runelord Haphrama} @UUID[Actor.CvuSQZwyDfC4HcVK]{Pridespawn Cultists (4)}

Creatures: A quartet of pridespawn cultists and Risen Runelord Haphrama, the direct predecessor of Runelord Karzoug, are stationed here to protect the entrance to the Crypt of Pride. Unless the PCs go out of their way to announce their entrance, when the party arrives, Haphrama is at the north end of the hall admiring the fresco, while the pridespawn linger near the southern stairwell. When they detect intruders, the pridespawn rush to attack. Haphrama has already manifested his runelord’s polearm (a burning glaive); his first action in combat is to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.A2JfEKe6BZcTG1S8]{Fly} on himself so he can soar up near the ceiling for the duration of the fight. During the battle, Haphrama targets the PCs with his most powerful spells (or attacks with his glaive if the PCs manage to reach him in melee), but once the pridespawn are defeated, he casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{Translocate} to teleport to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02barracksunde00]{B14}. If the PCs don’t discover the secret door to that area, Haphrama might return with reinforcements from there to confront the PCs as they explore other parts of the crypt. On this second confrontation, Haphrama fights to the death.

Crypt of Wrath.name: Crypt of Wrath
Crypt of Wrath.text:
B12. Crypt of Wrath

Five mausoleums, each carved with scenes of battle, crowd this oddly shaped chamber. The marble doors of each structure have been shattered, littering the floor with rubble.

The mausoleum of the final Runelord of Wrath, Alaznist, stands against the wall in the chamber’s southwest corner, while those of the other four runelords (Alderpash, Angothane, Xiren, and Thybidos) fill the remainder of the space.

A PC that enters one of the mausoleums atop the hill in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02fieldofruinu00]{B11} arrives from the corresponding structure in this chamber and are immediately met by the ghostly echo of Runelord Alaznist surrounded by the frightened spirits of three other figures—Runelords Angothane, Xiren, and Thybidos. Curiously, Alderpash’s spirit is not present (nor will the PCs encounter a Risen Alderpash, for he yet exists as a lich deep in the Outer Rifts). Rubble from the mausoleums’ broken doors swirls about her in a cloud animated by Alaznist’s rage. Her form is constantly being torn apart by fire and ice, lightning and acid, talons and tentacles, wind and wave, reforming after every destruction to repeat a new devastation. This remnant of the final runelord of Wrath takes note of the PCs as soon as they’re all gathered here or as soon as one of the PCs attempts to interact with her.

As soon as her attention is drawn to the PCs, each character realizes that even after her irrevocable destruction at the culmination of the events of the Return of the Runelords Adventure Path, her rage lives on. Each PC has a brief vision of somewhere on Golarion they hold dear being destroyed by an apocalypse caused by Alaznist and can tell that the wrathful energies in the room are now building toward them as the other three runelords of wrath feed into Alaznist’s rage. In order to calm and focus this chaos, the PCs must work to influence the spirits of the runelords—not through conversation, as is the norm for influence encounters, but by opposing the raw fury with their own emotional, spiritual, and physical conviction

This is an influence encounter (Pathfinder GM Core 187). The PCs have three one-minute rounds to sway Alaznist.

As a reminder, a character wielding Maddenmist’s greater staff of arcane might (from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22001histor.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{A5} of the Tarnished Temple) gains a +2 circumstance bonus to checks made to influence Alaznist.

Remnants of Wrath Influence 18

  • Unique
  • Mythic
  • Spirit

Perception +33

Will +36

Discovery @Check[arcana|dc:36|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[occultism|dc:38|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover] or @Check[religion|dc:38|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[perception|dc:40|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover]

Influence Skills @Check[intimidation|dc:36|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to refocus wrath from the Saga Lands to Xanderghul and to promise vengeance), @Check[arcana|dc:37|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to know how to disperse and lessen the wrathful magic), @Check[religion|dc:38|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to force intrusive elements from the Outer Rifts back from whence the came), @Check[occultism|dc:39|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to draw upon obscure rites and incantations to lessen the magic’s power), @Check[deception|dc:40|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[diplomacy|dc:43|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

Influence 2 Alaznist’s rage against the Saga Lands is lessened, but she still isn’t ready to turn her wrath to Xanderghul.

Influence 4 Alaznist concedes that her wrath has been misplaced and focuses instead on how to make Xanderghul pay for his recent insults. Her support is enough to break the ward of wrath blocking entrance to the Crypt of Pride.

Influence 6 Alaznist accepts the PCs as her proxies for vengeance against Xanderghul. The PCs can not only break the ward of wrath, but gain the favor of wrath.

Resistances Alaznist’s wrath is literally undying. Suggesting she’s been beaten or that the time has come to let go of her hatred increases the check’s DC by 2.

Weaknesses If the PCs remind Alaznist of her past victories—such as her defeat of two previous runelords of wrath, Alderpash and Thybidos, or of her more recent murder of Xanderghul—they reduce the DC of all subsequent checks by 2.

Background Alaznist was the last and longest ruling runelord of wrath. In the recent past, Alaznist attempted to rewrite the timeline of Golarion and conquer the modern Saga Lands. Her defeat led to the founding of the nation of New Thassilon.

Appearance Alaznist appears as she did in life, a red-haired human woman wielding a ranseur, though rage has warped her features into an inhuman mask, and her body is constantly being destroyed and rebuilt.

Personality This isn’t actually Alaznist—simply her rage given spiritual form. At this point, her anger can’t be assuaged, only redirected.

Special At the end of the third influence round, the wrathful energy that’s been building in the chamber finally reaches a critical point of no return. If the PCs have reached at least 4 Influence Points, this wrath collapses on itself, and the room goes silent. If the PCs have 2 or 3 Influence Points, the wrath explodes into a burst of rage, sending spiritual energy and fragments of stone outward—all creatures in area B12 take @Damage[4d10[bludgeoning]] and @Damage[4d10[spirit]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:35|basic] save). This damage increases to @Damage[8d10[bludgeoning]] and @Damage[8d10[spirit]] damage if the PCs have 1 or fewer Influence Points.

Reward: If the PCs earn 4 IP or more while reasoning with Alaznist’s spirit, award them 60 XP. Regardless of the outcome, influencing the remnants of wrath is a mythic deed that grants each PC 3 Mythic Points.

Breaking the Ward.name: Breaking the Ward
Breaking the Ward.text:
Breaking the Ward

Once the PCs have earned the favor of at least four sins gathered from the other six crypts, they can return to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02heartofsin0000]{B1} and break the corresponding rune wards on the entrance to the Crypt of Pride. Once the PCs become favored by a sin, they automatically know how to destroy the corresponding ward, by using a single Interact action that involves pressing their hand to the door and letting the vengeful energies of the runelords they represent flow into the magic of the ward. Once four of the rune wards are broken, the remaining three crumble into glowing dust that dissipates as if carried away on the wind.

Scene Notes Macros

@UUID[Macro.aZGaBhADfzILmGSa]{Break Ward} @UUID[Macro.JvojQGMpjfJoSRFY]{Reset}

As the wards over the entrance to the Crypt of Pride fade, the PCs feel the spirits of bitter runelords infusing them—their need for vengeance against Runelord Xanderghul for not only this latest affront (the harvesting of their remains and legacies to create risen runelords), but for every affront he brought to them while he lived. Every runelord has a reason to hate Runelord Xanderghul.

While the southern half of the Crypt of Runes is light on magic item treasures, the breaking of this ward grants the PCs access to an entirely different type of reward—bonus abilities in the form of Avenger Feats. These six feats (one associated with each of the sins in the southern crypts) are detailed @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22006advent.JournalEntryPage.06vengeancefea00]{Here}, and at this time the PCs may each choose one as a bonus feat, selecting from any sin they’ve gained the favor of in the southern crypts. Allow the players to read and consider all the feats they have access to, and encourage each to pick a specific runelord as their “avenging patron.” This choice is purely for flavor, but at your discretion, if a PC confronts a risen runelord crafted from the legacy of their avenging patron, they should be able to automatically recognize who that risen runelord is. Since it’s possible to select avenging patrons who won’t be encountered as risen runelords or who have already been defeated, it’s best to resist giving any rules benefit to this recognition, although when such a confrontation occurs, you might wish to grant the avenging PC 1 Mythic Point for the legendary accomplishment.

Once the ward is destroyed and the passage to the Crypt of Pride is opened, the hazards and dangers present in the southern crypts go quiet. These rooms are now devoid of all danger.

Reward: Breaking the ward is a mythic deed, and its removal grants all of the PCs 3 Mythic Points.

The Crypt of Pride.name: The Crypt of Pride
The Crypt of Pride.text:
The Crypt of Pride

The Crypt of Pride was always the most magnificent of the seven crypts of sin, and since Xanderghul’s return, the runelord has enhanced its splendor, magically expanding the area both to serve as a base of operations for the cult of the Trinity Star and as a testament to his own greatness. Feel free to augment the readaloud text in these areas with additional flourishes of your own design.

Unlike areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02heartofsin0000]{B1}–@UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02cryptofwrath00]{B12}, most occupants of the Crypt of Pride aren’t bound to a particular location. Once they realize the Crypt of Pride has been invaded, the cultists respond by raising alarms, mustering reinforcements, and taking other logical steps to repel intruders. That said, the risen runelords of the cult are no more likely to work together than their real-life counterparts were, making a coordinated effort to defeat the PCs unlikely. Also working in the PCs’ favor is the fact that Risen Karzoug. whom Xanderghul left in charge of the cult, is currently elsewhere in the Emerald Chambers (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}). As a result, he doesn’t realize the crypt’s security has been compromised until the party encounters him in that area.

Barracks.name: Barracks
Barracks.text:
B14. Barracks Trivial 16

Two hallways, one to the west and a wider one to the north, open into a sitting area filled with simple but well-crafted tables and chairs. Doorways line the walls of the northern corridor, while two more stand in the sitting area’s western wall.

This area serves as the private quarters of the Risen of the Trinity Star cultists. As the cult has only recently occupied the crypt, the cultists haven’t had the chance to properly secure their rooms. Except where noted (in Treasure below), the doors of all rooms are unlocked.

B14. Barracks Trivial 16

@UUID[Actor.CvuSQZwyDfC4HcVK]{Pridespawn Cultists (4)}

Creatures: Unless a risen runelord has enlisted them to help deal with the PCs, four pridespawn are in the northernmost room adjacent to the sitting area when the party arrives. The door to the room is ajar; unless the PCs take measures to remain quiet, the pridespawn rush out and attack.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.0pZdZYwvNcJX7a2z]{Southern Room}
The northern hall has been claimed by the cult’s risen runelords, but as the runelords don’t sleep, the rooms see little use. They each contain a bed, wardrobe, and writing desk, but nothing of interest to the PCs. However, the southernmost room adjacent to the sitting area is where the cult has stored many of the treasures and items Xanderghul looted from the other crypts to create more risen runelords. The door to this room has a superior lock. Opening the door requires six successful @Check[thievery|dc:40|traits:manipulate,skill,action:pick-a-lock|name:Pick a Lock] checks to Pick the Lock or a @Check[athletics|dc:40|traits:attack,skill,action:force-open|name:Force Open] check to Force it Open. The key to the door is inside the lectern in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02commandcente00]{B18}.

Piled neatly on a table inside the room, the PCs discover a collection of rings, scepters, crowns, and other symbols of power, along with dozens of ceramic jars containing bone dust, worth a total of 9,000 gp. Among this non-magical treasure is a peering aeon stone and a wand of fireball widening (7th rank).

Fleshworks.name: Fleshworks
Fleshworks.text:
B15. Fleshworks Moderate 16

Four steel vats burbling with foul-smelling liquid occupy the southern leg of this L-shaped room. Filling the room’s northern half are worktables cluttered with surgical tools, anatomical drawings, and jars in which eyeballs, strips of flesh, and other body parts are suspended. A wide stairwell rises from the area with the vats, while a narrower hallway extends from the work area.

Xanderghul used this area to create the mortal body he now inhabits, using the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZr1xrCpaSu6qrXU]{Clone} ritual. While the creation of a mere clone normally would have been a simple matter, manufacturing a new body without tissue samples from his previous one—and accelerating the clone’s growth such that he could inhabit the body in days, rather than months—proved challenging even for the runelord, but his mythic power allowed him success in the end, and he abandoned Aethusa’s body with relief, leaving her imprisoned for now in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21} as a “spare body” to retreat to should he be slain.

Creatures: The results of Xanderghul’s failed experiments float in the liquid that fills the steel vats. Risen Runelord Kaliphesta, the first runelord of gluttony, works in the northern portion of the room, trying to salvage what she can from these failures.

B15. Fleshworks Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.o5EnbLep2ZnJS5I2]{Risen Runelord Kaliphesta} @UUID[Actor.asQXdSQaJh0QvpaK]{Elite Unrisen (4)}

If Kaliphesta is alerted to the sounds of combat in an adjoining room, she’s already manifested her runelord’s polearm (a scythe adorned with bones) and cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.zR67Rt3UMHKC5evy]{Flicker} (giving her resistance 11 to all damage except force) when the PCs arrive. The unrisen in the vats are currently in a state of suspended animation, but Kaliphesta can awaken the unrisen inside with a single command as a free action. Once awakened, an unrisen must use one action to Stand and another action to Climb out of the vat, but after that, the unrisen focus their attacks on the PCs, fighting until destroyed. They have little loyalty to Kaliphesta; they make no effort to exclude her (or each other) from their Agonized Howls, and if they sense weakness in the risen runelord (automatic once she’s reduced to fewer than 50 Hit Points) any remaining unrisen abandons the PCs as targets and focuses their attacks on her.

Kaliphesta has been hoping to find some clue in the laboratory here to ascend beyond her current existence as a magically created being with no capacity to grow or learn, but over the past few months she’s been left here to her devices, she’s made zero progress. The PCs are a much-needed place for her to vent her frustrations. She attempts to flee once reduced to fewer than 50 hit points, hoping to seek reinforcements from the pridespawn in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02barracksunde00]{B14} but fights to the death if cornered.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.Sw8AUCJaS360pMoJ]{Worktables} @UUID[Actor.um4UCU8aToOrUjzW]{Northern Worktable}
Among the items on the worktables are 1,600 gp worth of alchemical reagents suitable for the casting the clone ritual as well as Xanderghul’s extensive notes (with Kaliphesta’s annotations) about the process, which the PCs can use to learn the ritual. From these notes, the PCs can also learn that Xanderghul no longer possesses Aethusa, having built himself a new body. The notes also mention that he’s keeping her “safe” here in the chambers, as one more “spare” in the event of unexpected death. The PCs can learn more of this from Aethusa herself if they rescue her from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}.

Resting on the northernmost worktable is a major healing potion in a crusty-looking bottle, as well as a larger (and even crustier) bottle filled with ten days’ breath. Note that the bonus to saving throws against inhaled threats granted by the ten days’ breath applies to the Caustic Aura of the chromatic ooze in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02chromaticcau00]{B16}. A high-grade cold-iron dagger sits on one of the workbenches next to a high-grade silver dagger—tools Xanderghul used in his ritual but will serve well as weapons.

Chromatic Cauldron.name: Chromatic Cauldron
Chromatic Cauldron.text:
B16. Chromatic Cauldron Moderate 16

Both doors of this room are unlocked but air-tight, keeping the caustic aura of the chromatic ooze within the chamber contained. However, opening a door causes the caustic aura to expand all the way into parts of the adjoining room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02fleshworks0000]{B15} if the southern door is opened or area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02viewingchamb00]{B17} if the eastern door is opened). A creature that succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:35|traits:concentrate,secret,action:seek|name:Seek] check to Seek detects traces of the odor before opening a door. The Risen of the Trinity Star cultists are aware of the room’s contents and avoid entering it.

Shelves and marble worktables crowded with alchemical equipment occupy three of this room’s four corners. An enormous iron cauldron lies in the center of the room, nearly ten feet in diameter. Within the cauldron roils a glowing liquid that rapidly shifts between all colors of the spectrum, casting rainbow-dappled light throughout the room. As beautiful as it is visually, the substance emits a caustic stench that fills the chamber.

This chamber originally served as an annex of Xanderghul’s fleshwarp workshop (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02fleshworks0000]{B15}), but the runelord repurposed it during his efforts to create Aethusa’s prison (area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}).

B16. Chromatic Cauldron Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.Fl7rYsTOlNMpJVYn]{Chromatic Ooze}

Creatures: The multicolored substance that fills the cauldron is a proto-version of the substance that makes up Aethusa’s prison in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}. Xanderghul brewed the substance as a backup in the event Aethusa’s current prison failed. The substance is currently inert, but if a creature moves adjacent to the cauldron, it animates as a chromatic ooze and attacks. The ooze is contained within the cauldron at the start of the battle and has no speed, but its aura and its Pseudopod Eruption allow it to affect and attack foes regardless. At the end of each round, attempt a @Check[flat|dc:11]. On a success, the ooze’s violent motion causes the cauldron to tip over, disrupting the magic that kept it within the cauldron and allowing it to slither free. Once loose, the ooze pursues the PCs relentlessly but also attacks any other creature it encounters, including those lured in by the PCs. This chromatic ooze won’t live for long once it’s out of the cauldron that contained it and takes @Damage[20[spirit]] damage at the end of each round until it’s dead.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.KP9tVk83CfsIqD1e]{Alchemical Equipment} @UUID[Actor.fKJbEEYZRFBmKosJ]{Southwest Worktable} @UUID[Actor.yo7JQNDVA23Ksprm]{Cauldron}
The alchemical equipment is the equivalent of an expanded alchemist’s lab. Among the various beakers, vials, and jars on the shelves are the following alchemical items: a major acid flask, a vial of major alchemist’s fire, a major bottled lightning PC2, a major frost vial PC2, two greater bomber’s eye elixirs, and two major elixirs of life.

Lying on the worktable in the southwest corner are Xanderghul’s notes related to the creation of Aethusa’s prison. As a one-hour activity, a PC who can read Thassilonian can study these notes by attempting a @Check[arcana|dc:35] or @Check[crafting|dc:35] check. On a success, the PC gains a +1 circumstance bonus (+2 circumstance bonus on a critical success) to Arcana or Crafting checks made to disable Aethusa’s prison in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}.

Though it has no magical properties and is difficult to transport (Bulk 16), the cauldron in the center of the room is made of a rare alloy of gold and orichalcum. These valuable materials make the cauldron worth 15,000 gp—assuming its current contents are removed!

Viewing Chamber.name: Viewing Chamber
Viewing Chamber.text:
B17. Viewing Chamber Moderate 16

This narrow chamber is divided into two parts. The southern portion is empty, save for a set of steps leading down to the west and a second, wider stairwell heading up to the east. The northern third of the room overlooks the southern portion and can be accessed by a short flight of steps. Set into the north wall is a window nearly thirty feet in diameter, through which an expanse of wispy colors can be seen.

The window in the north wall is a portal to the Astral Plane. The window’s “glass” is a magical barrier that prevents creatures from crossing it, though anyone with sufficient magical skill can weaken the barrier, temporarily allowing travel between this chamber and the Astral Plane. Xanderghul used the window to bind the shining children that protect Aethusa’s prison in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02aethusaspris00]{B21}.

A PC can weaken the window’s barrier by spending 10 minutes focusing on the magic and succeeding at a @Check[arcana|dc:35] or @Check[occultism|dc:35] check, allowing creatures to travel through the window for 1 round. On a critical failure, the window darkens instead, severing its connection to the Astral Plane. If the PCs retreat to other side of the window, the Risen of the Trinity Star cultists don’t think to look for them there, giving the party a refuge where they can rest. The Arcana check to weaken the barrier must be repeated from the opposite side, however, to regain passage back. A PC who critically fails the check might inadvertently trap the party on the Astral Plane!

B17. Viewing Chamber Moderate 16

@UUID[Actor.FqLwmOMQDS1WfWxk]{Risen Runelord Xirie} @UUID[Actor.CvuSQZwyDfC4HcVK]{Pridespawn Cultists (4)}

Creatures: When the PCs arrive, four pridespawn are in the southern portion of the chamber, two by each of the two stairwells. Meanwhile, Xirie, the first runelord of sloth, stands before the Astral window. Like Xanderghul, Xirie is searching for shining children to serve her, but thus far she’s had no luck.

If caught unprepared, Xirie casts slither to try to hold the PCs in place then uses the distraction provided by the pridespawn to retreat to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02barracksunde00]{B14}, possibly casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force} to cover her escape. She manifests her runelord’s polearm (a spear tipped with a dragon’s tooth) and fights in melee only if she has no other options. If her pridespawn allies are slain or if she’s reduced to fewer than 50 HP, she attempts to flee to area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22002tentho.JournalEntryPage.02prisonentran00]{B20} to warn the runelords stationed there.

Doorways to Dream and Doom.text:
Chapter 3: Doorways to Dream and Doom

When this chapter begins, make sure the players feel like they’re up against the clock in stopping the Risen from achieving their apocalyptic goal, but until you begin @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event3saving00]{Event 3}, that ticking countdown doesn’t begin. The PCs should have time to rest and recover from their adventures in the Crypt of Runes but not time to pursue any other downtime activities. When they’ve recovered, begin Event 3. If the PCs delay further (such as by deciding to travel first, sell goods, and shop for gear), reduce the number of rounds they have to complete Event 3 by 1 for each significant delay.
Doorways to Dream and Doom.name: Doorways to Dream and Doom

Travel Time.name: Travel Time
Travel Time.text:
Travel Time

These obstacles take place at points across the Saga Lands, separated in some cases by hundreds of miles. The assumption is that the PCs are working with their dragon ally, Kandirvek, who can fly at significant speeds. Other options, such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rxvS7EMJ7qmexAyA]{Umbral Journey} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.U0hL0LLaprcnAyzC]{Migration}, can suffice to travel quickly as well.

Faster Travel: If the PCs use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.69L70wKfGDY66Mk9]{Teleport} or methods of travel that allow them to reach the location in only a few hours, reduce all DCs for that obstacle by 2.

Slower Travel: If the PCs travel via slower means, such as by horseback or ship, increase all DCs for the obstacle by 5. Particularly slow travel (such as by walking) costs the party an entire round from the 6 they have to complete the chase.

Avengers of Sin.name: Avengers of Sin
Avengers of Sin.text:
Avengers of Sin

The PCs have an additional resource they can tap to foil Xanderghul’s plans: the spirits of the runelords they encountered in the Crypt of Runes! A PC who has a @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22006advent.JournalEntryPage.06vengeancefea00]{Vengeance Feat} can summon the runelords’ vengeful spirits to gain a +2 status bonus to any skill check they make at a Doomsday Door location that matches their feat’s sin.

Aethusa’s Plan.text:
Aethusa’s Plan

Regardless of whether Aethusa helped during Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands, she contacts the PCs shortly thereafter to remind them that she has a part to play in defeating Xanderghul. As she explained, Aethusa is being used by Xanderghul as a living soul cage—and furthermore, he could use any of the Risen Runelords he’s created as the same. While he must be present to potentially posses her again, if he were to die, he could simply hop into her body or into that of a Risen Runelord and simply start his plans over.

Should that occur, Aethusa admits that killing her would prevent Xanderghul from possessing her again—but she doesn’t want to die, and this tactic does nothing to prevent Xanderghul from possessing the bodies of his Risen Runelords, a few of whom he’s certainly hidden away in secret locations. A better solution, Aethusa notes, is to find a way to sever Xanderghul’s link to herself and the Risen Runelords all at once. The best place to start this research is the three locations the party visited earlier while researching the Emerald Chambers: the Sihedron Council in Magnimar, Korvosa’s Acadamae, and Riddleport’s Cypher Lodge.

This section uses the Research subsystem (Pathfinder GM Core 190). The PCs don’t have to overcome any challenges to access the research sites as, by now, the NPCs at the locations are happy to lend what aid they can. Each research round takes one day. The PCs can spend as much time researching as they like, but if they take more than three days to finish, the research they’ve been doing weighs so heavily on their minds that they find themselves dreaming about it—and in so doing, unknowingly alert Dream Aethusa in the Dreamlands (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event4aethus00]{Here} for more details).

Sihedron Council: Sheila Heidmarch opens the council’s documents and libraries up for the PCs to investigate.

  • Maximum RP 3
  • Research Checks @Check[academia-lore|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or @Check[library-lore|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to research in Sheila's library, @Check[diplomacy|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or @Check[society|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to consult with Sheila's contacts, @Check[perception|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to stumble upon pertinent information

Cypher Lodge: Elias Tammerhawk puts the Cypher Lodge’s best minds on the task, so that the PCs can direct them to aid in the research.

  • Maximum RP 3
  • Research Checks @Check[academia-lore|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or @Check[library-lore|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to search the Order’s library for leads, @Check[arcana|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] or @Check[occultism|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to collaborate with the cyphermages, @Check[perception|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to stumble upon pertinent information

The Acadamae: When the cult of the Trinity Star tried to open Doomsday Door beneath Korvosa, the Acadamae suffered heavy damage, requiring some heavy lifting and repair work before certain key documents the PCs need can be studied.

  • Maximum RP 3
  • Research Checks @Check[crafting|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to help repair broken supports and restore damaged texts, @Check[athletics|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to help put the grounds in order and clear rubble, @Check[perception|dc:41|traits:concentrate,exploration,linguistic,action:Research|name:Research] to stumble upon information

Xanderghul’s Immortality Research 17

  • unique

Research Checks Sihedron Council (Magnimar), Cypher Lodge (Riddleport), Acadamae (Korvosa)

2 Research Points Aethusa’s theory that she and the risen runelords have become Xanderghul’s soul cages is correct. Further, so long as at least one of these living soul cages exists, Xanderghul can create additional living soul cages with ease, so simply hunting down the remaining runelords would be futile.

4 Research Points Aethusa, like the risen runelords, no longer sleeps. This suggests the nature of Xanderghul’s link to them is related to the Dreamlands, a dimension formed from the dreams of the sleepers in the Universe. Unlike the risen runelords, who were woven from energy Xanderghul siphoned directly from the Dimension of Dreams, Aethusa remains a living, breathing person. To use her body as a living soul cage, Xanderghul must have created a duplicate of her somewhere in the Dreamlands. Destroying Aethusa’s dream simulacrum would sever Xanderghul’s link to her—and perhaps show the PCs how to prevent the runelord from creating more duplicates.

6 Research Points The Dreamlands are a vast place, large enough to contain the dreams of all creatures that have ever or shall ever dream. Rather than start from nothing in seeking out Aethusa’s dream simulacrum, her physical body can be used as a focus during the casting of interplanar teleport or planar displacement, allowing the PCs to arrive in the region her simulacrum now inhabits and saving potentially days or even weeks of dreaming to track her down.

9 Research Points @UUID[Actor.8XOWRd5RVg8xTi0v]{Scroll}
Knowing that they need to travel to the Dreamlands, the PCs’ investigations have led them to discover a long-forgotten scroll of interplanar teleport that their allies encourage them to keep. Further, the PCs’ exhaustive research prepares them for their encounter with the dream simulacrum, granting them a +4 circumstance bonus to initiative when they meet her in the Dreamlands.

Reward: For each Research Point the PCs earn, award the group 5 XP, to a maximum of 45 XP if they earn all 9 RP.
Aethusa’s Plan.name: Aethusa’s Plan

Into the Dreamlands.name: Into the Dreamlands
Into the Dreamlands.text:
Into the Dreamlands

The remainder of this chapter takes place in the Dreamlands, starting with the party traveling to the region Xanderghul traveled to when he constructed Aethusa’s dream copy as part of the rite to transform her into a living soul cage. If the PCs discovered the scroll of interplanar teleport during their research, they can use it to travel to the Dreamlands as soon as they’re ready. Alternatively, if they discovered the formula for @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.HmKajQS0DP23bipp]{Planar Displacement} in the Crypt of Runes, they could spend time learning that ritual and use it to travel to the Dreamlands. And of course, one of the PCs, or even Aethusa could cast the spell on their behalf

Dream Cyrusian.name: Dream Cyrusian
Dream Cyrusian.text:
Dream Cyrusian

Though Xanderghul first created Aethusa’s dream simulacrum less than a year ago, the region in the Dreamlands he chose to keep the simulacrum safe has existed for as long as anyone there remembers. Unlike its namesake, Dream Cyrusian isn’t the capital of a great empire, but rather an unassuming village at the borders of a dark wood. Arriving here via more traditional methods of travel, even in dreams, would take months at best, but using Aethusa as a focus allows the PCs to appear at the village’s outskirts. Using Aethusa in this way prevents her from traveling with the PCs—even if she’s the one who casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport} to travel there with them, she remains behind on Golarion.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.O961EnJlUvOQpiuV]{Dreamlands}

When the party first arrives at the village of Dream Cyrusian, the residents are guarded. Only after the PCs assure them they aren’t “nightmares” from the nearby forest do the villagers become more welcoming. There’s no need to make any skill checks here—the PCs are powerful enough that earning the villagers’ trust is automatic if they wish. If the PCs antagonize the villagers, they panic and flee into their cottages, and the PCs learn nothing before @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03event4aethus00]{Event 4} begins shortly thereafter.

Speaking to the Villagers.name: Speaking to the Villagers
Speaking to the Villagers.text:
Speaking to the Villagers

After speaking with the villagers a few minutes, the PCs learn the following:

  • This village is called Cyrusian. Its residents are woods-folk who’ve lived here for generations. Except for brief, daytime forays into the nearby Endless Wood, no one has ever traveled beyond the village’s borders. They’ve never really needed to.
  • The Endless Forest is inhabited by nightmares and the hunters who track them—shadowy figures nearly as terrifying as the nightmares themselves. The forest earned its name from the fact that the wood seems to expand each night at dusk. The forest would swallow Cyrusian whole were it not for the magic amulet worn by their Lord Mayor.
  • Until recently, Cyrusian’s mayor was a man named Simon Cradle. He kept the horrors of the Endless Forest at bay with a magic amulet, but Simon has been replaced by Lady Aethusa, a powerful wizard from parts unknown after she stole the amulet from him. Aethusa arrives each night to receive offerings and adoration from the villagers in return for her protection.

If the PCs ask to speak with Simon Cradle (calm male human dream traveler 12), they find the man in his cottage poking at a strange contraption (a typewriter). As a dreamer from a far distant world called Earth, Simon’s dress is unusual and, unlike the other villagers, he understands that neither Cyrusian nor the Endless Forest are “real.” (If pressed, Simon admits he’s not from the Dreamlands. He’s a bookkeeper—and aspiring novelist—from a place called “Boston.”) He’s unfazed by the loss of his title as Lord Mayor, as the change gives him more time to devote to writing. If asked about Aethusa, Simon confirms she isn’t a “dream” like the other villagers. “She’s like you and me,” he says with a wink. “From somewhere else.”

Event 4: Aethusa Arrives.text:
Event 4: Aethusa Arrives Severe 17

Simon and the other villagers have little else useful to tell the PCs about Aethusa; unless the PCs press them, the villagers even fail to mention that Aethusa typically arrives riding on the back of a dragon! Before long, the villagers wander back to collect their offerings (mushrooms, bird eggs, and flowers harvested from the Endless Forest) in anticipation of Aethusa’s arrival. In the meantime, the PCs can make whatever preparations they’d like, such as scouting the village square (see the map on the inside back cover) where Aethusa is expected to arrive.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.AQypK1YpO38fcckg]{Trinity Star}

Event 4: Aethusa Arrives Severe 17

@UUID[Actor.zsny30XTtWeEQSe0]{Dream Aethusa} @UUID[Actor.w13Ji0JCryj4zm3E]{Mirage Dragon (Ancient)} @UUID[Actor.7SyzhlbbxuHH2qJC]{Trinity Star}

Creatures: Just before dusk, an ancient mirage dragon appears in the sky. On the creature’s back is a figure the PCs recognize as Aethusa, wearing a green cloak frilled with peacock feathers. As the dragon descends, they see Aethusa gripping a bec-de corbin much like the one wielded by Xanderghul. Though this dream copy looks like Aethusa, her thoughts and desires are as much Xanderghul’s as her own. As soon as she spots the party, Dream Aethusa attacks. She’s already cast her 7th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.A2JfEKe6BZcTG1S8]{Fly}, so her first action in combat is to dismount from the nameless dragon that serves her but keeps to the skies as she rains down spells from above. The dragon lands amid the PCs to fight them in melee—a creature made of raw dreamstuff, once it’s slain, it fades away into nothing.

If the PCs attacked the villagers, or if the PCs took longer than 3 days to research Xanderghul’s immortality, Dream Aethusa arrives with additional allies—four adult mirage dragons that obey her commands. This increases the event to an Extreme 17 encounter.

Hazard: When Dream Aethusa dies, a shell of shimmering energy surrounds her body for 10 minutes. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] or @Check[occultism|dc:36|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] check or @Check[nature|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] or @Check[religion|dc:38|traits:concentrate,exploration,secret,action:identify-magic|name:Identify Magic] check to Identify Magic recognizes the energy shell as a sliver of Xanderghul’s mythic power which, even now, the runelord summons back. Once this mythic power is ready to return to Xanderghul, the PCs will have only a small window in which to intercept it. Until then, the PCs can Refocus and tend to their wounds as needed.

After 10 minutes, the dream simulacrum’s body rises into the air and transforms into a comet with three blazing tails: one blood red, one jet black, and the third a display of iridescent color. For the next 30 seconds, the comet circles about the village square, leaving a path of destruction in its wake. If the PCs haven’t disabled the Trinity Star hazard after 5 rounds, the comet disappears into the Dreamlands sky and hurtles back to the Universe, returning Xanderghul’s mythic power to him.

If the Trinity Star is destroyed or disabled, the comet explodes in a burst of blinding (but ultimately harmless) multicolored light. When their vision returns a few moments later, the PCs find that their bodies now glow with the same energy as Xanderghul’s mythic power. This glow swiftly fades, but the PCs sense that their mythic destinies have been interwoven with that of Xanderghul. Each PC immediately understands something astounding: while Xanderghul could still be reborn in the body of one of his Risen Runelords, this ability won’t work if he’s slain by one of the PCs. From this point onward, if Xanderghul is slain by a PC, he’ll be dead forever! (This destiny passes on to new PCs created to replace ones by the same player for the remainder of this campaign.)

Treasure: All that remains of Dream Aethusa after the Trinity Star is destroyed is her gear. Among this equipment is a pentagonal green stone amulet onto which has been carved a rune in the shape of a five-branched twig. A successful @Check[occultism|dc:30] check allows a PC to identify this rune as a depiction of the elder sign, yet this amulet isn’t a fully functional version of the powerful ward—merely a replica worth 20 gp (the idea that it keeps the horrors of the Endless Forest at bay is merely a superstition). If the PCs return the amulet to the villagers, Simon retrieves a spare typewriter from his cottage and gives it to the party as thanks. Though its keys are prone to sticking, this strange 1 Bulk invention is worth 2,500 gp for its novelty. The dream hunter’s lodge also belonged to Simon, but he not only encourages the PCs to keep it and also tells them how to use it.

Reward: Disabling the Trinity Star is a Mythic Deed, earning the PCs 3 Mythic Points each.
Event 4: Aethusa Arrives.name: Event 4: Aethusa Arrives

A Cry for Help.name: A Cry for Help
A Cry for Help.text:
A Cry for Help

Once the PCs destroy the Trinity Star, but before they leave the Dreamlands, they hear a familiar voice calling out to them as if from across an unimaginable distance. This is Liralarue, sending a psychic distress beacon to the party. Anticipating that Liralarue might assist the PCs in stopping Xanderghul if she remained free, the Ashen Man imprisoned her shortly after the party’s first encounter with her (as described in the beginning of Pathfinder Adventure Path #219: Lord of the Trinity Star). Though imprisoned, Liralarue can call out to the PCs psychically, now that they’re on the same plane as her and Xanderghul’s occluding influence has been lifted. Through this psychic link, she directs them to her location: a region of the Plateau of Leng known as the Oubliette Plains.

If the PCs ask about the Oubliette Plains in Dream Cyrusian, only Simon recognizes the name. He explains that the Oubliette Plains rest atop a plateau a great distance north from the village. Traveling there would take many weeks, he claims, even if the party could survive the dangers that surely lurk along the route. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[occultism|dc:36|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[arcana|dc:38|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge], @Check[nature|dc:38|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge], or @Check[religion|dc:38|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge comes up with an alternate method of traveling to the Oubliette Planes—and if no PC comes up with this idea, Simon suggests it himself. Leng, as part of the Dreamlands, can be reached by a focused attempt to travel there while sleeping. Normally, the ability to deliberately and physically travel to the Dreamlands in dreams is a skill that only the most experienced of dreamers can ever develop, but the psychic link Liralarue has used to contact the PCs, built off of their shared experience at the start of this Adventure Path, can serve the dreaming mind as a beacon. In theory, the PCs could follow her call when they sleep and transport the party to the Oubliette Planes simply by going to bed.

Traveling to Leng.name: Traveling to Leng
Traveling to Leng.text:
Traveling to Leng

Once the PCs decide to travel to Leng, they can do so simply by falling asleep in close proximity. As they head to bed, each PC must concentrate on the idea of listening for Liralarue’s voice and then following it. Each PC who sleeps can then attempt a @Check[occultism|dc:38], @Check[arcana|dc:40], @Check[nature|dc:40], or @Check[religion|dc:40], or @Check[perception|dc:43] check to follow her voice. If even one PC succeeds at one of these checks, the entire party awakens in Leng’s Oubliette Plains. Of course (and you should make sure the PCs realize this), this method of travel doesn’t work in reverse—if they use this method of traveling to Leng, they’ll have to use another to get back to Golarion! Interplanar teleport works great for this, as does planar displacement. The PCs can’t know it now, but Liralarue can aid them in returning to Golarion as well, once they rescue her.

Traveling to Leng via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.HmKajQS0DP23bipp]{Planar Displacement} instead of dreaming oneself there is also possible, but this travel is distorted and inaccurate. If the PCs use this method to travel to Leng, they arrive several days’ travel from their destination. They can still follow Liralarue’s telepathic beacon, but this journey across the plateau should not be easy. The @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22005terror]{Terrors of Leng} article presents advice for adventuring on Leng, as well as several hazards you can use to vex and torment the PCs with on their journey.

The Oubliette Plains of Leng.name: The Oubliette Plains of Leng
The Oubliette Plains of Leng.text:
The Oubliette Plains of Leng

West of the ruins of Sarkomand on the Plateau of Leng lies a region known as the Oubliette Plains, a windswept land where some of the Dreamlands’ most horrifying dreams are kept. As far as the eye can see, spindle-shaped towers of steel float above the plain, tethered to the ground by cables of spider silk hundreds of feet in length. Every so often, cross-sections of individual spindles rotate, spinning as if along a central axis before returning to their original form.

As the PCs approach, they have a few minutes to take in this otherworldly vista. Though hundreds of spindles float above the Oubliette Plains, Liralarue senses the PCs as they draw near, and her psychic transmissions make it obvious which of the towers she’s imprisoned in, yet once the PCs approach area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03anchorpoint000]{C1}, her psychic beacon loses its focus—the PCs must explore further to find her and rescue her.

Liralarue’s Oubliette.name: Liralarue’s Oubliette
Liralarue’s Oubliette.text:
Liralarue’s Oubliette

The oubliette where Liralarue is imprisoned is a spindle-shaped tower roughly 400 feet from top to bottom, with its lower point a further 400 feet off the ground. The cables that tether the oubliette to the ground converge at its lowermost point. A passageway secured with a portcullis stands near the bottom of the oubliette’s western face, while an opening at the bottommost point provides an alternate entrance.

The oubliette’s walls are made of ten-foot-thick dull-gray steel. Floors within the oubliette have a 20-foot-high ceiling (unless otherwise noted in the text), and each is separated from the floor above and below by a ten-foot-thick layer of steel. A 20-foot-wide shaft piercing the length of the oubliette provides access to each level, but only when the separators of the oubliette are properly aligned. These steel separators can be rotated individually by a device called a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.GSVzDZFbnreVWGRD]{Spindle Key}, and doing so closes off access between those two floors with a ten-foot-wide solid steel barrier. Note that there are no stairs or ladders connecting these floors—a creature must climb, fly, or use other forms of travel (such as translocate) to move up or down the shaft to access floors above or below. Climbing the inner walls in this manner requires a @Check[athletics|dc:40|traits:move,skill,action:climb|name:Climb].

All interior areas of the oubliette are unlit unless otherwise indicated by the text.

Anchor Point.name: Anchor Point
Anchor Point.text:
C1. Anchor Point

Wrist-thick strands of what appear be black silk connect to anchor points at the corners of an inverted, pyramid-shaped impression in the earth. A giant iron spindle floats hundreds of feet above, tethered to the ground by these strands. About halfway between the pit’s northern and eastern points, the horn of some strange beast balances atop a metal spike driven into the ground. Shards of glass are scattered about the area, crunching nosily with every step.

The shards of glass are remnants of the “bubble cells” that imprison the nightmares in the oubliettes above (see area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}). The shards have lost their magic and can be crushed easily in one’s hand, although their edges remain sharp.

While the PCs might assume the horn near the pit is a signaling horn, a closer inspection reveals that the horn’s tip connects to the spike driven into the ground—while the horn is hollow, there’s no place for the PCs to blow into it. The horn spirals like a helix but is otherwise unidentifiable.

In fact, the horn is a magical speaking tube: any words spoken into its wider end are magically transmitted as telepathic messages into the mind of Javownir in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3} above. If the PCs test the device, Javownir receives the message and responds a few moments later, his raspy telepathic voice manifesting in the mind of whoever holds the magical speaking tube.

If the PCs aren’t insulting or antagonistic, they can carry on a telepathic conversation with Javownir. He explains the current situation within the oubliette. Unless the party grows belligerent, Javownir agrees to lower the oubliette for them, seeing their arrival as an opportunity to rid himself of the Bittersweet Sisters. He can also raise the oubliette’s portcullis (in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}), although he warns that doing so will release the elder shantaks in that area. Javownir is more hesitant to alert the PCs about the maze-weavers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2}, as he has a fondness for the spiders and relies on them to raise and lower the oubliette.

If they have means to do so, the PCs can simply fly to the oubliette’s gate at area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3} (or to the opening in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2}, although that entrance isn’t obvious from this distance). Alternatively, the PCs can climb the oubliette’s anchor cables, which are woven from the silk of the maze-weavers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2}. Climbing the cables is a simple task for characters of this level (@Check[athletics|dc:20|traits:move,skill,action:climb|name:Climb] check), but halfway through the ascent (about 200 feet above the ground), a chill gust forces anyone on the strands to succeed at a @Check[athletics|dc:40] check to hang on. Characters who fall can Grab an Edge with a @Check[reflex|dc:36|traits:manipulate,action:grab-an-edge|name:Grab an Edge] save but otherwise plummet to the ground. Moments later, the unnatural movement on the cables alerts the maze-weavers, who scuttle down the cables to attack. The combat with the maze-weavers is only a Low encounter but fighting the spiders while climbing might prove difficult!

The PCs might think to sever the cables or pull out the anchors that tether the oubliette to the ground. Each cable has Hardness 15, 60 HP (BT 30), and typical object immunities. Pulling an anchor the ground requires a successful @Check[athletics|dc:40|traits:attack,skill,action:force-open|name:Force Open] check. So long as the oubliette remains tethered to the ground by at least one cable, it remains floating in midair, but once the final cable is removed, the structure descends gently, locking into place inside the pit so that it stands upright like an obelisk. If the PCs take this course without speaking to Javownir first, he assumes the oubliette is under attack. As the spire descends, Javownir opens the portcullis to release the shantaks in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}.

Finally, the PCs can pull the oubliette to the ground by hauling on its cables until the oubliette locks in place. To do so, at least three PCs must work together and succeed at three simultaneous @Check[athletics|dc:38] checks. If only two PCs work together, the DC of the check increases to @Check[athletics|dc:41]. Only a PC who is legendary in Athletics can perform the feat alone by succeeding at a @Check[athletics|dc:46] check.

Reward: Regardless of how they do so, reward the PCs 10 XP for finding a way to enter the oubliette. Pulling the oubliette to the ground without assistance is a Mythic Deed, earning the PC who accomplishes the feat 1 Mythic Point.

Minimum-Security.name: Minimum-Security
Minimum-Security.text:
C4. Minimum-Security Moderate 17

Clusters of what appear to be soap bubbles, the largest of which could contain a fully grown human, grow throughout this area. In the chamber’s southwest corner stands a marble column nearly fifteen feet high. Atop the column is a statue depicting a muscled, lion-headed man locked in battle with an enormous serpent.

C4. Minimum-Security Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.T5IcN50iJw5Paf5N]{Disordered Axolotls (2)}

Creatures: The bubbles are more examples of the cells described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03entranceunde00]{C3}. Currently, all are empty, except two. Inside a bubble in the northeastern formation float two creatures that look like pink-and-blue axolotls. If the PCs approach, the creatures alternate between making playful circuits around their cells and tapping forlornly against the “glass” making up their bubble prisons.

Despite their cute appearances, both creatures are dangerous. While they appear to be puppy-dog sized amphibians, both are in fact animate nightmares, and the bubbles they’re trapped in have become unusually weakened. Any solid blow struck from the outside can shatter the “axolotl” prison. Alternatively, the two smash free as soon as it appears that the PCs are moving on to a different floor. Regardless, when they are released, each returns to their terrifying true forms: a 10-foot-tall distortion of axolotls whose limbs jut from their bodies at disturbing angles. These nightmares were spawned from a breakdown of law and order; if released, they use their Panicking Touch ability to sow confusion via its Disorder effect. The nightmares pursue the PCs throughout the oubliette; if they flee entirely, the animate nightmares wait an hour for their return, then abandon the oubliette forever.

Low-Security.name: Low-Security
Low-Security.text:
C5. Low-Security Moderate 17

More formations of organic-looking bubbles grow throughout this area. Several of the largest bubbles appear to have shattered, littering the floor with shards of broken glass.

The bubble cells on this level are identical to those on the minimum-security level, but many are broken. The few cells that remain unbroken are currently empty.

C5. Low-Security Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.TYZkUOrgSNyMOFqp]{Aceta} @UUID[Actor.XEHXfbjA2ZeKb3LA]{Famine Bear}

Creatures: This level is currently occupied by Aceta, the youngest of the Bittersweet Sisters, who is here “playing” with an animate nightmare she released from one of the bubble cells. This nightmare was spawned from a fear of famine and is shaped like a grizzly bear with a fleshless skull. When the PCs arrive, Aceta has just finished “feeding” a hapless human traveler she snatched up from elsewhere to the famine bear, enjoying the fact that no matter how much the nightmare “eats” it never gets full. She attacks the party immediately, targeting them with spells as the nightmare rushes them. Once it looks likely the PCs are going to win the encounter, Aceta retreats (either via the shaft or, if that route is blocked, by Riding the Moonbeams) to alert her sister Raanka in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03highsecurity00]{C6}.

Maximum-Security.name: Maximum-Security
Maximum-Security.text:
C7. Maximum-Security Severe 17

The separator between this room and area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03upperpointun00]{C8} above is rotated, blocking easy access upward.

A single bubble, nearly thirty feet in diameter, rises from the floor near the western wall of this level. In each of the chamber’s four corners, portrait-sized mirrors balance on tripods made of polished ebony. Reflected in the surface of each mirror is the image of a moon hanging in the nighttime sky. The glow from these moons fills the chamber with silver light.

The bubble cell against the western wall contains a terrifying prisoner: an elite animate nightmare that formed when an entire world was torn apart by Yog-Sothoth. The cell’s magic barely alleviates the horror of this nightmare’s true form: a mass of writhing tentacles that mirrors Yog-Sothoth’s incarnation as the Lurker at the Threshold. Even the Bittersweet Sisters fear this nightmare, but in desperation, Spleen is trying to set it free (see Creatures, below).

The mirrors in the corners of the room belong to the Bittersweet Sisters, who brought them when they arrived here from Jandelay. Each mirror reflects the moonlight of the god @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.WloVxo6HXJdS4YTt]{Groetus}, who hangs like a skull-faced moon above the Boneyard. The mirrors shed this unsettling moonlight into their corresponding quadrants of the chamber, allowing the hags to benefit from their Moonlight’s Kiss ability. Each mirror can be shattered with a Strike or otherwise rendered inoperable with a single Interact action (by covering the mirror with a cloak, tipping it off its tripod, and so on).

Scene Notes Macros

@UUID[Macro.fWzVJ7SdTbyx4gN9]{Break Mirror NW} @UUID[Macro.KHlcG2iPwSG66hKV]{NE} @UUID[Macro.5NzmXSnIqYSuM5TX]{SW} @UUID[Macro.DPPYcjj5ZO4bW0Lx]{SE} | @UUID[Macro.hDQ04KCSfpRZiwqt]{Burst Bubble}

C7. Maximum-Security Severe 17

@UUID[Actor.EAtCrHLzlytvvVjL]{Spleen} @UUID[Actor.8tsFnx9wfP6JiSp2]{Lurking Cataclysm}

Creatures: Spleen, the eldest of the Bittersweet Sisters, is in this chamber working to overcome the bubble cell’s defenses and release the nightmare trapped inside. When the PCs arrive, she’s just managed to decipher a method of opening the bubble cell, only to realize that in doing so, she’s started a chain reaction that will cause the cell to burst. Three rounds after the encounter with Spleen begins, the nightmare within breaks free, attacking the PCs, Spleen, and any other creatures in the chamber indiscriminately.

In combat, Spleen targets the PCs with her most damaging spells. Once engaged in melee, she keeps to the areas of the chamber lit by moonlight from the mirrors, using the extra action granted by Moonlight’s Kiss to make claw Strikes. If one (or both) of Spleen’s sisters are here, the hags work together to defeat the PCs, and this encounter escalates to beyond Extreme, but the introduction of the disaster-themed animate nightmare could be something that tips the flow of the fight in the PCs’ direction.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.ZzemVlPly4XGJ0JP]{Mirrors} @UUID[Actor.45Zn7KrsIPG4lpiW]{Leather Thong}
Except for their ability to reflect the Groetus-moon, the Sisters’ mirrors possess no magical properties. Nevertheless, the mirrors can be sold as a curiosities for 1,500 gp each, provided they survive the battle. The ebony tripods on which the mirrors rest are worth 75 gp each. Strung on a leather thong around Spleen’s neck is the key that unlocks the masks worn by Javownir and Liralarue, as well as a fate tempter’s ring.

Upper Point.name: Upper Point
Upper Point.text:
C8. Upper Point Moderate 17

Normally, the shaft connecting area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7} and the oubliette’s upper point is a mere 10 feet long. However, the recent convergence of such powerful magic—including the arrival of the Bittersweet Sisters, Liralarue’s imprisonment, and the release of the various animate nightmares—has warped the length of the shaft, transforming it into an extradimensional space. To make matters worse, the maze-weavers from area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2} have extended their extradimensional webbing into the shaft. Finally, the separator disk between the two areas is rotated, requiring the spindle key open it. Even with the oubliette properly aligned, the PCs must traverse the extradimensional space before they can reach Liralarue’s chambers. When the PCs first investigate the shaft leading to area C8, read or paraphrase the following.

Rather than leading to another chamber, the shaft opens into an endless black void crisscrossed with webs that stretch to infinity. The opening to a second shaft hangs above the void hundreds of feet overhead, though from this vantage point it appears no larger than a distant star.

C8. Upper Point Moderate 17

@UUID[Actor.LiQDLBP3kMT9oeP9]{Apocalypse Stormfront} @UUID[Actor.5R0z7j2nKVkBjF53]{Maze-Weavers (2)}

Hazard: To reach Liralarue’s quarters, the PCs must climb the maze-weavers’ webs while being buffeted by visions of Golarion’s destruction. When describing these visions to the players, try to pick locations their characters have recently visited or places that are familiar to them; as the PCs climb, they must watch helplessly as these beloved locations are destroyed before their eyes.

Note that the Apocalypse Stormfront is a nightmare hazard, as detailed in the article on @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22005terror]{Terrors of Leng}. Disabling the nightmare involves the PCs navigating and pushing through the eternity and torment it creates—by succeeding in the face of these visions and this eternal voyage, they can unravel the nightmare with their own convictions.

As long as this nightmare remains, the entirety of Liralarue’s Prison beyond remains impossibly distant at the far end of this void; only by disabling this hazard can the PCs progress. Once a creature enters the Apocalypse Stormfront, they can exit back into area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7} by spending three actions to attempt a @Check[will|dc:41] save; on a success, they find themselves back, safe, in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03maximumsecur00]{C7}. The number of successes the PCs accumulate toward the six required to disable this nightmare does not reset if they retreat from the Apocalypse Stormfront.

Creatures: If the PCs haven’t dealt with the maze-weavers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03lowerpointun00]{C2}, the spiders sense the disturbance of their webs in this area. One round later, two of the maze-weavers arrive, attacking the PCs as they climb. The spiders are immune to the effects of the Apocalypse Stormfront hazard, and their presence in the encounter increases the difficulty to Severe.

Reward: Reaching Liralarue’s Prison is a mythic deed; award each character 3 Mythic Points.

Liralarue’s Prison.name: Liralarue’s Prison
Liralarue’s Prison.text:
Liralarue’s Prison Trivial 17

Once the PCs disable the Apocalypse Stormfront hazard, they find themselves in the uppermost point of the oubliette. Javownir used this chamber as his home, but the Bittersweet Sisters ousted the denizen of Leng shortly after they arrived. The room now serves as a prison for the Sisters’ captive, Liralarue.

This chamber is shaped like the interior of a pyramid. The space is filled with modest but comfortable-looking furnishings, including a small dining table, a writing desk flanked by bookshelves, a wardrobe, and a pair of divans.

Liralarue’s Prison Trivial 17

@UUID[Actor.7EtywkFz8aRJB5Ap]{Bittersweet Mask}

Hazard: When the PCs arrive, they find a beautiful human woman dressed in gold and purple robes and armed with a naginata, at rest on one of the divans. This is Liralarue, and she wears a mask identical to the one worn by Javownir that must be removed before she can communicate with the PCs. Once the mask is off, Liralarue tells the PCs what she knows about Xanderghul’s plans to destroy Golarion (see @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap22003doorwa.JournalEntryPage.03concludingth00]{Concluding the Adventure} below). While she can’t leave the Dreamlands, she can transport the PCs back to Golarion when they’re ready to continue their fight against Xanderghul.

Reward: For saving Liralarue, award each PC 80 XP.

Concluding the Adventure.name: Concluding the Adventure
Concluding the Adventure.text:
Concluding the Adventure

Once she’s been rescued and has time to speak to the PCs, Liralarue reveals that she has developed the power to see all possible futures but is cursed to never know which one is real. While she can’t say whether Xanderghul’s bid to become a god will succeed, she knows it was the Ashen Man who set the runelord on his current path. The Ashen Man helped Xanderghul escape from the Eclipse in Abaddon then showed him how he might offer the Saga Lands as a sacrifice and become a god worshipped on a brand-new world. The PCs prevented Xanderghul from expediting this process via the Doomsday Doors, but he hasn’t given up. Liralarue warns the PCs that Xanderghul has traveled to Jandelay to complete Golarion’s addition to that plane of destroyed worlds. Liralarue can’t exist outside of the Dreamlands, but now that the PCs have rescued her, she can aid them from beyond the wall of sleep as they take steps to stop Xanderghul’s plans. Except for being able to send the PCs back to Golarion from the Dreamlands when they wish, her aid truly begins with the start of the next adventure, so notes on her history and personality and the ways she can help aren’t presented in this volume; the next adventure will provide these details.

For now, though, the PCs have more than earned a chance to rest and recover from their adventures—at least until news reaches them that Runelord Belimarius has made her move in a brazen attempt to claim all New Thassilon for herself, as detailed at the start of the final adventure in the Revenge of the Runelords Adventure Path!

Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands.name: Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands
Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands.text:
Event 3: Saving the Saga Lands

Once the PCs have recovered (grant them all 3 Mythic Points as well if you’re not starting a new session at this point), it’s time for them to race against the Risen to save the Saga Lands. While each of the six groups seeking to open a different Doomsday Door are large, and each group is led by a level 11 risen runelord, the challenge of this event lies not in combat, but in gathering allies, deploying a plan, and then acting to prevent the opening of six Doomsday Doors before time runs out.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.oU34lExuiNfgXT3i.PlaylistSound.C1Ayc4Kh3fh4Laxn]{Nature}

This event uses the Beat the Clock version of the chase rules (Pathfinder GM Core 192). Each chase round represents the work of several days as the PCs race across the Saga Lands to assemble their allies, organize a response, and travel to the Doomsday Door sites to stop Xanderghul’s allies from opening them.

The PCs can tackle the six obstacles in any order. The more Doomsday Doors the PCs close before they reach the end of round 6 of the chase, the more lives they save. Any obstacles not completed after the chase’s six rounds are up are automatically lost as the Doomsday Door at that location is opened, releasing a catastrophe that will burden that region for years.

Help from Allies.name: Help from Allies
Help from Allies.text:
Help from Allies

Before the chase begins, work with your players to generate a list of the allies they’ve made thus far in the adventure. These allies could include Ayavah, Elias Tammerhawk, Sheila Heidmarch, Toff Ornelos, Lograsi, Roaring Storm, and Knud Helmarsson. (If the PCs aren’t relying on the omen dragon Kandirvek for travel, he could be an ally as well.) This event assumes the PCs have at least six allies to call upon during the chase but not more than a dozen.

An ally must be deployed to an obstacle; once this is done, that ally cannot aid at other obstacles, and they reduce the Overcome DCs for the obstacle to which they’re deployed by 1, regardless of how long the PCs take to overcome the obstacle. These reductions stack if the PCs deploy multiple allies to a single obstacle.

Doomsday Door Obstacles.name: Doomsday Door Obstacles
Doomsday Door Obstacles.text:
Doomsday Door Obstacles

The PCs can attempt the following six obstacles in any order. Each obstacles has a sin trait—this sin indicates what region of Old Thassilon the obstacle takes place in, and thus whether or not a PC can apply their +2 status bonus for having a matching vengeance feat.

The PCs can also distribute their allies as they wish among these six sites and can continue to redistribute them among obstacles they haven’t yet started or completed. For each obstacle, two key allies are called out as being particularly useful. When one of these two allies is deployed to that obstacle, they decrease the Overcome DCs by 2 points instead of by 1.

For each of these obstacles, an option to use Arcana, Nature, Occultism, or Religion is presented. When a PC chooses to use one of these options, it’s assumed they’re using spells or magic to aid. While you don’t need to build an exact list of what spells and effects the PC employs, allow them to describe what they’re doing. If, at your discretion, the effort involves the expenditure of powerful and appropriate magic of rank 7 or higher, reduce the DC of that skill check by 2.

Jol Obstacle 17

  • Pride

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[survival|dc:38] to navigate sudden blizzards, @Check[thievery|dc:41] to disarm ancient traps, @Check[nature|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to fight the deadly weather with magic

The city of Jol is the capital of Southmoor in the Lands of the Linnorm Kings. Furious blizzards presage the opening of this Doomsday Door. Risen Runelord of Greed Fethryr leads this obstacle, as she and her cultists hunker down in the heart of a trap-ridden vault beneath the Skirim River where the Doomsday Door is hidden.

Key Allies: Knud Helmarsson’s familiarity with the terrain helps you navigate the blizzards; Sheila’s Pathfinders aid in disabling the vault’s traps

Failure: The southern Lands of the Linnorm Kings endure a deadly series of blizzards and storms. If the PCs fail to defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure, a land of eternal winter blooms across the borderlands here, allowing Irrisen to potentially expand their reach while devastating the economy of the Linnorm Kingdoms.

Korvosa Obstacle 17

  • Lust

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[athletics|dc:38] to jump, climb, and force open barriers, @Check[society|dc:41] to mobilize the city’s defenses, @Check[religion|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], or @Check[occultism|dc:46]) to deploy Korvosa’s healers

Disease spreads through the streets of the city, evoking panic and fear about a potential new outbreak of blood veil, the plague that nearly brought Korvosa to her knees years ago. Korvosa’s Doomsday Door lies in a long-forgotten corner of the Vaults, the city’s sprawling sewer system, in a dungeon that was hidden even from Runelord Sorshen. Risen Runelord of Envy Zarve leads this group of cultists.

Key Allies: Roaring Storm leaps across the rooftops without fear and both inspires and aids those who follow; the Acadamae’s wizards, led by Toff Ornelos, hold off the runelords while you press on to the Doomsday Door

Failure: A sudden resurgence of the supernatural disease known as blood veil sweeps through Korvosa, but this time it cannot be stopped, and it spreads throughout southeastern Varisia and into Nidal in a devastating pandemic if the PCs fail to defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure.

Old Xin-Edasseril Obstacle 17

  • Envy

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[diplomacy|dc:38] to navigate bureaucracy to reach the site, @Check[stealth|dc:41] to sneak into the area, @Check[arcana|dc:36] (or @Check[nature|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to avoid remaining arcane wards

Edasseril’s capital was originally located on modern-day Chakikoth Isle in the Ironbound Archipelago, and its here in the depths of a series of caverns that this Doomsday Door lies. Reaching the ancient city requires navigating the nation’s byzantine bureaucracy as flooding and destructive shoreline surges increasingly panic the populace. Risen Runelord of Gluttony Goparlis leads the charge here.

Key Allies: Lograsi uses his influence with Belimarius to pave your way into the nation; Elias Tammerhawk enlists the pirate captains of Riddleport to sail you to Old Xin-Edasseril

Failure: A tsunami wreaks havoc on the coast, while torrential rainstorms cause inland flooding. Fears that the islands might be sinking spread, incidentally spurring Runelord Belimarius even further into expansion onto the mainland. The islands will indeed sink if Runelord Xanderghul isn’t defeated in the next adventure.

Sech Nevali Obstacle 17

  • Sloth

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[intimidation|dc:38] to hold your own among the nightmares; @Check[acrobatics|dc:41] to navigate narrow walkways, @Check[occultism|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to disarm occult energies

Sech Nevali is a temple complex suspended over a chasm. Here, dreams and nightmares grow interchangeable with reality as a plague of horror made real seep out of the opening Doomsday Door. Risen Runelord of Envy Esedrea has forged alliances with the monastery’s graveknight guardians—former warriors of the Peacock Spirit.

Key Allies: Sheila Heidmarch supplies you with texts that include rites of protection from nightmare plagues; Ayavah draws upon ancient texts she’s studied about Sech Nevali’s artistry and architecture to help guide you

Failure: The nightmare plague spreads, and those who slumber and dream in the region must contend with the growing truth that death in a nightmare now equates to death in real life. If the PCs don’t defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure, this nightmare plague spreads swiftly through the Saga Lands.

The Sleeper Obstacle 17

  • Gluttony

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[performance|dc:38] to inspire allies, @Check[athletics|dc:41] to endure the grueling climb, @Check[arcana|dc:36] (or @Check[nature|dc:46], @Check[occultism|dc:46], or @Check[religion|dc:46]) to battle the magical wards that protect the Sleeper

A monument in the Hold of Belkzen, the Sleeper is sculpted to resemble a dragon wrapped around a mountaintop. You must inspire your troops to climb the mountain into the dragon’s maw, then cut down the undead hordes pouring through the Doomsday Door hidden in the deep cavern within the Sleeper. These hordes are commanded by Risen Runelord of Gluttony Aethusa.

Key Allies: Roaring Storm’s bravery inspires the troops forward; Toff Ornelos helps you to navigate the ancient magic found within the Sleeper

Failure: A horde of undead spills out of the Sleeper and invades the surrounding region. If the PCs don’t defeat Runelord Xanderghul in the next adventure, this invasion of undead from an unexpected direction throws the Hold of Belkzen into chaos and war

Windsong Abbey Obstacle 17

  • Wrath

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[stealth|dc:38] to creep behind enemy lines, @Check[intimidation|dc:41] to cow the invading fiends, @Check[religion|dc:36] (or @Check[arcana|dc:46], @Check[nature|dc:46], or @Check[occultism|dc:46]) to use magic to defeat the invading fiends

Located on Varisia’s Lost Coast, Windsong Abbey serves as a neutral ground where opposing religions resolve their differences. This Doomsday Door is located deep below the abbey and, upon arrival, you find the local priests fighting to hold off an invasion of qlippoth that have been seeping through the door below after Risen Runelord of Sloth Ilthyrius infiltrated the site.

Key Allies: Ayavah chastises the unholy fiends; Knud Helmarsson’s Horselords help you chase down and slay fiends who have escaped into the surrounding region.

Failure: Windsong Abbey is destroyed and an army of fiends swarm the land. If Runelord Xanderghul isn’t defeated in the next adventure, this smaller eruption triggers a greater breach into the Outer Rifts at the base of the Pit, just outside of Sandpoint, and a new Worldwound opens on Golarion.
